                              SuitWatch--April 1

  Views on Linux in Business

  --by Doc Searls, Senior Editor of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                                 April Fuel

   Thursday, April 1, 2004--Hey, it's a holiday, so I can't resist
   running some real news-type stories in the newsletter here:

   SCO, known for decades as the acronym for Santa Cruz Operation, has
   changed its name to PO, for Provo Operation. "It kind of goes better
   with our attitude, don't you think?" said Darl McBride, the company
   CEO. Asked if the new name reflects a change in the nature or the
   strategy of the company, McBride said, "If anything, it expresses a
   renewed sense of commitment. Recently we noticed that we hadn't pissed
   off everybody yet. That's still our goal." In a related move, McBride
   also was named CLO, Chief Litigation Officer. His other titles remain.

   As a company-wide exercise in rhetorical restraint, Microsoft has
   challenged its employees to go "just one day" without using the words
   "smart" or "threat". Said CEO Steve Ballmer, "Y'know, after twenty
   years of chanting the same damn things to ourselves, I just got
   freaking tired of it." As part of a long-term plan to change the
   hyper-competitive culture of the company, Microsoft's HR department
   has quietly dropped its requirement that applicants submit their high
   school SAT scores or take the tests again if the original scores
   failed to meet company threshold requirements. "But we're still going
   to grade everybody on a curve", said a company press release.

   In a surprise move, Linus Torvalds for the first time issued a policy
   statement regarding the pronunciation of both his first name and that
   of the operating system he launched almost 14 years ago. "I'm
   'eenus'", he said. "The operating system is 'eenux'. The L is silent
   in both cases. I'm sorry I forgot to mention that before."

   AOL, Apple, Yahoo and Microsoft's MSN group today announced their
   joint intention to "jump ahead into the Nineties" and open up their
   instant messaging clients to servers running XMPP and other open IM
   transport protocols. "We finally realized it was flat-out nuts to keep
   users locked in proprietary silos", the four companies said in a joint
   press release. Nobody at any of the companies could be reached for
   comment.

   Reuters reports the discovery of a Wi-Fi hot spot "about the size of
   Turkey" in the Atlantic Ocean, just west of the Canary Islands. The
   dimensions of the spot were determined by combined reports of
   communications officers on-board container cargo and cruise ships.
   Asked to comment on the quality of the connection through the hot
   spot, Ozmo Zdilmidgi, who works with the Maersk Sealand company, said
   "I dunno. It was WEPped and we couldn't get on."

   Acting swiftly after passage of the Communications Decency Enforcement
   Act, the FCC ordered broadcasters to cease operating on the AM band.
   "We just got tired of it", said FCC Chairman Michael Powell. "We were
   going to fine everybody, but it was easier just to wipe the whole
   thing out." Asked if the Commission would offer an alternative band
   for broadcasters to start over, the weary Powell said, "Why?"

   Responding to threats by Senator John McCain (R-Mars) to mandate a l?
   carte pricing for worthless channels that cable and satellite
   providers feel forced to carry for subscribers, DishTV announced the
   development of a "reality channel reduction policy", in which the
   number of channels on the service would be reduced by viewer call-in
   votes. "Each week viewers will vote one channel off the service", said
   Charles Ergen, Chairman and CEO of DishTV parent EchoStar. "And
   they'll pay to vote, too, which is cool." He added, "Dropping one
   channel per week, we should be down to the original 100 channels in
   three or four years."

   Ending a complete absence of speculation about who would end up buying
   Red Hat, it surprised analysts to learn that the winning suitor was
   Red Flag, the official Linux of the People's Republic of China. "The
   red thing is important to us", said Matthew Szulik, Red Hat's
   Chairman, Chief Executive Officer, President and now Chief Propaganda
   Minister. "It wasn't happening with IBM's blue theme or Oracle's
   whatever-it-is. Plaid? I forget. Anyway, the hat goes well with the
   flag." Asked to comment on the sale, a Red Flag spokesperson said, "We
   did? Really. Oh. That's really nice."

   Sorry, I couldn't resist. See ya next round.

   --
   Doc Searls:

A breakout box such as an EasyBob, could be useful. The laptop should
have a serial port, and you may need an assortment of serial modem, and
null-modem cables and/or port adapters. Some older devices require a
connection through a serial port in order to set up the configuration.
Are you working only with CAT-5 type  cables? What about fiber optics,
which bring up a whole new set of goodies for your bag-o-tricks. Here is
a great source for cable management stuff:
http://andcable.com/intro.html 

Mel

Hi Robert.

Robert Kopp wrote:
> I seem to have a slight problem. I have a Logitech
> Quickcam 3000 which works under Linux, but requires
a
> compressor module for maximum performance. The
source
> code for this module (pwcx.o) is not available; you
> just have to download it for the right combination
of
> kernel version and compiler.
[snip]
> Linux has been making impressive strides toward the
> desktop. But to secure good performance from one of
> the most popular Web cams, it takes a diligent
search
> for a module and a kernel compilation. With Windows,
> it's a five-minute download.)

If this bugs you then I recommend you contact Logitech
and ask them to stop requiring an NDA to get the specs
on some aspects of their cameras:
http://www.logitech.com/index.cfm?countryid=19&languageid=1&page=support/contactcs
Also, their forums:
http://forums.logitech.com/index.html?l=en&c=usa

Here are some details about the NDA:
http://www.smcc.demon.nl/webcam/nda.html

What I recommend you do to solve the problem is
download the "PWCX 8.2.2 super value pack" from here
and use the 2.4.20 module:
http://www.smcc.demon.nl/webcam/release.html#pwcx

Please have a nice day.

Regards,
Technoumena

From technoumena at yahoo.com  Thu Apr  1 12:53:02 2004
From: technoumena at yahoo.com (Technoumena)
Date: Thu Apr  1 12:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] IMQ Kernel Patch
In-Reply-To: <20040401193013.16105.72147.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040401205139.17857.qmail@web41402.mail.yahoo.com>

Dave Scott wrote:
> Yes, I have CONFIG_NETFILTER set.

> From what I understand, I need to apply two patches.
> the first one  (kernel patch) I found at
> http://www.linuximq.net/
> It's labeled for 2.4.24, or 2.4.25.  This is the
> one I applied to kernel sources.

> Now the confusing part, they say I need to
> patch my iptables , since I am using a package
> from Debian, I'm not sure how to do this, I'm 
> guessing I need this iptables patch in place
> before the IMQ options will show in menuconfig.

iptables provides a module and a userspace interface
for configuring netfilter.  While you need the kernel
hooks that CONFIG_NETFILTER provides, the kernel
should be fully buildable independent of the iptables
source package.  You would need the patched iptables
though as the IMQ patch basically extends the
netfilter/iptables system.

With Debian it might be best to just 'apt-get remove
iptables' and then download the 1.2.6a version of
iptables from
http://www.netfilter.org/files/iptables-1.2.6a.tar.bz2
, patch, build and install it.  I couldn't find an IMQ
patched version in the apt-get repos but you might
have more luck.

Now the way the IMQ options are missing in the kernel
configuration menus is interesting.  Check
linux/drivers/net/Config.in for references to IMQ. 
You could also check for the presence of
linux/drivers/net/imq.c.  If nothing turns up in a
'grep -r IMQ *' in your linux source directory
something apparently went wrong with the patch.

Good luck.

Regards,
Technoumena

http://promotions.yahoo.com/design_giveaway/

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Apr  1 23:34:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Apr  1 23:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Restoring an installation
Message-ID: <20040402073307.59345.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com>

I am by now convinced of the importance of using
backup utilities. I have a Linux installation that is
partly functional but does not load kernel modules for
some reason, an important shortcoming. As I send this
message, I'm using Windows.

It occurred to me to make another Linux partition on
my system and install the same distribution from CD's.
Then I suppose I should use rsync to copy files that
do not yet exist in the newly-created installation. I
heard that this was one of the uses of rsync: it does
what xxcopy does for Windows. That, of course, would
even take care of .bash_profile.

There will be a few remaining problems, perhaps. Any
configuration file that is hard-coded with /dev/hdxx
might act up, except for /etc/fstab, which should be
correct. And files like smb.conf and cupsd.conf should
be overwritten on a case-by-case basis.

After that, I should probably clone the installation I
am using so that restoring it will be more
straightforward in the future. So wha't my question?
Is the approach using rsync in my present situation
basically sound?

> I am by now convinced of the importance of using

> even take care of .bash_profile.

> configuration file that is hard-coded with /dev/hdxx
> might act up, except for /etc/fstab, which should be
> correct. And files like smb.conf and cupsd.conf should
> be overwritten on a case-by-case basis.
>
> After that, I should probably clone the installation I
> am using so that restoring it will be more

From technoumena at yahoo.com  Fri Apr  2 12:26:02 2004
From: technoumena at yahoo.com (Technoumena)
Date: Fri Apr  2 12:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Simple graphics programming?
In-Reply-To: <20040402144406.13249.48338.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040402202513.59534.qmail@web41406.mail.yahoo.com>

Aaron Burt wrote:
> Back when I was a kid, I used to write li'l 
> AppleBASIC programs to draw
> interesting geometric figures in hi-res graphics.  
> 
> I have no idea how to write a program that
> draws simple graphical
> figures under Linux.  What modern language
> would a fellow use to do
> silly little things like that in X?  TCL?
> Perl?  Python?  
> 
> I'd rather not fool around with something
> special-purpose and heavy, like Octave.

Hi Aaron.

Although you did say 'modern language', you might
enjoy the familiar usage of Blassic, a BASIC
interpreter:
http://www.arrakis.es/~ninsesabe/blassic/

You might try one of the SDL adaptions.  If you are
familiar with (or want to learn) C, there are several
libraries with 2D primitives such as:
http://sourceforge.net/projects/sagl
http://sdl-draw.sourceforge.net/
http://www.ferzkopp.net/~aschiffler/Software/SDL_gfx-2.0/
http://freshmeat.net/projects/sge/

An easier approach if you don't know C is to use
Pygame, a Python interface to SDL and friends:
http://pygame.seul.org/

There is a good Python package building on Pygame with
primitives and even a turtle graphics module:
http://www.nongnu.org/pygsear/

Python with Tkinter might be a good start as you
probably already have it installed.  In particular,
check out the turtle module:
http://www.python.org/doc/2.3.3/lib/module-turtle.html

You can try it very easily; just start python (by
entering 'python' on the command line) and do the
following:

import turtle
t = turtle.Pen()
t.circle(20)

Python is very easy to learn and is very versatile
language.  I would recommend Python + Tkinter/Turtle
the most.

Regards,
Technoumena

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Apr  2 14:16:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri Apr  2 14:16:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Firewalls (Sonicwall vs. Linux)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404021120440.19854-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404021120440.19854-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1080944118.21621.9.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Fri, 2004-04-02 at 11:28, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> To those familiar with these things, what class/type of Linux box would it
> take -- if possible -- to get the same functionality as the two lower end
> Sonicwall boxes provide?

I'm gonna toot my own horn here and tell you the SnapGear units I sell
(http://nakedape.cc/products/hardware/snapgear) are comparable to the
SonicWall, but not limited to a set number of IP addresses and include
IPSEC and PPTP VPN support.  Like the SonicWalls, they include an easy
web interface for management, plus SSH and telnet access for access to
embedded versions of regular Linux/UNIX network utilities (ping,
traceroute, etc).

For DIY, a Soekris (http://www.soekris.com/) unit makes a nice firewall
if you want to use LEAF (http://leaf.sourceforge.net/) or other embedded
firewall distributions.  The Soekris units are 100-266MHz AMD i586-class
chips with 32-128MB RAM and connectors for CompactFlash, PCMCIA,
mini-PCI, 2+ NICs, etc.  I've used them to make wireless access points
and they're pretty good.

Wil

On Fri, 2 Apr 2004, Robert Kopp wrote:

> I've heard good things about Qt, which is related to KDE in some way. It's
> capable, but probably not really simple.

  Qt is a GUI widget library written in C++. It competes with gtk+ (C) as a
GUI widget library for application interfaces. FWIW, and just as a personal
preference, I prefer the "look and feel" of gtk+ to qt. But, to do graphics
coding I'd use something completely different.

This is not what this file should look like; from my laptop I've got
entries like this:

alias eth0 e100
alias usb-controller usb-uhci
alias eth1 orinoco_pci
alias tty-ldisc-11 irtty
alias char-major-161 ircomm-tty
alias nsc-ircc dongle_id=0x09
alias irda0 nsc-ircc
alias floppy off

Note that it might also be called /etc/modprobe.conf, which is I think
the new preferred name.

To answer your question totally directly in terms of processing power and
memory requirements, you could use a 486 with 16MB of RAM to duplicate
this functionality with a 2.4 kernel, iptables, and a DHCP server.

If you're using a model with VPN capability, you'll probably want a faster
box (pentium class -- the bigger the better on the proc side) and double
the RAM and you'll need to run an OpenVPN service on the firewall box.
There are floppy and CD based distribution in existence to do this.

And while I'm a strong proponent of the floppy firewall, there are some
very fine off the shelf products out there that will do the job at a low
cost and have a smaller physical and power-consumption footprint.

My jobs lately have been using the Netgear FV[SM]318 boxes, but that's
just because I had a line on some really good quality refurbs at a really
low price.

Wil's suggestions are all great.  I'm a fan of the Soekris products, too.
They give you the flexibility of a self-managed linux box on common
hardware with the size and power of a special purpose unit.  They're a
little bit more expensive, though, in many cases.

I'm really only posting to answer the first part of your question which
doesn't really need to be answered, but should be because you asked it.

J.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Apr  2 17:19:01 2004

Subject: [PLUG] New Laptop Toy - NCharge External Battery
Message-ID: <20040403011722.GB30362@gate.kl-ic.com>

This isn't exactly Linux specific, but many of you travel with laptops
so you may be interested.

Last night I was at PLUG with a new toy from Fry's, an NCHARGE 130
(130 Watt-hour) external Li-Ion battery pack.  This gizmo can be
charged from my Thinkpad AC adapter, and provides an additional
6 hours of operation (in addition to my power-guzzling T30's normal
2 hours).  That gets me across the country on an airplane without
hunting down wall sockets in hub airports.   It charges in about
70 minutes, longer if in series with an operating, charging T30.

It costs $260, with an additional $25 for the Thinkpad adapter.
Not cheap, but cheaper than three spare batteries for the T30.
The unit weighs 3 lbs, and is laptop-sized but half an inch thick.

I also considered ordering an Electrovaya Powerpad 120 PP120-D from
Page Computing in LA ($250+shipping), but that requires a separate
charger and Electrovaya has a bad rep (even worse than Fry's :-( ).

Now all I have to worry about is carrying around the energy equivalent
of a stick of dynamite.  The unit is NOT allowed in checked baggage,
I must carry it on board with me, and if they tighten the rules I will
have a high-tech doorstop.

Keith

P.S. Thanks to Keith Packard for showing me his NCHARGE unit.

### This file is automatically generated by update-modules"
#
# Please do not edit this file directly. If you want to change or add
# anything please take a look at the files in /etc/modutils and read
# the manpage for update-modules.
#
### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/0keep
# DO NOT MODIFY THIS FILE!
# This file is not marked as conffile to make sure if you upgrade modutils
# it will be restored in case some modifications have been made.
#
# The keep command is necessary to prevent insmod and friends from ignoring
# the builtin defaults of a path-statement is encountered. Until all other
# packages use the new `add path'-statement this keep-statement is essential
# to keep your system working
keep

### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/0keep

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/actions
# Special actions that are needed for some modules

# The BTTV module does not load the tuner module automatically,
# so do that in here
post-install bttv insmod tuner
post-remove bttv rmmod tuner


### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/actions

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/aliases
# Aliases to tell insmod/modprobe which modules to use

# Uncomment the network protocols you don't want loaded:
# alias net-pf-1 off            # Unix
# alias net-pf-2 off            # IPv4
# alias net-pf-3 off            # Amateur Radio AX.25
# alias net-pf-4 off            # IPX
# alias net-pf-5 off            # DDP / appletalk
# alias net-pf-6 off            # Amateur Radio NET/ROM
# alias net-pf-9 off            # X.25
# alias net-pf-10 off           # IPv6
# alias net-pf-11 off           # ROSE / Amateur Radio X.25 PLP
# alias net-pf-19 off           # Acorn Econet

alias char-major-10-175 agpgart
alias char-major-10-200 tun
alias char-major-81     bttv
alias char-major-108    ppp_generic
alias /dev/ppp          ppp_generic
alias tty-ldisc-3       ppp_async
alias tty-ldisc-14      ppp_synctty
alias ppp-compress-21   bsd_comp
alias ppp-compress-24   ppp_deflate
alias ppp-compress-26   ppp_deflate


# Crypto modules (see http://www.kerneli.org/)
alias loop-xfer-gen-0   loop_gen
alias loop-xfer-3       loop_fish2
alias loop-xfer-gen-10  loop_gen
alias cipher-2          des
alias cipher-3          fish2
alias cipher-4          blowfish
alias cipher-6          idea
alias cipher-7          serp6f
alias cipher-8          mars6
alias cipher-11         rc62
alias cipher-15         dfc2
alias cipher-16         rijndael
alias cipher-17         rc5

alias char-major-195 nvidia

### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/aliases

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/alsa
### DEBCONF MAGIC
# This file was automatically generated by alsa-base's debconf stuff

alias char-major-116 snd
alias char-major-14 soundcore

options snd major=116 cards_limit=4
alias sound-service-0-0 snd-mixer-oss
alias sound-service-0-1 snd-seq-oss
alias sound-service-0-3 snd-pcm-oss
alias sound-service-0-8 snd-seq-oss
alias sound-service-0-12 snd-pcm-oss
alias /dev/dsp* snd-pcm-oss



### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/alsa

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/apm
alias char-major-10-134 apm
alias /dev/apm_bios             /dev/misc/apm_bios
alias /dev/misc/apm_bios        apm

### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/apm

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/nvidia-kernel-nkc
alias char-major-195 nvidia

### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/nvidia-kernel-nkc

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/paths
# This file contains a list of paths that modprobe should scan,
# beside the ones that are compiled into the modutils tools
# themselves.


### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/paths

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/ppp
alias /dev/ppp          ppp_generic
alias char-major-108    ppp_generic
alias tty-ldisc-3       ppp_async
alias tty-ldisc-14      ppp_synctty
alias ppp-compress-21   bsd_comp
alias ppp-compress-24   ppp_deflate

### update-modules: start processing /etc/modutils/setserial
#
# This is what I wanted to do, but logger is in /usr/bin, which isn't loaded
# when the module is first loaded into the kernel at boot time!
#
#post-install serial /etc/init.d/setserial start | logger -p daemon.info -t "setserial
#pre-remove serial /etc/init.d/setserial stop | logger -p daemon.info -t "setserial-mo
#
alias /dev/tts          serial
alias /dev/tts/0        serial
alias /dev/tts/1        serial
alias /dev/tts/2        serial
alias /dev/tts/3        serial
post-install serial /etc/init.d/setserial modload > /dev/null 2> /dev/null
pre-remove serial /etc/init.d/setserial modsave  > /dev/null 2> /dev/null

### update-modules: end processing /etc/modutils/setserial

From aschlemm at comcast.net  Sat Apr  3 18:38:02 2004
From: aschlemm at comcast.net (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat Apr  3 18:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Firewalls (Sonicwall vs. Linux)
In-Reply-To: <406DF17D.8060105@comcast.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404021432130.20753-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <406DF17D.8060105@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <200404031836.42647.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Friday 02 April 2004 15:04 pm, Garl Grigsby wrote:
> Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> > (BTW, the on-line emulator link is broken.)
>
> http://www.cyberguard.com/snapgear/emulator.html
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

The company I work for is spread out to 3 offices and we have 3 Snapgear 
SME570s boxes and they're an impressive little box. The case is the 
size of an 8 port switch and has a hardware encryption engine which I 
think supports something like 500 VPN tunnels. 

We've got a VPN setup between our offices and have a few telecommuters 
that have dedicated firewall/VPN boxes at home. The box supports IPSec, 
L2TP, GRE, and PPTP so it gives a company quite a bit of flexibility in 
allowing VPN connections. Most non-tech people have a Netgear FVS318 
firewall at home and we have others using FreeS/WAN on Linux, and I'm 
using "isakmpd" on an OpenBSD firewall for my tunnel into the office.

For the non-tech users that travel with a Windows laptop a simple to 
configure VPN client is the way to go and that client should completely 
isolate the box from any other network so the Windows box cannot be 
hijacked and uses as a conduit into the VPN. I don't have a lot of 
experience with Windows VPN but I was given a "Nortel Contivity" client 
so I could remotely support a demo system we have setup in the Midwest 
and it does exactly like I describe and totally cuts my laptop off from 
all external network access expect the VPN connection.

I only had to enter a userid, password and the IP address of the remote 
gateway to get the Nortel client configured and working and this is the 
sort of client that a non-technical road-warrior users should be given 
for VPN access IMHO. 

The only downside with this solution is the client is Windows-based and 
so for people using Linux or something I don't know if the remote 
gateway would work with a standard IPSec client under Linux. It looks 
like a Diffie-Hellman Group II 3DES/SHA IPSec tunnel from looking at 
some of information dialogs on the client software.

I've met resistance from management on getting a good VPN client for our 
Windows users as they feel that WinXP's PPTP support and built-in 
firewalling is good enough even through the firewalling is disabled by 
default. My fear is that a user can easily disabled the firewalling 
either accidently or intentionally opening a remote client up to being 
hijacked at some point.

Sorry for my long posting which is a bit offtopic...

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net




From ian at znark.com  Sat Apr  3 23:23:02 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sat Apr  3 23:23:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Virus Hunting
In-Reply-To: <1081017377.406f0421e5e6f@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1081017377.406f0421e5e6f@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <406FB780.40303@znark.com>

dan at fiddlers-green.info wrote:
> 
> I'm helping a group track down someone one their mailing list who has gotten the
> W32/Netsky.p at MM virus. That person keeps blasting the entire list with infected
> mails. I was hoping someone might have tips on how to track down the
> individual. Personally I would start with the mail server logs, but beyond that
> I'm a newbie.
> 

Try looking at the Received headers in the email.  Most important is the 
last one, which if you are lucky, will have the IP address of the 
sending machine.  Reverse DNS or whois will tell you the ISP.  You may 
be able to correlate this with other email sent by the subscriber.

I have noticed that IP address can be pretty easy to spot with the virus 
email.  One of our clients got blasted and the IP address was the same 
for all of them.

  - Ian

ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Apr  4 19:44:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Apr  4 19:44:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sylpheed authentication error for user
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404041940510.30265@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  My fiancee uses sylpheed and is working exclusively on her laptop. I set
it up to get mail via pop3 from the server and it worked fine for a while.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Apr  5 01:22:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Apr  5 01:22:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] anyone got a 250meg Iomega ZIP drive?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404050044380.22998@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <86vfkfck73.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.52.0404050044380.22998@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86ad1qltr7.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Russell> That is starting to sound like a drive failure rather than a
Russell> media failure.  A new drive is around $60 or $100.  Before we
Russell> buy one, does someone have one we could try one of the disks
Russell> in?  Alternatively, has anyone seen one at FreeGeek's thrift
Russell> store?

Jeme> Could this be the notorious "Click Death" that plagues IOmega
Jeme> Zip and Jaz drives? [...]

Nope, no clicking really in evidence.  After downloading a KNOPPIX
image and burning it to CD (is there a reason that Mozilla downloads
abort when the screen saver kicks in on w2k?), dd'ing from /dev/sda4
to a file, I got to about sector 246xxx before the read failed.
Seeking past it by 8 sectors, I could read a varying number of blocks
before getting another read error.  Always, skipping 8 sectors let me
read more data.  I was on chunk 7 when I learned that the data still
existed on the hard disk so actual recovery wasn't necessary.  When
switching media, we found that the errors didn't start occurring until
similarly near the middle of the media.

In addition to the one noted above, the KNOPPIX burning sub-project
had another surprise: cygwin's rsync would recreate all of the
pre-existing data, but then stall before actually making any progress
in completing the file.  That is, mozilla's download had aborted at,
say, 200meg.  Rsync would (with the --progress option) furiously
recreate the amount of data already present, then basically stop.
This was violated the principle of least astonishment.  I eventually
installed cygwin's wget and used the -c (continue) option, which
worked.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From ehem at m5p.com  Mon Apr  5 15:26:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Mon Apr  5 15:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Simple graphics programming?
In-Reply-To: <20040405134322.4585.25914.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200404052224.i35MOTxl090114@m5p.com>

> From: Aaron Burt <aaron at speakeasy.org>
> On Thu, Apr 01, 2004 at 11:43:05PM -0800, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > > From: Aaron Burt <aaron at speakeasy.org>
> > > Back when I was a kid, I used to write li'l AppleBASIC programs to draw
> > > interesting geometric figures in hi-res graphics.  
> > > 
> > How much graphics power do you want (just 2D, lines and boxes vs full
> > 3D)? What level of language (C, scripting)? Is portability a concern?
> 
> Excellent questions.
> 
> I'm looking to do basic 2-D figures (lines, points) in X using a
> commonly-used interpreted language.  I've been thinking Perl or Python
> with TK, but that's one of hundreds of options.

So interpreted 2D. Tcl/Tk sounds like the closest match here, however I
do feel Tcl/Tk is a dead end, I imagine it will be a few years before it
is a dead language but the future doesn't look good.

RPN is a bit weird for people who are used to scripting, but Jeme's
mention of PostScript does have merit. Unlike Tcl/Tk, PS isn't going to
die anytime soon. PostScript is also oriented solely at drawing things,
not at producing a GUI with areas for drawing being one widget.

I haven't touched Python or Perl enough to recommend drawing libraries,
though I've seen an awful lot of mentions of "wxPython".

> When I was a kid, I had AppleBasic (and later, GW-Basic).   What would
> you point a smart 12-year-old kid at to get 'im started down the garden
> path these days?

The above are some options. The question is trying to avoid going too
deep.

Might also try one of the game engines. All of the recent FPSes are
deliberately designed with scripting interfaces nowadays. I don't know
how advanced they are, but might be right for handling a 3D engine. Both
of the big FPSes (Unreal Tournament and Quake families) are available for
Linux.

On a more general front Java is still very much alive and usable for
some graphics. The GTK library is also *very* nice.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Apr  5 16:13:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Apr  5 16:13:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Simple graphics programming?
In-Reply-To: <1081205857.18271.14.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <200404052224.i35MOTxl090114@m5p.com>
	 <1081205857.18271.14.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1081206766.1449.50.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2004-04-05 at 15:57, Bill Spears wrote:

> Why do you say this?  I'm just curious because I was using Python with
> Tk and because of the nature of my use it was really slow, so much so,
> that I'm considering switching to wxPython.

Scriptics, the company Ousterhout form to support Tcl/Tk, went out of
business a year or more ago.  The death of Scriptics is by no means an
end to the language, but there just isn't a lot of talk about it and I
don't know of anyone actually learning it or using it actively.

Tk itself has problems, due to the lack of Unicode support; not to
mention the grumbling all around about it being a poor API and slow.

I don't follow the Python lists closely, but I do recall reading a
discussion about moving the default Python GUI library to wxWindows.

> > The GTK library is also *very* nice.
> It has Python bindings doesn't it? Have you used it?

I have; well, I used the Glade interface.  I haven't really done much
GUI development, so I didn't get very far in the 8-16 hours I played
with it.  I do know PyGTK is the preferred toolkit by Red Hat; it's used
by the GUI admin tools and Anaconda.

Wil

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Mon Apr  5 16:19:02 2004
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Mon Apr  5 16:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Simple graphics programming?
In-Reply-To: <200404052224.i35MOTxl090114@m5p.com>
References: <200404052224.i35MOTxl090114@m5p.com>
Message-ID: <200404051618.17345.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Monday 05 April 2004 15:24, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> So interpreted 2D. Tcl/Tk sounds like the closest match here,
> however I do feel Tcl/Tk is a dead end, I imagine it will be a few
> years before it is a dead language but the future doesn't look
> good.

Hmm, not really.  I can't think of any major new project that uses it.

> RPN is a bit weird for people who are used to scripting, but Jeme's
> mention of PostScript does have merit. Unlike Tcl/Tk, PS isn't
> going to die anytime soon. PostScript is also oriented solely at
> drawing things, not at producing a GUI with areas for drawing being
> one widget.

Unfortunately, knowlege of postscript isn't really going to help you 
understand much of the commonly used graphics systems.  The raw 
concepts are the same (lines, points etc.), but between the RPN 
syntax and the rest, I just don't think this would be the best place 
to start.

> I haven't touched Python or Perl enough to recommend drawing
> libraries, though I've seen an awful lot of mentions of "wxPython".

There are other graphics libraries.  wxWidgets (used to be wxWindows) 
is a full windowing library.  Is that what is really needed?  See 
below.

> > When I was a kid, I had AppleBasic (and later, GW-Basic).   What
> > would you point a smart 12-year-old kid at to get 'im started
> > down the garden path these days?
>
> The above are some options. The question is trying to avoid going
> too deep.
>
> Might also try one of the game engines. All of the recent FPSes are
> deliberately designed with scripting interfaces nowadays. I don't
> know how advanced they are, but might be right for handling a 3D
> engine. Both of the big FPSes (Unreal Tournament and Quake
> families) are available for Linux.

This is a good point.  I am not a gamer nor do I know any, but I did 
work in the VR industry for a while a long time ago.  Even then, 
there were libraries that allowed you to script 3D.  This might be a 
bit much though.  It is a lot harder to do interesting and 
nice-looking things in 3D than most people think.  The potential for 
frustration is very high.

> On a more general front Java is still very much alive and usable
> for some graphics. The GTK library is also *very* nice.

I think all of these are pretty difficult to start with.  They require 
a fair number of concepts to be understood before anything can 
happen.  Still, PyQt or PyGTK might be good.  There are some good 
tutorials online.  There are bindings for both Qt and GTK for Ruby 
and Perl too.  I vastly prefer Qt over GTK, but that's due to my 
distaste for faking OO in C.  Sure, you can do it, but I've done it 
in assembly too.  It still doesn't work as nicely as a real OO 
system.

If you just want graphics, the GD library works well.  It isn't 
interactive, but you can make some nice images with it.  There are 
wrappers for Python and Perl.  I've used the Perl module to do 
prototypes for code I later rewrote in C.  The module was on CPAN.  
The Python wrapper is also OO and is here:

http://freshmeat.net/projects/pythongd/

Plus, GD comes with most distros.  The main GD site is here:

http://www.boutell.com/gd/

One of the nice things about GD is that is is actually very simple C 
code.  It isn't spectacularly fast, but if you ever want to dig into 
it and see how it all works, it is quite easy to understand.  Except 
maybe for the PNG and JPEG encoders :-)

While I'm not a Python person, it does seem like a really easy 
language to learn and it supposedly very good for people starting 
out.  Perl is probably _not_ the best first language to learn.  All 
the sigils....  And, I normally program in Perl :-)  I just don't 
know enough about Ruby to say either way.  The interactive command 
line tools for Python and Ruby are really handy when you are learning 
the languages.

You might want to look at what language seems best suited and then 
figure out what libraries are supported.

Best,
Kyle

they exist. Add another candidate, though once again GTK is a GUI layer
on top of X (or MacOS, or...). This reminds me, for simple, pure 2D
drawing, the underlying library, GDK, might be a viable option.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Mon Apr  5 19:26:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Mon Apr  5 19:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The Silent World of KNOPPIX
Message-ID: <20040406022441.23530.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>

I downloaded the Russian version of KNOPPIX last
night, and already had the English version. Anyhow, I
mentioned that the "bootable" disk wouldn't boot on my
computer (in either language version). Making a boot
floppy is easy, however, and solves that problem.

What surprised me was that, since a pleasant female
voice announced the beginning of the startup sequence,
my ac97 sound card is not supported. (I opened
Gnomemeeting, and was informed that no sound card was
detected. When I tried to set it up, it was said not
to be supported.)

Apart from the conventional distributions that have
detected the sound card automatically, there have been
three bootable, or semi-bootable (in the above sense)
ones to play pleasant MIDI music with my sound card:
SuSE, Mandrake, and Blin, the latter smaller than 200
MB. KNOPPIX has many impressive features, but until it
supports sound on my system, it is likely to remain a curiosity.

Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

stuff (mostly games) for the C64, Apple II, Atari, etc.

Gibraltar will back up your smirk, except for the cost issue (about 1000
euros if you want the web interface), however the licensing will be much
nicer, no limit to the number of interfaces or connections.  I guess my
point is, the Open Source technology is there, it is just a matter of
what you have to invest in it (time and/or money).  There are other much
less expensive options, but I haven't found any as full featured as
Gibraltar.  It is also being very actively worked on.

I still have eigenstien floppy routers running as firewalls for both
small and medium sized companies.  The hardware was free and I very
rarely have to do anything to them.  I just invested a little time (ok,
a lot of time) in figuring out how to configure them.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From technoumena at yahoo.com  Tue Apr  6 09:16:01 2004
From: technoumena at yahoo.com (Technoumena)
Date: Tue Apr  6 09:16:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Simple graphics programming?
In-Reply-To: <20040406055902.12239.79250.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040406161510.46069.qmail@web41415.mail.yahoo.com>

John Meissen wrote:
> If you're interested in something to use as
> a teaching language for a kid with no previous
> experience, Tcl/Tk, Perl, Java, etc might
> be a bit much.

An interesting option for introducing kids to
programming is Squeak, a modern, education-oriented
Smalltalk implementation:
http://www.squeakland.org/

After trying Python and even C what worked best with
my kids was actually Mathematica (~$150 academic
license):
http://www.wolfram.com/products/mathematica/index.html

They really groked the ideas of functions, input and
output and variables and it was easy to put to
graphics.  This was when they were just four and six
years old.  Octave with gnuplot (I know you said
something that wasn't heavy like that) pales in
comparison but would do the trick in a pinch.

The questions of whether to use TCL/TK, GTK, Qt,
WxWindows, etc bindings for Python is (IMO) more
important for GUI applications than for programmatic
2D drawing.  The reason TCL/TK is often used is that
it is highly cross-platform.  I'd prefer Pygame
(SDL-based) because its library is focused on graphics
programming rather than UI design but there are other
good Python graphics packages such as:
http://www.pythonware.com/products/pil/
http://matplotlib.sourceforge.net/

There is another option that might be very interesting
to you: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG).
http://www.w3.org/Graphics/SVG/
http://www.svg.org/

I think SVG could very probably be the one I would
choose if I was looking for a language like you
described.

Regards,
technoumena

IIRC, Scriptics was a victim of VC financing. Ousterhout wanted help
with the business side of things, the suits who came in decided that
there wasn't enough money in Tcl/Tk, & dropped support.
>

Tk appears to have some life left to it: there is a Perl module that

I haven't played with Perl/Tk for a couple of years, so I don't know
the current state of its development. (Maybe Randal or another of the
Perl gurus out there might want to offer his opinion on this matter.)

However, more important to the original poster, Tk was intended to
support menus, dialogue boxes, & other GUI stuff. I see from my copy of
_Advanced Perl Programming_ that one can create a Tetris game with
Perl/Tk, but for other graphical applications it probably isn't a
wise choice.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Apr  6 13:21:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Apr  6 13:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux KVM problem
In-Reply-To: <4072FEF3.90308@ohga.org>
References: <4072FEF3.90308@ohga.org>
Message-ID: <4073111A.6040405@dimstar.net>

Dave Scott wrote:

> Twas wondering if any of you have ever experianced this issue with 
> Belkin KVM?
>
> The problem is when you switch back and forth, when you get to a X 
> session, the mouse behaves all erratic and goes crazy.  This can be 
> fixed by switching between X sessions (ctl-alt-f8, then ctl-alt-f7) 
> but this is annoying at best. Does anyone know of a better KVM switch 
> that fixes this problem or is this just a linux driver issue.    I've 
> used both Microsoft mice and Logitech 3 buttom wheel mice. 

I've had this problem with some cheapo 2 port KVMs, Belkin OmniPro 4 
ports, 8 ports and 16 port switches. I've seen the problem with Linux, 
Windows, Solaris, HP-UX, AIX, Tru64, and FreeBSD.

In short, this is not usually a driver issue.

What I have been told by folks at Belkin, and a couple of Electronic 
Engineers, is that it's a clock mismatch issue.

Basically, there is a clock in the mouse, on each motherboard, and in 
the KVM. When they get out of sync, the mouse behaves erratically.

My fix in the past has been to unplug/replug the mouse in the KVM. This 
causes the mouse to "reboot" and the clock syncs up.

I'm sure there is a more technical explaination, and I'm simply 
repeating what I have been told.

If any of it is in error, I'd love to hear a better explaination.

Russ

> var1= cat ~/.filelight

Make the variable assignment like this: var1=`cat ~/.filelight`
(back ticks around the "cat" command, and no spaces around the "=" sign)

> #Execute the file itself using the temp file created
> #echo $var1
> 
> /usr/local/kde/bin/filelight $var1
> 
> #clean the Temp file after we close down
> 
>> Thanks. It's good for "at a glance" filesystem usage.

>> manually, (defaulting to /) However, I'm not having very much luck with
it.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Apr  6 13:59:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Apr  6 13:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Next steps in Bayian SpamAssassin installation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404061316360.15078@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404061316360.15078@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404061351550.18784@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Now I cannot see the trees for the forest. I see tons of document
> files but I cannot separate the wheat from the chaff. What are the
> following steps I need to take in order to train the Bayes filter (I
> suppose I can use some of my saved message files for that) and get
> the rest of the installation completed?

You'll want to separate the spam from the good stuff (aka "ham"), then
run sa-learn:

  sa-learn --showdots --spam /path/to/spam
  sa-learn --showdots --ham  /path/to/ham

You'll need to do that for both you and your fiancee.

Also, you'll want to poke around the Mail::SpamAssassin::Conf man page
(or its perldoc equivalent). Here's a slightly edited version of my
~/.spamassassin/user_prefs file:

  version_tag        ph20040310.0
  whitelist_from     my.friend at teleport.com
  required_hits      4.00
  use_bayes          1
  bayes_min_spam_num 100
  bayes_min_ham_num  100
  rewrite_subject    0
  report_header      1
  report_safe        0
  use_terse_report   1
  defang_mime        0
  ok_languages       en de
  ok_locales         en de
  rbl_timeout        10

  # too many spammers are abusing this header set
  score HABEAS_SWE 0.0

Let us know if you need any further pointers...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: Russ Johnson [mailto:russj at dimstar.net]
Sent: Tuesday, April 06, 2004 1:21 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Linux KVM problem


Dave Scott wrote:

> Twas wondering if any of you have ever experianced this issue with 
> Belkin KVM?
>
> The problem is when you switch back and forth, when you get to a X 
> session, the mouse behaves all erratic and goes crazy.  This can be 
> fixed by switching between X sessions (ctl-alt-f8, then ctl-alt-f7) 
> but this is annoying at best. Does anyone know of a better KVM switch 
> that fixes this problem or is this just a linux driver issue.    I've 
> used both Microsoft mice and Logitech 3 buttom wheel mice. 

I've had this problem with some cheapo 2 port KVMs, Belkin OmniPro 4 
ports, 8 ports and 16 port switches. I've seen the problem with Linux, 
Windows, Solaris, HP-UX, AIX, Tru64, and FreeBSD.

In short, this is not usually a driver issue.

What I have been told by folks at Belkin, and a couple of Electronic 
Engineers, is that it's a clock mismatch issue.

Basically, there is a clock in the mouse, on each motherboard, and in 
the KVM. When they get out of sync, the mouse behaves erratically.

My fix in the past has been to unplug/replug the mouse in the KVM. This 
causes the mouse to "reboot" and the clock syncs up.

I'm sure there is a more technical explaination, and I'm simply 
repeating what I have been told.

If any of it is in error, I'd love to hear a better explaination.

Russ

http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Russell, Allen wrote:
> So it is OK to unplug-replug a PS2 mouse while the machine is running??

Hoo, boy... the hardware geeks and low-level hackers will give you the
real skinny on this, but basically the PS/2 protocol wasn't designed to be
hotpluggable.

That said, many hardware and software implementations do some nifty things
to rescan the bus or whatever and make connections or reconnections on a
running system work.

The answer is "Yeah... but don't be surprised if you can't."

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Apr  6 16:49:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Apr  6 16:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux KVM problem
In-Reply-To: <40733C8B.2070701@ohga.org>
References: <E2215FB1E2914145B6AEE9E7837E3B6B926575@crater.chr.or.kp.org>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404061607220.22998@shaft.bitmine.net> <40733C8B.2070701@ohga.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404061644140.22998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Dave Scott wrote:
> My second question would be, how can we fix this issue, what part of
> GNU/Linux would we have to fix to get this to work.  I must point out
> that this never happens when switching back to a microsoft desktop, so I
> know it's got to be something that we can fix, just probably isn't that
> important at the moment.

If I had to guess, I would say that the switch was to blame rather than
the kernel or any mouse daemon.

I'm guessing here that your KVM switch doesn't properly emulate a
connected mouse and keyboard on the output ports when they are not
connected to the input ports.  The switch to another port is like plugging
in the mouse/keyboard again and that's causing problems.  That is to say,
the KVM vendor is breaking the protocol and expecting the system
hardware/software to take up the slack.

A proper KVM switch shouldn't cause those problems... that is to say, the
KVM switch should do absolutely nothing to the signal to or from the
systems to which it is attached.  The system shouldn't get anything
different than a directly connected mouse and keyboard.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org



From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Apr  6 16:51:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Apr  6 16:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] KNOPPIX and the VT82C686
In-Reply-To: <20040406234800.99807.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040406234800.99807.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404061648500.22998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Robert Kopp wrote:
> The sound actually does work. I tried to use Gnomemeeting, which
> complained that there was no sound card, even though there was sound. If
> I want to use Gnomemeeting, at least the read-only version I have, it
> must need to be configured differently.

Check to make sure that the appropriate sound daemon knows which card to
use and if gnomemeeting has an output plug-in architecture, check to see
that the proper output plugin is selected.

This sort of problem comes up with newly installed XMMS and ESD systems
all the time.  The problem with Knoppix is that it's ALWAYS a newly
installed system and therefore has to do some pretty heavy magic to avoid
these problems.

J.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Apr  6 18:15:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Apr  6 18:15:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Next steps in Bayian SpamAssassin installation
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404061316360.15078@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404061316360.15078@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <22752-70904@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Rich Shepard rshepard-at-appl-ecosys.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> What are the following steps I need to take in order to train the Bayes
> filter (I suppose I can use some of my saved message files for that) and
> get the rest of the installation completed?

I wouldn't bother.  I've had very poor luck with the Bayes filter in
spamassassin.  Even after training it for months I found that the
spamassassin settings resulted in more messages getting through because
the Bayes algorithm thought they weren't spam than if I weren't using
Bayes at all.  The spammers are on to the Bayes approach and inject random
junk into their spams to defeat them.

I still use Bayes, but it will never reduce the spam score any more, it
will only increase it.  This can be controlled in your
.spamassassin/user_prefs file by adding these lines:

score BAYES_00 0.0
score BAYES_01 0.0
score BAYES_10 0.0
score BAYES_20 0.0
score BAYES_30 0.0
score BAYES_40 0.0
score BAYES_44 0.0
score BAYES_50 0.0

Here are some statistics on spam and Bayes from a local public-access UNIX
admin:

http://www.rdrop.com/spam/

  -- Steve

From technoumena at yahoo.com  Tue Apr  6 23:50:02 2004
From: technoumena at yahoo.com (Technoumena)
Date: Tue Apr  6 23:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ps to pdf conversion
In-Reply-To: <20040406230502.25750.44685.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040407050209.50784.qmail@web41409.mail.yahoo.com>

Richard Shepard wrote:
> Vincent Yau wrote:
> > I have a postscript file that I want
> > to convert to pdf. I tried gsview and a
> > few other options and all complain that there
> > is a font that is not supported inside the file.
>  ps2pdf

ps2pdf is a convenient way to invoke Ghostscript (gs).
 The error is that Ghostscript isn't able to find some
font in it's search path.  Do 'gs -h' to find out what
the search path.  Please see the following pages for
more information:
http://www.ghostscript.com/pipermail/bug-gs/2001-February/000213.html

http://www.linuxprinting.org/pipermail/epson-list/2002q4/002111.html
leading to when he simply reinstalls the related
software and, lo and behold, the font paths match with
the fonts. :)

The solution may involve installing fonts and/or
recompiling Ghostscript.

Regards,
technoumena

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Apr  7 00:54:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Apr  7 00:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Next steps in Bayian SpamAssassin installation
In-Reply-To: <22752-70904@sneakemail.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404061316360.15078@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <22752-70904@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404070031300.22998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Steve Bonds wrote:
> I wouldn't bother.

I think you'd be just about unique in recommending against it.

> I've had very poor luck with the Bayes filter in spamassassin.  Even
> after training it for months I found that the spamassassin settings
> resulted in more messages getting through because the Bayes algorithm
> thought they weren't spam than if I weren't using Bayes at all.

I think that I could filter on Bayes scores alone and get great spam
protection.  A quick run through my mailboxes shows that my caught spam
ALL ranks Bayes scores greater than 80 and my regular mail ALL ranks below
50 (except for a couple of specifically whitelisted addresses which
trigger Bayes for their commercial content).  Interestingly, my false
negatives folder lists spam with Bayes ratings from 50-90 -- usually with
some negative scores that artificially lower the score.

I haven't had a false positive spam score since the Bayesian filters
kicked in and I added a couple of the above-mentioned addresses to my
whitelist.

> The spammers are on to the Bayes approach and inject random junk into
> their spams to defeat them.

The randomness of the junk actually helps to make it have just about no
effect on Bayesian filtering.

> I still use Bayes, but it will never reduce the spam score any more, it
> will only increase it.

Your datasets seem exceedingly strange.  Have you been feeding it lots of
ham?  Do you have autolearn enabled?

> This can be controlled in your .spamassassin/user_prefs file by adding
> these lines:
[snip]
> score BAYES_50 0.0

This is actually an increase in score.  Spamassassin gives BAYES_50 a
score of .001.

I think that if you're getting lots of false negatives due to low Bayes
scores, you're not feeding your filters properly.

I tend to feed spamassassin all of the false negatives every fifty
messages or so, so I don't have a large number of false negatives on hand
(I delete them after feeding the sa-learn), but I can show you the stats
from what I have right now:

jbrelin at shaft:~$ grep BAYES_ ./mail/IN.spam.is|cut -d_ -f2 |cut -d,
-f1|uniq -c|sort -n
      1 CREDIT
      1 30
      1 40
      1 80
      3 44
      5 56
      6 90
      9 99
     14 50

OK... so you can discard that first line... I'll have to see what the
input looked like.  But you can see that only 4 of the 41 messages in my
current pack of false negatives (which goes back a few weeks at least)
were attributed negative scores for their Bayesian ranking.

The command above run against my regular inbox (the default drop-box for
mail that isn't filtered based on content or sender and already purged of
actual spam either by spamassassin or by hand) shows no scores over 50 and
most everything hovering in the 00-20 range.

J.

On Wed, 7 Apr 2004, Jeme A Brelin jeme-at-brelin.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

>
> On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Steve Bonds wrote:
> > I wouldn't bother.
>
> I think you'd be just about unique in recommending against it.

I wouldn't have even tried disabling it if I hadn't heard about the
experience mentioned at:

http://www.rdrop.com/spam/

I was as surprised as anyone that it could be counter-effective.

> A quick run through my mailboxes shows that my caught spam ALL ranks
> Bayes scores greater than 80 and my regular mail ALL ranks below 50
> (except for a couple of specifically whitelisted addresses which trigger
> Bayes for their commercial content).  Interestingly, my false negatives
> folder lists spam with Bayes ratings from 50-90 -- usually with some
> negative scores that artificially lower the score.

Most (not all) of my caught spam also has Bayes probabilities over 50.
My false negatives folder has a collection Bayes scores from 00 to 99,
with most of them below 50.

I did find it interesting that none of my auto-caught spam has a Bayes
score of 00, even after I changed the weight on that to 0.0.  Perhaps I
wasn't giving the Bayes filter enough credit.  ;-)

Several of the spams that weren't caught automatically had a Bayes score
of 00.

> Your datasets seem exceedingly strange.  Have you been feeding it lots
> of ham?  Do you have autolearn enabled?

Yes, and yes.  For quite some time now.

> > This can be controlled in your .spamassassin/user_prefs file by adding
> > these lines:
> [snip]
> > score BAYES_50 0.0
>
> This is actually an increase in score.  Spamassassin gives BAYES_50 a
> score of .001.

Yeah, maybe I got a bit carried away when I was trimming this out.  ;-)

> I think that if you're getting lots of false negatives due to low Bayes
> scores, you're not feeding your filters properly.

I don't get lots of false negatives, just enough to be irksome.  The main
problem was that the incorrect Bayes scores would override Spamassassin
correctly categorizing something as spam through other means.

The user_prefs settings fixed this problem, but I'm still left wondering
if it's worth the extra CPU time and disk space to store the Bayes info.

  -- Steve

Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> writes:

> On Tue, 6 Apr 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
>
>>   Now I cannot see the trees for the forest. I see tons of document
>> files but I cannot separate the wheat from the chaff. What are the
>> following steps I need to take in order to train the Bayes filter (I
>> suppose I can use some of my saved message files for that) and get
>> the rest of the installation completed?
>
> You'll want to separate the spam from the good stuff (aka "ham"), then
> run sa-learn:
>
>   sa-learn --showdots --spam /path/to/spam
>   sa-learn --showdots --ham  /path/to/ham
>
> You'll need to do that for both you and your fiancee.

Those files that you're giving in /path/to/spam and /path/to/ham are 

> Also, you'll want to poke around the Mail::SpamAssassin::Conf man page
> (or its perldoc equivalent). Here's a slightly edited version of my
> ~/.spamassassin/user_prefs file:
>
>   version_tag        ph20040310.0
>   whitelist_from     my.friend at teleport.com
>   required_hits      4.00
>   use_bayes          1
>   bayes_min_spam_num 100
>   bayes_min_ham_num  100
>   rewrite_subject    0
>   report_header      1
>   report_safe        0
>   use_terse_report   1
>   defang_mime        0
>   ok_languages       en de
>   ok_locales         en de
>   rbl_timeout        10
>
>   # too many spammers are abusing this header set
>   score HABEAS_SWE 0.0
>
> Let us know if you need any further pointers...
>
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>   I've not saved any spam so I'll need to start collecting some in a new
> ~/mail/spam file.

Just go through your mail archive and sort through that.  If you're
not keeping a running archive yet, procmail makes it easy.  Just add
this before your other procmail rules.

######################################################################
# Backup

MONTH=`date +%y-%m`

:0 c
~/mail-backup/$MONTH

>> Also, you'll want to poke around the Mail::SpamAssassin::Conf man page
>
>   All in due time. :-)

> http://www.rdrop.com/spam/
>
> I was as surprised as anyone that it could be counter-effective.

My method isn't counter-effective, it just works.
http://dman13.dyndns.org/~dman/config_docs/exim-spamassassin/
http://ursine.ca/~baloo/clamd-exiscan.txt

> I don't get lots of false negatives, just enough to be irksome.  The main
> problem was that the incorrect Bayes scores would override Spamassassin
> correctly categorizing something as spam through other means.

I usually get false negatives from mailing lists, oddly enough.

capture card that now sells for $40 (after rebate) at

weak, so the user is advised to connect it to the
installed sound card with an included external cable.

It works as specified under Linux, however (xawtv).
Perhaps Hauppage should include a KNOPPIX disk with
the product for the benefit of purchasers with

I've had pretty good results with Bayesian filtering; though I do use a
two level filter (both spamassassin and bogofilter).

Slightly off topic, I got a piece of spam today (a typical quack
medicine / illegal prescription drugs con game) that may have gone to
next level beyond just adding random dictionary words.

This piece of junk had over 60 references to different "web sites",
where the web site names looked like random combinations of dictionary
words and the suffixes ".com", ".org" and ".net".  Interspersed among
those were references to "the" real web sites of the con artist.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404080943410.3700-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

I have a tab-delimited text file that I'm inserting into a database.  The
first three fields need to be unique.  Sometimes the text file has
duplication of the first three fields, but the rest is different, so I
can't simply use "sort -u" to remove the dups.  The first occurance of the
dupe is always the one that I want removed.

Any suggestions on a way to find the dups and remove the first occurance?
Thanks,
~M








From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Apr  8 10:02:02 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu Apr  8 10:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] removing dups
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404080943410.3700-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404080943410.3700-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <20040408170049.GD18069@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Apr 08, 2004 at 09:50:13AM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I have a tab-delimited text file that I'm inserting into a database.  The
> first three fields need to be unique.  Sometimes the text file has
> duplication of the first three fields, but the rest is different, so I
> can't simply use "sort -u" to remove the dups.  The first occurance of the
> dupe is always the one that I want removed.
> 
> Any suggestions on a way to find the dups and remove the first occurance?

Build a perl script that uses a three-level hash where the key is a string
that is all other fields.  Each line will be add or modify an entry in the hash.

At the end, you'll have a hash with all unique keys where the values are
the last-most seen.

If the order of the file is important, use something like a supplementary
array to keep the original order or use a tied array like Tie::IxHash

Colin

> I have a tab-delimited text file that I'm inserting into a database.  The

> duplication of the first three fields, but the rest is different, so I

Do a select based on those three fields.  If you get a "hit", replace the 
record with the current one.  If you don't, insert the line as a new 
record.

From krisa at subtend.net  Thu Apr  8 10:59:02 2004
From: krisa at subtend.net (Kris)
Date: Thu Apr  8 10:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] postfix ezmlm forwarding
Message-ID: <20040408175840.GC9054@subtend.net>

I have a temporary situation where list mail is delivered to a postfix
server and forwarded to a qmail+ezmlm server for processing.

List traffic works fine.  I added "listname: listname at qmail.host.com" to
/etc/aliases.

My problem is sub and unsub confirmations.  The way confirmation works
with ezmlm is you just reply to a special specific email address which
starts with the list name and has the auth string in the right part of the
user address.  For example:

listname-sc.1081445909.hfdeppphaondhppklagi-krisamundson=yahoo.com at domain.com

As you can see it puts an auth code in, and the email address of the
subscriber at the end.

I'm trying to figure out how to configure postfix:

for listname-*, send to listname-*@qmail.host.com


If I can't do this with postfix I will either need to turn off
confirmation of sub/unsub's, or ramp up conversion of moving the list to
the postfix server with mailman.

-- 
I'm just a packet pusher.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Thu Apr  8 11:51:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Thu Apr  8 11:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] removing dups
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404081016570.3761-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404081016570.3761-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <1081450184.6629.49.camel@localhost.localdomain>

A really bad way of doing it:

#Assuming ',' is field seperator
FS=, cat filetoamkerandallmad.csv | awk 'sub("\n"); {print "$0|$i $1$2$3\n"; $i++}' | sort -k 1 | uniq -F 1 | sort -t '|' -k 1| awk '{sub("|.*$");  print $0}'


The idea is create field with the key ($1$2$3) at the end (by a space). 
Then sort on the key field,
Then ditch the dups
Then sort on the incrementor.
Then ditch the incrementor and key field.


This assumes the field separator is ',' and is not escaped.  that there
are no spaces pipes in the fields, That the sub command effects $0
(otherwise you need to use a variable there).

I did not test any of this.  I am avoiding reading a long document.....

--

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Apr  8 13:11:02 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu Apr  8 13:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] removing dups
In-Reply-To: <1081450184.6629.49.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404081016570.3761-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org> <1081450184.6629.49.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20040408201038.GG18069@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Apr 08, 2004 at 01:49:44PM -0500, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> A really bad way of doing it:
> 
> #Assuming ',' is field seperator
> FS=, cat filetoamkerandallmad.csv | awk 'sub("\n"); {print "$0|$i $1$2$3\n"; $i++}' | sort -k 1 | uniq -F 1 | sort -t '|' -k 1| awk '{sub("|.*$");  print $0}'
> 
> 
> This assumes the field separator is ',' and is not escaped.  that there
> are no spaces pipes in the fields, That the sub command effects $0
> (otherwise you need to use a variable there).

It also assumes that concatenating $1$2$3 produces a unique key,
which might be true depending on the data.  It would be better to
break each line into 4 fields, $1, $2, $3, $4(the rest of the line)
and create a key separated by some unlikely character.

Colin

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Fri Apr  9 03:26:02 2004
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Fri Apr  9 03:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] removing dups
References: <mailman.1081443425.372.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86oeq1bgb6.fsf@blue.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Matt" == Matt Alexander <m at phxlinux.org> writes:

Matt> I have a tab-delimited text file that I'm inserting into a
Matt> database.  The first three fields need to be unique.  Sometimes
Matt> the text file has duplication of the first three fields, but the
Matt> rest is different, so I can't simply use "sort -u" to remove the
Matt> dups.  The first occurance of the dupe is always the one that I
Matt> want removed.

So, the key is /^([^\t]+\t){3}/, and you want the later appearances
to override the earlier ones?

    #!/usr/bin/perl

    my %datum;
    ## gather data
    while (<>) {
      next unless my ($key) = /^((?:[^\t]+\t){3})/;
      $datum{$key} = [$_, $.]; # original line, and line number
      ## note that later ones override earlier ones
    }
    ## display data in original order, since the hash is scrambled
    for my $key (sort { $a->[1] <=> $b->[1] } keys %datum) {
      print $datum{$key}[0]; # original line is [0]
    }

Untested except on the Perl installed in my head. :)

I'm guessing from your comment about "library" of code that you are talking
about being the coder, as opposed to buyer. My understanding is that, if the
buyer is retaining the copyright, you cannot keep, or reuse the code later.
If you did, you'd be infringing on the buyer's copyright.

This is just my understanding, but I think it's a safe way to assume things
are.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Apr  9 10:52:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Apr  9 10:52:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] alt.religion.email
Message-ID: <20040409175034.GA29428@gate.kl-ic.com>

There is another religious argument about top posting versus bottom
posting.  It is of course going on under the title of:

"Re: [PLUG] Next steps in Bayian SpamAssassin installation"

Please move the top/bottom posting discussion elsewhere, like
plug-talk, or alt.religion.email, AND FIX THE $^%$*& SUBJECT LINE!
If you are going to be sophmoric enough to blather on about RFC1855,
please read the goddam thing, especially the other 98% that talks
about summarizing, quoting appropriately, 72 characters, changing
subject lines to match the content, long binary attachments,
avoiding flamage, etc. 

As in all writing, the golden rule is "consider the needs of your
audience".  Write your diary any way you want, write your code for
functionality and adherence to coding standards, and write for other
people so they can understand what you are writing and quickly 
determine whether they need to read more of it.  "> >> >>> >"
conveys nothing other than laziness, whether it sits above or below
your own deathless prose.  Don't pretend there is some magic algorithm
that will make a huge pile of nested quotes readable; intelligent
communication involves cognition and creativity, not slavish
adherence to favored subsets of rules.

Newbies:  the flamers do have a point,  even if they communicate
it in a petulant and arrogant way.  If you don't make your posting
readable and follow some recognizable pattern you are wasting your
reader's time and you look sloppy.  On the other hand, the usual
>name2 \  >>name1 \  >>content1 \  >content2  format that results
from lazy use of the "r" key, which some glorify with the name of
"bottom posting", is no less sloppy.  The point is to massage the
old text to make it readable in a new context and follow a time
sequence, while preserving attribution and avoiding misquoting. 
Archived mailing lists that get digested face additional constraints; 
html,  PGP keys, and binary attachments are so much space-filling
trash, for example, and don't belong on ASCII mailing lists.  But
if you think the majority of your readers would prefer deviations
from some rigid standard in a particular instance, go ahead and
deviate from the norm.  This is about readability, not rules.

Keep in mind that this mailing list is archived, so sophmoric flamage
will follow you for the rest of your life.  Imagine that job interview
30 years from now, where your interviewer has run a quick net check
on you.  She may be disturbed that you were so idiotic as to flame
then-young and now-famous John Q. Noobe on some tiny bit of pedantic
trivia.  Your future will depend somewhat on the prudence and sympathy
you show in your writing today.

And if your own future doesn't interest you, at least consider the
future of Linux.  Our best selling point is the support we offer
newbies.  Our worst selling point is our bombastic flamage of people
that do not adhere to our own rigid, neurotic, and arbitrary standards.  
To the extent that we indulge in the latter unfriendly behavior, we
limit the spread of free software.  No healthy person wants to
emulate assholes.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Apr  9 11:22:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr  9 11:22:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Training a bayesian filter
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404091057360.16338@pecos.madboa.com>

Since, as Keith properly pointed out, the old thread about bayesian
filters got hijacked, I thought I'd start a new one.

On average, I get about 100 spam messages a day. It's not so much that
I couldn't handle it manually, but I like having SpamAssassin
performing sentinal duty for me.

I've got four folders for unwanted messages:

1. junk: where procmail diverts messages that under temporary
   blacklisting. Typically, these are mailing-list threads gone amok,
   but sometimes I blacklist people, too.

2. spam: where procmail diverts messages with a "X-Spam-Flag: YES"
   header.

3. spam.uncaught: where I manually put messages that slipped through
   SpamAssassin's filters. More on this folder below.

4. spam.kept: where I keep about 250 known-spam messages. This is
   useful if I have to rebuild a bayes database.

A couple times a week, I pop into the spam folder and search for all
messages with 'BAYES_99 BODY' in them. These are messages SpamAssassin
is 99 to 100% sure are spam. Since my bayesian database has done as
good a job as possible identifying these messages, there's no reason
to feed them to sa-learn; so I just delete them.

Any that are left (typically these days, no more than 3 to 5% of the
total number of filtered messages), I move to the spam.uncaught
folder. Every so often, I feed the uncaught spam to sa-learn and then
delete all the messages in spam.uncaught.

The reward comes when I see messages with spam reports like this:

  X-Spam-Report:
    *  5.4 BAYES_99 BODY: Bayesian spam probability is 99 to 100%
    *      [score: 0.9997]

This message did nothing to violate SpamAssassin's stock filters -- no
funky HTML, no forged MUA headers, no wierd return address -- but
since I'd seen and fed to sa-learn similar messages, it was correctly
identified and filtered out of my inbox.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

  I seem to encounter more incidents when I send a client (or prospective

  Are there steps I can take to ensure the delivery of attachments on the

From romanmir at comcast.net  Fri Apr  9 12:17:02 2004
From: romanmir at comcast.net (Chris Penwell)
Date: Fri Apr  9 12:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Attachments not received
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404091153210.495@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <001201c41e67$12b7b2b0$4b00a8c0@alphaqq4o0tdl8>

	Generally speaking, (Unless I just had one of the Good Brownies..)
if an attachment is not received, it's because:

	A: the receiving mail server strips it out, (unusual with .pdf and
.zip; though given the nature of the last round of Windows viruses, more and
more are stripping out .zip attachments)
-or-
	B: the recipient is using either Outlook or Outlook Express, in
which case the aforementioned email client is making the call to hide the
attachment.

If it's A, then you may need to rename the file in order for it to go
through.
If it's B, then either they need to turn off that mail hiding capacity (and
most likely exposing themselves to malware,) or (if they are using
Exchange,) see if that attachment type can be ignored.

I've run into situations here at work where AOL strips out .pdf and leaves
.exe alone..

Bass Ackwards If you ask me but whatever.. Just makes it more inconvenient
for me.

Anyhoo, anybody else got any ideas?
_______________________________________________
Chris Penwell

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Apr  9 13:38:02 2004
From: josh at emediatedesigns.com (Josh Orchard)
Date: Fri Apr  9 13:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Attachments not received
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404091257410.752@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <001201c41e67$12b7b2b0$4b00a8c0@alphaqq4o0tdl8>
    <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404091257410.752@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1401.216.99.218.67.1081543326.squirrel@sautez.com>

>   Do I need to rename the files so something inocuous and tell the
> recipients what to do with them? In linux pdf views and uncompressors
> don't
> care about file names. Does this also hold true in the world of
> Redmond?

Yes it does hold true in MS world as well.  The Exchange server will
open all files regardless of what you name them.  In fact, the last
virus was putting passwords on the zip files so virus scanners
couldn't open them.  Then in the body of the email tell you the
password to open the attachment.  Cleaver.  Well many are now not
allowing any unknown files through the email server.  They have one of
two solutions to this.

1. create a special extension that they will allow through the server.
This has been created with my company and another to allow
attachments.

2. Use FTP or another form of retrieval when sending large files or
documents.  This is the preferred way as we have set up a share web
repository and the users just click a weblink that gives them the
file.

The suggested ftp link will work on an anonymous ftp site as a good
solutions as well. I would suggest you user something like:

ftp://ftp.yourhost.com/private/companyone/file.zip

Then you can hide the private directory and not list the files yet
allow others that have the path to download the files.

Josh
