From zw at superlucidity.net  Fri Apr  9 14:56:01 2004
From: zw at superlucidity.net (Zach Welch)
Date: Fri Apr  9 14:56:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] faux-legal question
In-Reply-To: <200404091657.i39GvKD01774@box002.ultravolt.net>
References: <200404091657.i39GvKD01774@box002.ultravolt.net>
Message-ID: <40771BD8.9070101@superlucidity.net>

Aaron Ten Clay wrote:
> I'm guessing from your comment about "library" of code that you are 
> talking about being the coder, as opposed to buyer. My understanding 
> is that, if the buyer is retaining the copyright, you cannot keep, or
> reuse the code later. If you did, you'd be infringing on the buyer's
> copyright.

Yup, and it's worse.  Unless you have explicitly obtained privileges for
the past works which comprise your library, you may not even have the
rights to use those works - if they were created in a similar
contractual situation.  My past experience dredges up the phrase "work
for hire" for such contexts, meaning all rights are implicitly (if not
explicitly) owned by the person that paid for the work.  It is not
sufficient to have a verbal agreement with your old employer to take
code with you when completing a contract; you need to have these things
in writing in order for it to function as your "stay out of jail" card.

When obtaining new contracts, it becomes very important to add language
which expressly grants you rights to portions of the system that you
expect or want to take with you.  In many cases, finding a mix of
exclusive rights and shared rights will allow you to take the reusable
parts (if not all) of the systems' code with you, and most employers or
clients can probably be convinced of the mutual value for those rights.
To whatever extent possible, make everything as explicit as possible
without detracting from the abstract function the language should serve,
though that tends to also be generally useful contract writing advice.

Further, I have recently decided to take the trouble of forcing future
NDAs and contracts to be written "implicitly open," where all work
product rights will automatically be licensed under FOSS terms unless
specifically labeled proprietary.  This is something more professionals
should consider, but some clients will initially balk.  I myself love to
convince businesses that these are the right choices to make now and
into the future; it can be hard - and even pragmatically impossible in
some rare cases - but it usually produces richly rewarding results.

Finally, I am not a lawyer but pay a good one to handle these issues,
and those looking for these kinds of solutions should consult one too.
Many of us may be gifted enough to write our own contracts, but I
sincerely doubt any of us have passed the bar exam in Oregon and thus
could know for sure if our words would hold a drop of legal water.

Cheers,

Zach Welch
Superlucidity Services

Again, I'll repeat there is a setting in exchange to Scan ALL
attachments regardless of extension.  Our exchange server does just
that at my work.  We have tried to go around it and it will scan the
attachments regardless of what we named them and it remove files that
we need sent to co-workers.  It even tries to unzip all files
regardless of extension.  The file may still never make it to the
user.

Unless you have the person running the exchange server agree not to
scan your particular file type they will most likely now scan
everything.  Too many viruses not to do just that.

I'd suggest that you work out the ftp anonymous mode or ask your
client where you could upload the files.  Many have an anonymous ftp
server available.

Josh

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sat Apr 10 11:36:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Sat Apr 10 11:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Dealing with smtp abuse from a whole entire subnet of DSL and Cable
 customers...
Message-ID: <1081621639.2394.37.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I have an inordinate number of improperly set up mail sources from
evidently DSL and Cable customers.  These people are probably virused.
It seems that registered sites only send .01% of the garbage I get.

I've been blocking a lot of ip addresses of the form 69.10.92.xxx
where xxx is seemingly almost every number between 1 and 254. 
These are not properly registered sites.  I'm almost tempted to 
write a program that looks up every possible address with that 
69.10.92 subnet blocking combinations that either don't resolve
or that haven't been in the maillog within the past 72 hours as
errors.  One concern is that even if these addresses are 
infected machines today, I might not want to block them
indefinitely.

Maybe it's best to use jabber to establish initial contact and
then explicitly list valid source email addresses.  I don't know
that NT/200x/XP users would like that though or even be able to 
install a chat program.

I've noticed that computers at Providence hospital aren't set
up correctly.  They are not masquerading correctly as I have 
gotten mail from an address that must be internal to
their network.  If I start blocking every address that
doesn't forward resolve, I'm looking at potentially blocking
a lot of legit sites.  I don't want my server logs flooding
with this user doesn't exist from every ip in a single subnet,
nor do I want to lose all my bandwidth to 200+ hosts 
trying to send me the same garbage.  If nothing else, 
the logging is cutting my performance.  What I guess I
should do is come up with a dynamic subnet blocking system.

My Internet speed has gone up significantly blocking over 100 
ip addresses in the 69.10.92.xxx network.  It looks like I was 
getting hit with denial of service.  All I can think is that 
it costs so much for my server to even ignore connection 
attempts where I'm getting a whole subnet, looks like a 
Class C one, hitting me. 

I'm using a dns ignorant database and trying to apply address 
tests, what I'm finding is that probably none of this addresses 
denial of service.  The best is not having an ip 
conversation with certain abusive hosts.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Apr 10 17:45:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat Apr 10 17:45:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MX seconding and fetchmail
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404101738210.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

I've got a hare-brained idea that is so crazy, it just might work!
</irony>

I may be moving my home network in a little while.  No assurance that I
can get any kind of overlap on the network connectivity, so I'm
considering a kind of stop-gap measure that could possibly be a permanent
fail-over solution for my mail.

There are some assumptions here about the way things work that I've never
used before, so please pipe up if I write something nutso.

I figure I'll set my domains' secondary MX to some machine off-net (that
is to say, not at the end of my DSL connection).  That machine will be
configured to deliver ALL mail for my domains to a single mailbox
accessible by some remote retrieval protocol.  Then, whenever my primary
MX is unavailable, the mail will be delivered to the secondary.
Periodically, my primary MX will launch a fetchmail process to grab all
the mail from the secondary MX and deliver it locally according to the
local MTA's configuration.

Does that all sound quite sane and reasonable?  The initial delivery to
the secondary MX shouldn't mess with any of the envelope information of
the messages and prevent them from being delivered to disparate mailboxes
on the primary, will it?

This seems so straightforward, I would think it's probably common practice
in some circles (unless there's a configuration within the MTA to do the
failover and re-delivery).

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Apr 10 18:11:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat Apr 10 18:11:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MX seconding and fetchmail
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404101738210.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404101738210.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404101806330.4452@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 10 Apr 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I've got a hare-brained idea that is so crazy, it just might work!

  Hare today, coon tomorrow.

> I figure I'll set my domains' secondary MX to some machine off-net (that
> is to say, not at the end of my DSL connection).  That machine will be
> configured to deliver ALL mail for my domains to a single mailbox
> accessible by some remote retrieval protocol.  Then, whenever my primary
> MX is unavailable, the mail will be delivered to the secondary.
> Periodically, my primary MX will launch a fetchmail process to grab all
> the mail from the secondary MX and deliver it locally according to the
> local MTA's configuration.

  If you replace "secondary MX" with "primary MX" that's exactly what we did
here for several years before getting the DSL connection. I had fetchmail
running in daemon mode and it would run over to our domain mailbox at the
ISP's mail server, carry back all waiting message and deliver them via
procmail to the appropriate inbox. Used diald to instantiate outgoing
connections as desired.

> Does that all sound quite sane and reasonable?  The initial delivery to
> the secondary MX shouldn't mess with any of the envelope information of
> the messages and prevent them from being delivered to disparate mailboxes
> on the primary, will it?

  Nope.

Rich

From baloo at ursine.ca  Sat Apr 10 19:19:02 2004
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)
Date: Sat Apr 10 19:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Training a bayesian filter
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404091057360.16338@pecos.madboa.com> (Paul
 Heinlein's message of "Fri, 9 Apr 2004 11:21:02 -0700 (PDT)")
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404091057360.16338@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <87hdvrs1es.fsf@ursine.ca>

Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> writes:

> On average, I get about 100 spam messages a day. It's not so much that
> I couldn't handle it manually, but I like having SpamAssassin
> performing sentinal duty for me.

I usually get at least three times that, and judicious use of
SpamAssassin, ClamAV, procmail and gnus scoring, it's more than
manageable.

> I've got four folders for unwanted messages:
[...]
> 4. spam.kept: where I keep about 250 known-spam messages. This is
>    useful if I have to rebuild a bayes database.

I'm intrigued why you bother keeping this one around when one could
easily get their fill and then some by browsing through
nntp://news.spamcop.net/spamcop.spam,
news:news.admin.net-abuse.sightings or http://www.spamarchive.org/ .

> Any that are left (typically these days, no more than 3 to 5% of the
> total number of filtered messages), I move to the spam.uncaught
> folder. Every so often, I feed the uncaught spam to sa-learn and then
> delete all the messages in spam.uncaught.

If you pipe the messages through spamassassin -r instead of dumping a
folder at sa-learn, spamassassin will also submit hashes to
razor/razor2 and pyzor if you have razor, razor2 and/or pyzor
installed.  Installing those gives spamassassin more things to check
against, making it more accurate.

-- 
Paul Johnson
<baloo at ursine.ca>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>   I seem to encounter more incidents when I send a client (or
> prospective client) information attached to an e-mail and receive a
> return mail that the attachments were not received.

Ah, the joys of mailing people who are on brokenly-configured servers...

>   Based on a previous thread here I suspect Microsoft is protecting
> the poor recipient by determining that the attachment is malware and
> not letting it be seen. Ergo, my question: what can I do to prevent
> or reduce the number of such incidents?

Convince the admins of such broken sites to find a better solution.
And I don't just criticize, I create.
http://ursine.ca/~baloo/clamd-exiscan.txt

>   Most of the files I send are .pdf. However, when there is a
> collection to send I package them using plain, ol' .zip so the
> winduhs users can extract them.

Do you get much compression out of that?  I was under the impression
that PDF is a compressed format to start with.

> I suspect that it's the zipped file that sometimes causes the
> problem.  Of course, I may be completely wrong in all this.

Probably the case.  Just send a tarball instead, WinZip easily handles
tarballs and they're not anywhere near as likely to trip things up
except with sites whose admins are suffering from severe recto-cranial
inversion.

>   Are there steps I can take to ensure the delivery of attachments
> on the first try?

Three off the top of my head:

1) Try sending the PDF bare.
2) Convince the site's admins to fix their broken mail server.
3) Give the recipient a login on your server.
4) Find some other method to send the file.

On Sat, 10 Apr 2004, Chaz Sliger wrote:
> [Chaz Sliger] Read the article.  It's interesting that a program could
> be spawned by playing a sound file.  Any idea how that happens?  Looks
> like the Apple files/player were designed to allow this.

Yeah, what I didn't get was that they explained that this was NOT an
iTunes exploit.  So yeah, it must be designed to run programs from inside
MP3s.  Weird as hell.

There was an mpg123 exploit a while back that allowed arbitrary code
inside an MP3 to be executed, but it's been patched (and may have only
been theoretical, anyway).

So it really can't be coming to "Linux" anytime soon.  There might be some
application that is designed to run downloaded code that can be used on a
Linux system, but you'd have to be crazy to use it.

On Sat, 10 Apr 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:
> Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:
> >   Most of the files I send are .pdf. However, when there is a
> > collection to send I package them using plain, ol' .zip so the winduhs
> > users can extract them.
>
> Do you get much compression out of that?  I was under the impression
> that PDF is a compressed format to start with.

He's using zip to create archives of multiple files in one file (like tar
does) instead of using zip to make a compressed file from another file
(like gzip does).

Zip does both and there is no commonly used archive format for Windows
that does not also attempt to compress.

Also, PDFs do not necessarily contain compressed data.

> >   Are there steps I can take to ensure the delivery of attachments on
> > the first try?
>
> 4) Find some other method to send the file.

Really, this is what I think he should be doing.  Email just isn't for
file transfer.  It CAN be used to do so, but you can also use a
screwdriver to bash in a nail and you can drive a car with your feet if
you want to... that don't make it a good idea.

Sending a URL is more respectful of the recipient because it allows them
to consume the additional bandwidth of the file transfer at will instead
of on command.

Message-ID: <871xmvrztg.fsf@ursine.ca>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>   A proof-of-concept Trojan horse for OSX:
>
>     <http://www.cnn.com/2004/TECH/internet/04/09/apple.trojan/index.html>
>
>   Guess that linux is next.

It's already happened.  And we've moved on.  There were three worms,
all somewhat successful, all exclusive to Red Hat and derived
distros.  Number still in the wild today, 5 years later?  Zero.  We
already know it can be done, Unix just proves to be a seriously
hostile environment for viruses since most people still don't log in
as root and run more than they have to (you really don't have a reason
to log in as root, just su -m to run the commands you need as root
From your normal user.  Or better yet, get something like sudo and use
that.).

This only proves it's possible on OSX, not that there is actually
something in the wild getting loose.

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>   Is anyone here using VoIP on a DSL connection? I'm wondering if it's
> something I should consider for both the business and residential phone
> lines. 

The price of DSL for the kind of bandwidth you'll need for more than a
single line will far outweigh the price benefit of consumer-grade
VoIP.

> How's it work with faxes?

TiVo barely works and is only tolerable once you get past the initial
setup.  It took us three days without TV playing UT with roommates in
the living room waiting for the TiVo to make the Program Call so we
could finish changing the lineup from Comcast Downtown Portland
Economy Basic to Comcast Wood Village Digital Basic and watch TV again
because it couldn't hold the call long enough.  Now that the TiVo's up
and running, it's fine since it just keeps trying once every few hours
if it can't dial out.  I'm not sure faxing would be a possibility if
you didn't automate it, and if you automate it, I wouldn't gayrauntee a
delivery time.

> From: Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>
> 
> On Sat, 10 Apr 2004, Chaz Sliger wrote:
> > [Chaz Sliger] Read the article.  It's interesting that a program could
> > be spawned by playing a sound file.  Any idea how that happens?  Looks
> > like the Apple files/player were designed to allow this.
> 
> Yeah, what I didn't get was that they explained that this was NOT an
> iTunes exploit.  So yeah, it must be designed to run programs from inside
> MP3s.  Weird as hell.

My reading is that it truely falls into the "trojan horse" category. My
impression is that on MacOS the icons for executables are embeded in the
file itself, and what this is doing is placing an icon normally
associated with a sound file on a trojan executable file. If my reading
is correct, there are two weaknesses, first is an exploit of where the
MacOS desktop in where it looks for icons, and the second is that the
downloading program is saving the downloaded file with the execute bit
set (otherwise it would refuse to execute it).

> There was an mpg123 exploit a while back that allowed arbitrary code
> inside an MP3 to be executed, but it's been patched (and may have only
> been theoretical, anyway).

There have been a couple mpg123 holes found, though I doubt many people
have been hit by it (could only hit the user).

> So it really can't be coming to "Linux" anytime soon.  There might be some
> application that is designed to run downloaded code that can be used on a
> Linux system, but you'd have to be crazy to use it.

Games tend to do it, but they know their source. The real problem is that
the file was apparently being saved with the execute bits set (or some
part of the desktop was dishonoring the execute bit).

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sat Apr 10 22:22:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Sat Apr 10 22:22:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Attachments not received
Message-ID: <1081660362.11501.6.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

> 1) Try sending the PDF bare.
> 2) Convince the site's admins to fix their broken mail server.
> 3) Give the recipient a login on your server.
> 4) Find some other method to send the file.

Set up proftpd read only chrooted with only an anonymous login
if you don't care about sniffing.  For that matter, if you 
encrypt the data itself and give the recipient the key 
through more secure means, who cares if the package is 
sniffed en route?  Just put the URL in your email message.

Email has become so unreliable with poor authentication and
broken sites that it's a wonder it works at all.

Watch out about giving a login, this is where most security 
breaches start.

Subject: [PLUG] Training a bayesian filter
In-Reply-To: <200404110219.i3B2Jjew012197@gourmet.spamgourmet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404091057360.16338@pecos.madboa.com> <200404110219.i3B2Jjew012197@gourmet.spamgourmet.com>
Message-ID: <20040411155257.GD14756@merlot.com>

Paul Johnson (baloo at ursine.ca) typed this ...
> Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> writes:
> > 4. spam.kept: where I keep about 250 known-spam messages. This is
> >    useful if I have to rebuild a bayes database.
> 
> I'm intrigued why you bother keeping this one around when one could
> easily get their fill and then some by browsing through
> ...

Because your spam is not the same as my spam. I host email for some
friends' domains, and I see the spam I reject for them and the spam I
reject for me. There is almost zero intersection, if you leave out the
fact that most of it is relayed through Asia or sent via
broadband-connected zombies.

I see this as proof that keeping my own spam corpus is critical to
proper training of whatever Bayesian solution I choose to use.

From aaron at ultravolt.net  Sun Apr 11 11:56:01 2004
From: aaron at ultravolt.net (Aaron Ten Clay)

Subject: [PLUG] VoIP on DSL?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404110239370.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

Jeme is correct. VoIP connections generally consume around 55kbps after
compression. (Both up and down, of course) So with an ADSL connection of,
say, 1500/256, you could easily have 4 VoIP "lines".

As to latency: most VoIP providers offer routers supporting QoS,
preconfigured to pre-empt VoIP traffic, ensuring the lowest possible
latency.

Aaron

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Sun Apr 11 12:27:01 2004
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Sun Apr 11 12:27:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] VoIP on DSL?
In-Reply-To: <200404111855.i3BIttD10497@box002.ultravolt.net>
References: <200404111855.i3BIttD10497@box002.ultravolt.net>
Message-ID: <200404111220.53622.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Sunday 11 April 2004 11:56, Aaron Ten Clay wrote:
> Jeme is correct. VoIP connections generally consume around 55kbps
> after compression. (Both up and down, of course) So with an ADSL
> connection of, say, 1500/256, you could easily have 4 VoIP "lines".
>
> As to latency: most VoIP providers offer routers supporting QoS,
> preconfigured to pre-empt VoIP traffic, ensuring the lowest
> possible latency.

Uhm, this certainly doesn't dovetail with the experiences I had 
working for a VoIP firm for four years.

Different codecs have different bandwidth requirements.  G.723.1 is 
one of the lowest with around 7-8kbps.  G.729 is better quality but a 
little higher bandwidth.  About 12kpbs IIRC.  This is just for the 
codec audio stream, not other overhead!

If you sample voice at 8khz with 8-bit samples, you get standard G.711 
(which is no compression at all) and that is 64kbps.

There are a couple of more open codecs such as Speex and GSM.  Those 
are fairly good.  G.729 licensing is ugly.  $1 per port in single 
configurations and $10/port in multiple port configurations.  Yuck.  
G.723.1 is pretty bad too.

On top of the codec bandwidth, you've got packet overhead.  Generally 
you want to put two or three packets of audio into each UDP packet to 
reduce that overhead.  Too much audio data per RTP/UDP packet and 
you've got bad latency again and you'll need to bump up the jitter 
buffer.  Then you're in latency land again.  Over 200ms and the human 
ear can easily detect the latency.  Under that, and generally you 
don't notice it.   Note that using a microphone/speak ensemble 
through a sound card is a guaranteed way to introduce a _lot_ of 
latency.

I've personally run two simultaneous bidirectional calls through a 
28.8 modem without problems other than the horrible latency from the 
modem.  That was with G.723.1, 60ms frames, one frame per RTP packet.

If you are using G.711 and not doing any compression, then you'll be 
able to get one call per ISDN channel equivalent (i.e. 64kbps).  
Since there are free codecs, why would you want to run uncompressed 
audio streams?

So, let's assume that GSM plus packet overhead is about 20kpbs.  That 
leaves you with about a dozen simultaneous calls through a 256kbps 
link (you've got to count the lowest bandwidth side only).

Best,
Kyle

max_kb_per_request      64              1               127             rw
multcount               8               0               8               rw
nice1                   1               0               1               rw
nowerr                  0               0               1               rw
pio_mode                write-only      0               255             w
slow                    0               0               1               rw
unmaskirq               1               0               1               rw
using_dma               1               0               1               rw

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sun Apr 11 15:38:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sun Apr 11 15:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Something I don't want in my maillog...
Message-ID: <4079C87C.2050103@robinson-west.com>

I could try to block every ip off from three subnets trying to sending
to a nonexistent account at my site, it's tedious though blocking
individual ip's and I'm well over a hundred of them now.  There
has to be a way to tell postfix I don't want it to log people who
can't get past the hello stage because they want to send to certain
nonexistent accounts.  If someone wanted to understand I'm not
listening, they would by now because they are not allowed to send
me data.  With the number of addresses in the same subnet trying
to send me this, it is clearly a virus or worm that I'm fighting.

On the other hand, there are rare cases where I want to see a record of
failure to send to a nonexistent account that should exist.  Maybe someone
came by the site and wants to contact someone through it thinking there's
an account for this person.  There's also the braindead providence network,
mail from inside the hospital never comes from a globally registered
address.  I had to turn off unknown hostname in helo checks because
I can't consistently get this to override for Providence.  I figured out
a long time ago that the name of the computer in the private network
behind the Internet connection hosting the mail should have the same
name that is used on the Internet side.  I have an external and
an internal goose record.  Providence should at least masquerade
to an address that can actually be looked up.

I'm tired of the log pollution because there's the inefficiency of logging
so much and log pollution makes it harder to see meaningful errors.

From ian at znark.com  Sun Apr 11 15:54:01 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Sun Apr 11 15:54:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MX seconding and fetchmail
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404101738210.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404101738210.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <4079CC44.2060206@znark.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> I may be moving my home network in a little while.  No assurance that
>  I can get any kind of overlap on the network connectivity, so I'm 
> considering a kind of stop-gap measure that could possibly be a 
> permanent fail-over solution for my mail.
> 
> There are some assumptions here about the way things work that I've 
> never used before, so please pipe up if I write something nutso.
> 
> I figure I'll set my domains' secondary MX to some machine off-net 
> (that is to say, not at the end of my DSL connection).  That machine 
> will be configured to deliver ALL mail for my domains to a single 
> mailbox accessible by some remote retrieval protocol.  Then, whenever
>  my primary MX is unavailable, the mail will be delivered to the 
> secondary. Periodically, my primary MX will launch a fetchmail 
> process to grab all the mail from the secondary MX and deliver it 
> locally according to the local MTA's configuration.
> 

I don't think mail servers can be configured to try the primary and
deliver locally if it can't be reached.  They either are a secondary,
queueing mail for the primary MX.  Or they deliver the mail locally.

If your local server is going to be down for a while, I would setup the 
remote site to accept the mail and use fetchmail to retrieve it.  If the 
downtime is going to be short, then setup the secondary and let it queue 
the mail.

> Does that all sound quite sane and reasonable?  The initial delivery 
> to the secondary MX shouldn't mess with any of the envelope 
> information of the messages and prevent them from being delivered to 
> disparate mailboxes on the primary, will it?
> 

With many mail servers, the SMTP recipient is completely lost
once the message is delivered.  This can create problems when splitting 
to multiple mailboxes.  This happens especially with mailing lists and 
similar where the receipient is not found in the headers.  Postfix and 
qmail add the Delivered-To header with the receipient.  This can be used 
by fetchmail.

> This seems so straightforward, I would think it's probably common 
> practice in some circles (unless there's a configuration within the
> MTA to do the failover and re-delivery).
> 

Fetchmail works with the fetching remove mailbox and delivering it 
locally with multiple mailboxes.

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

On Sun, 11 Apr 2004, Chris Penwell wrote:

> It looks like you didn't enter a hostname when you set up your networking. I
> installed 9.1 (i think,) on a friend of mine's machine, and it did the same
> thing.. kinda irritating..

  man hostname:

HOSTNAME(1)                 Linux Programmer's Manual               HOSTNAME(1)

NAME
       hostname - show or set the system's host name
       domainname - show or set the system's NIS/YP domain name
       dnsdomainname - show the system's DNS domain name
       nisdomainname - show or set system's NIS/YP domain name
       ypdomainname - show or set the system's NIS/YP domain name
       nodename - show or set the system's DECnet node name

SYNOPSIS
       hostname  [-v]  [-a]  [--alias] [-d] [--domain] [-f] [--fqdn] [-i] [--ip-
       address] [--long] [-s] [--short] [-y] [--yp] [--nis] [-n] [--node]

       hostname [-v] [-F filename] [--file filename] [hostname]

       domainname [-v] [-F filename] [--file filename] [name]

       nodename [-v] [-F filename] [--file filename] [name]

       hostname [-v] [-h] [--help] [-V] [--version]

       dnsdomainname [-v]
       nisdomainname [-v]
       ypdomainname [-v]

DESCRIPTION
       Hostname is the program that is used to either set or display the current
       host, domain or node name of the system.  These names are used by many of
       the networking programs to identify the machine. The domain name is also
       used by NIS/YP.

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From barryb at proaxis.com  Sun Apr 11 22:52:02 2004
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Sun Apr 11 22:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Data recovery service?
In-Reply-To: <20040412051550.EE5CD744E9@john.meissen.org>
References: <20040412051550.EE5CD744E9@john.meissen.org>
Message-ID: <20040412055101.GA20144@edge>

On Sun, Apr 11, 2004 at 10:15:50PM -0700, John Meissen wrote:
> 
> I have a friend who (like most people) wasn't doing adequate backups on
> his Windows system. His IBM Deathstar drive suddenly died yesterday, and 
> he needs to try to recover whatever can be saved from it. I spent a good 
> part of the day playing with it, but only managed to copy off one or two
> files. So we need to find a professional recovery service. Does anyone
> have a recommendation for such a place in the Portland area, preferably 
> on the West side?
> 

I don't know about places in the Portland area, but I had good luck
with DTI Data http://www.dtidata.com/
I sent them a laptop hard drive that died and they recovered 
all the data from it for about half the price I was quoted from 
other services.

My other recommendation is to give the drive a days rest and try
it again. Others have had good luck putting the drive in the 
freezer for a while. Just be prepared if it does come back
alive to immediately get the important data off first.

Bill Barry



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Apr 12 00:24:02 2004
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon Apr 12 00:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] laptop display and external monitor together
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404111556150.15272-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404111556150.15272-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <16506.17410.170733.54741@bebop.local>

How you do this is very dependant on your video card.  (probably
wether you can also.)  In general, this is done through the xinerama
extension to X.  (Option "xinerama" in your ServerLayout section of
XF86Config[-4]).  If you have a radeon, you want to use the "big
desktop" mode w/ the "official" radeon driver.  Nvidia has a similar
trick to get multi-head, but I don't recall what it is called.  As far
as I know, the _only_ reason not to use xinerama is to get hardware
acceleration with dual head. (dri is not compatable with xinerama).

Regrettably, the radeon "big desktop" mode dosen't support the
xinerama extensions to X.  With xinerama, the window manager can tell
where one monitor ends and the next one begins, and (I think) find
"blank" zones that aren't displayed at all (for example, two monitors
running at different vertical resolutions, yet arrayed side-by-side
will have some un-displayable area infringing on the standard
rectangular desktop shape).  Without the multi-head hack from ATI (I
imagine nvidia as well..) you have annoying things like windows
popping up split accross monitors, and maximizing windows spreads
accross all monitors, rather than one (which can be nice, I admit).

You can also use dual-head without xinerama, in which case each head
is running it's own xsession (and window manager.. etc).  This is
kindof cool, since your mouse traverses heads, but you can't drag
windows accross.  It's an interesting way to do things, but never got
me going (one trick of note is that you don't have to run the same WM
on each head--how you do this is left as an excersize--I don't know
of the top of my head).

Matt Alexander writes:
 > I have a dual-boot laptop (XP/Fedora) and on the XP side I can configure
 > my display to use the laptop screen as well as an LCD display that's
 > plugged into the laptop.  Then I can move windows, etc., from one screen
 > to the other and they both function together as one large monitor.
 > 
 > Does anyone know of a way to do this in Linux?
 > 
 > 
 > 
 > 
 > _______________________________________________
 > PLUG mailing list
 > PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
 > http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

On Sun, 11 Apr 2004, Russ Johnson wrote:

> > Procmail seems to have no trouble writing to the files once they
> > exist. It just can't create them if they don't exist.
>
> OK, after more testing, I have determined that it makes no
> difference as to what the permissions on the directory are.
>
> I set them to 777, and it made no difference. I still get "Unable to
> write..." error if the file does not exist.

Wierd. Next barrage of questions:

1. Do the same symptoms exist for all users on your system, or only
   for you?

   a. If only for you, do you have any funky 'noclobber' options in
      your shell environment? Have you tried setting "VERBOSE=yes" in
      your .procmailrc file?

2. Who built your procmail? Can you provide an exact rpm, deb, or
   whatever version string?

3. What arguments does your MTA (sendmail, postfix, ...) provide
   procmail? In sendmail land, you'd see something like this in your
   sendmail.cf conf:

Mprocmail,      P=/usr/bin/procmail, F=DFMSPhnu9,
		S=EnvFromSMTP/HdrFromSMTP, R=EnvToSMTP/HdrFromSMTP,
                T=DNS/RFC822/X-Unix,
                A=procmail -Y -m $h $f $u

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Paul Heinlein wrote:

>Wierd. Next barrage of questions:
>
>1. Do the same symptoms exist for all users on your system, or only
>   for you?
>
OK, I set up the same backup example in another users account, and it 
happens for them as well.

procmail: Error while writing to "~/.mailbackup/04-04"

(Thunder goes off in my head....)

I figured it out.

Procmail does not support ~/ as the users home directory. You have to 
use $HOME.

Russ

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue Apr 13 00:25:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue Apr 13 00:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] smtp with sender subscription...
Message-ID: <407B9576.3000608@robinson-west.com>

Rationale...


I want to reconfigure postfix 2.0.19 or set up qmail
as a frontend to it so that you have to subscribe to
my site to send me email.  Essentially, if an unknown
sender tries to email my server, a bounce should be
generated explaining that they must subscribe to send
me email.  This way, random spammers fearing
identification probably won't bother to respond and
I'll actually be able to spare my users from a lot of
upsetting unsolicited garbage that is very hard to detect
with 100% accuracy.  


The Problems...


For a sender must subscribe system to work well,
local users need to be able to manually modify
subscription lists for mailing lists and trusted private
addresses, preemptively.  For example, I would put
plug at lists.pdxlinux.org in a subscribed list for
any account I want to use it from.
  
Forcing sender subscription may be shunned
by some, but I'm fighting a losing battle trying to add
iptables rules in order to block the addresses of
abusers.  Not knowing how long an address should be
blocked and realizing as time goes on that the sheer
length of the list is becoming a problem for manual
maintenance methods, it's try another approach or
eventually shut down.  I already use spamassassin
and Mailfilter, but I'm not stopping annoying ads.  

It amazes me that there is so much attempted traffic to
sonya.h on my mailsite, yet I don't host a sonya.h
account.  Abusive senders should have figured
that out by now.  I'm tired of blocking ips to try and
get rid of useless errors from computers trying to
send to sonya.h.  

I don't want a system where every one is
blacklisted except for a short whitelist, that doesn't
address growth very well.  

SMTP authentication is out, after all, all that
anyone has to do is copy the authentication
if you're running through a clear text smtp
server or relay.  Authentication doesn't
seem friendly to adding new senders.

...

On solving problem with a sender must subscribe
approach...


I should probably have a website that people have to
go to to subscribe to my site before they can email
me, though I'm open to suggestions.  

The hold feature in postfix-2.0.19, does it work
indefinitely?  I'm wondering thinking to hold the
mail from unsubscribed senders until the sender
subscribes or a reasonable amount of time so
that I'm not holding onto junk forever.

Subscription should be a one time thing
for a sender for as long as the local
recipient(s) approve.
 
Maybe I should run qmail in parallel with postfix,
just for subscription purposes, feeding the messages
that are passing subscription check through into my  
existing Postfix/Mailfilter/Clamav/spamassassin
setup.  Maybe I'll have to alias a second private
address onto my mailserver to give qmail a home.

I've had trouble with valid senders saying helo with
unregistered addresses.  I either work out an override
feature when it comes to hostname checking, or I'll
have to give up on hostname checking entirely.  Why
isn't who you say hello as defined more rigidly?  
What are the implications for setting up a
senders must subscribe smtp server?


Summary...


Exposed to the whole Internet and attempting to
stop abusers of my mail site, I'll never succeed
with a block individual ips approach. 
Spamassassin and Mailfilter help, but they're
not stopping drug ads.  I can hold a message
perhaps until it's sender subscribes, so losing
messages should be mitigateable.  The goal is
to stop spam or at least know where it's coming
from.

I'd be imposing opt-in on senders with a subscription
requirement, a lot of computer generated stuff should
be stopped cold by this.  Especially if I make the
subscription process something that can only be done
by a human, albeit over the Net for convenience, a
subscription requirement should affectively cut down
UCE/spam.  A web site could have an agreement as
part of subscription that legally protects me and my
local users.

Yes  or no on force sender subscription?

     --  Michael C. Robinson

Subject: [PLUG] Spam gets around my WHITELIST?
Message-ID: <200404130703.20876.guy1656@ados.com>

I have a whitelist in K-Mail, using partial chunks of acceptable email addys, 
(including PLUG) of course. The LAST filter rule is: if 'message' contains 
'x' OR 'message' doesn't contain 'x,' put the e-mail in the trash.

This has worked great for months. I -have- had a few bits of spam get through 
on the off chance that they include the same cluster of letters as the 
cluster I use to pick out a valid e-mail, but that has been rare enough to be 
amusing when it does happen.

However, the e-mail I attach here shouldn't be able to make it thruogh ... yet 
it did. I am including part of the header in case the attachment itself gets 
scrubbed.

From gmickels at yahoo.com  Tue Apr 13 08:52:01 2004
From: gmickels at yahoo.com (Garrett Mickelson)
Date: Tue Apr 13 08:52:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux IRC channel
In-Reply-To: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E6028D81A1@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
References: 
	 <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E6028D81A1@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
Message-ID: <1081871473.5987.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Freenode (irc.freenode.net) you can find #linpeople and #linux.
#linux gets pretty full, making it difficult to ask questions and get a
timely reply if any. #linpeople though seems geared toward linux support
as well, and has fewer people. One thing to keep in mind though is that
often times depending on the time of day, you may or may not get much
help. It also depends on the knowledge level of those logged in and
paying attention. Unfortunately it seems that a lot of people remain
logged in when not on their computers making it seem as though 100
people are on the channel and paying attention, though you don't get any
reply to questions. That can be really annoying especially on smaller,
more directly focused channels. 
You also may find help on any of the numerous LUG channels as well.

Good luck!

-Garrett

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Apr 13 09:48:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Apr 13 09:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] smtp with sender subscription...
In-Reply-To: <407B9576.3000608@robinson-west.com>
References: <407B9576.3000608@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <407C19B2.4060102@dimstar.net>

Michael Robinson wrote:

> Rationale...
>
>
> I want to reconfigure postfix 2.0.19 or set up qmail
> as a frontend to it so that you have to subscribe to
> my site to send me email.  


OK, we just discussed this, and determined that it's a bad idea.

> For a sender must subscribe system to work well,
> local users need to be able to manually modify
> subscription lists for mailing lists and trusted private
> addresses, preemptively.  For example, I would put
> plug at lists.pdxlinux.org in a subscribed list for
> any account I want to use it from.

Yes, we are well versed in how this works. It's still a bad idea.

> I'm fighting a losing battle trying to add
> iptables rules in order to block the addresses of
> abusers.

Why bother? Properly configured, your existing system should stop or 
identify 95%+ of the UCE coming into your system.

Once it's identified, it's easy to manage, and you don't inconvienence 
the legitimate senders of email by forcing them to jump through hoops to 
talk to you. That's like punishing folks because they want to talk to you.

Like I said, bad idea.

> I already use spamassassin
> and Mailfilter, but I'm not stopping annoying ads. 

Then something isn't configured properly.

Are you using bayesian filtering in spamassassin?

Do you have DNSBL set up in postfix?

> It amazes me that there is so much attempted traffic to
> sonya.h on my mailsite, yet I don't host a sonya.h
> account.

So? Do you actually have postfix configure to tell you when that 
happens? Why? Does it matter? Why not just silently /dev/null it, and 
move on?

My report for yesterday (pflogsum.pl) says that over 600 message were 
attempted to unknown users, from one site. It appears to have mostly 
happened within a 2 hour time period, and other than the report, I 
wouldn't know about it.

According to the same report, 56% of the mail that was attempted to be 
delivered yesterday was rejected. Due to unknown user, DNSBL and other 
reasons. This does NOT include the spam that spamassassin eventually 
flagged, and procmail filed for me.

> Abusive senders should have figured
> that out by now.  I'm tired of blocking ips to try and
> get rid of useless errors from computers trying to
> send to sonya.h. 

Then don't. You are simply spinning in circles trying to stop something 
that you have no control over. There are much easier ways to handle 
this, and it doesn't require that you make people jump through hoops to 
talk to you.

> I don't want a system where every one is
> blacklisted except for a short whitelist, that doesn't
> address growth very well. 

Isn't this exactly what you are asking for?

> SMTP authentication is out, after all, all that
> anyone has to do is copy the authentication
> if you're running through a clear text smtp
> server or relay.  Authentication doesn't
> seem friendly to adding new senders.

SMTP auth is for your users, not for servers.

Russ

From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue Apr 13 11:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] smtp with sender subscription...
In-Reply-To: <407C19B2.4060102@dimstar.net>
References: <407B9576.3000608@robinson-west.com> <407C19B2.4060102@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <407C3821.2020600@robinson-west.com>

>
>
>> I don't want a system where every one is
>> blacklisted except for a short whitelist, that doesn't
>> address growth very well. 
>
>
> Isn't this exactly what you are asking for?


My first Linux instructor Mike was so disgusted with spam that
he did go to a short whitelist, everyone else blacklisted, scheme.  
I'm just trying to adapt that for growth.

No, I'll have the ability to add people to a permanently subscribed,
or white list, ahead of tine.  This way they don't have to answer a
subscription question in the future.  I'm not looking at iptables
blocking anyone where I can't know that they're trying to send
me email.  The probability of a subscriber sending you spam
compared to some random address sending you spam is
much lower.  If I use blacklists on line where I do use dns
ignorant at least, how do I know if I should trust these or not? 
It costs to go out and use these resources too.  I use postfix
logsumm from Jim Sun, though I don't fully understand
what it tells me.  Some spam still does get through what
I'm already doing, so a maillog full of errors from rejected
senders makes it hard to find information about actual spam
sources.  I figure blacklisting means not knowing a particular
sender is trying to send me email and not holding any
attempted message from them pending verification.

There is too much temptation to send out unsolicited email
 because it doesn't cost the sender anything and many senders
are confident that the vast majority of sites won't impose any
system that can identify them.
  
Using someone else's black list is letting someone else force
registration in some form, albeit incompletely in many cases.  
A check of rfc ignorant is checking  a registry.  The spamhaus
database is a registry.  Is it better  to let someone else do
registration than it is to do it yourself on your own traffic?  
Maybe online databases get their information from people
who are sent garbage and report it, but they are still registries.

I would like to know how to log worthless errors where no mail is
delivered to a log other than the maillog so thaI can get to pertinent
information faster, like where spam that got through dns resolution
checking came from.

Is the attitude about spam where people are anti registration that
anonymity of senders and conveniencing senders is more sacred than
protecting local users?  Who has the right to be anonymous sending
email to private sites without asking first?

     --  Michael Robinson

> > asking first?

Jeme responded with: 
> Everyone... just as they have the right to speak or send mail through the
> post office.

> J.

And just so- everyone also has the right to only open the mail they want. 
I don't open and shred the "sell you house now" physical mail I get. Nothing
in your right to send me anonymous mail violates my right not to read it.
The same goes for email. And weblog comments- even up to a seriously aggrevating
USBank shill posting on a 11 month old comment on my weblog. I leave the shill
there but take off the "casino" guy with the advertisement.  

We all have a right to anonyminity. Anomymousness. Name-freedom. But there's a 
price that's exacted; you lose some credibility, and there's the possibility
that your message will be unheeded, trashed or even shredded.



From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Apr 13 12:56:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Apr 13 12:56:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] smtp with sender subscription...
In-Reply-To: <407C3821.2020600@robinson-west.com>
References: <407B9576.3000608@robinson-west.com> <407C19B2.4060102@dimstar.net> <407C3821.2020600@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <407C459E.7030209@dimstar.net>

Michael Robinson wrote:

>>
>>
>>> I don't want a system where every one is
>>> blacklisted except for a short whitelist, that doesn't
>>> address growth very well. 
>>
>>
>>
>> Isn't this exactly what you are asking for?
>
>
>
> My first Linux instructor Mike was so disgusted with spam that
> he did go to a short whitelist, everyone else blacklisted, scheme.  
> I'm just trying to adapt that for growth.

It's still blacklisting everyone, and then whitelisting those you deem 
worthy of communication with.

The system I advocate blacklists those that have proven themselves not 
worthy. Sure, I get a few false negatives. Maybe 10 a week. The rest 
either never make it past postfixes dnsbl or get tagged by spamassassin. 
10 a week is very manageable, and I can plug those through salearn so 
spamassassin learns to block them in the future.

I haven't implemented razor, as my particular problem hasn't gotten that 
bad. But that system seems to be fairly good as well, and plugs right 
into spamassassin.

> No, I'll have the ability to add people to a permanently subscribed,
> or white list, ahead of tine.  This way they don't have to answer a
> subscription question in the future.

Wow. You know when your high school buddy is going to find you on the 
'net? AND what his email address is? Cool. Did you learn this technique, 
or were you born with it?

You can't know all the email addresses that will send you legitimate email.

> If I use blacklists on line where I do use dns
> ignorant at least, how do I know if I should trust these or not? 

Well, track records go a long way. Folks on this list have posted what 
they use. I'd give that a try before going to a 
blacklist/whitelist/opt-in method.

> It costs to go out and use these resources too.

It does? Then you aren't looking in the right places. I have around 10 
dnsrbls that I use, and they're all free.

>  I use postfix logsumm from Jim Sun, though I don't fully understand
> what it tells me.

Well, give us a try, or search the web. I'm sure it's not that hard to 
figure out.

>   Some spam still does get through what
> I'm already doing, so a maillog full of errors from rejected
> senders makes it hard to find information about actual spam
> sources.

The source doesn't matter when you have things properly configured.

I have done nothing to my system except make sure the binaries are up to 
date, and copy false negatives to my spamscan folder. Everything else is 
automatic.

>   I figure blacklisting means not knowing a particular
> sender is trying to send me email and not holding any
> attempted message from them pending verification.

So you just /dev/null anything from folks you don't deem worthy.

That's what I thought you meant.

> There is too much temptation to send out unsolicited email
> because it doesn't cost the sender anything and many senders
> are confident that the vast majority of sites won't impose any
> system that can identify them.

Which is, for the most part, true. That doesn't mean there aren't 
effective measures to limit the amount of spam that comes into your 
email box.

> Using someone else's black list is letting someone else force
> registration in some form, albeit incompletely in many cases.  A check 
> of rfc ignorant is checking  a registry.  The spamhaus
> database is a registry.  Is it better  to let someone else do
> registration than it is to do it yourself on your own traffic?  Maybe 
> online databases get their information from people
> who are sent garbage and report it, but they are still registries.

I think you misunderstand. These "registries" are of known spammers, not 
of known legitimate emailers. They are doing exactly the reverse of what 
you are proposing.

> Is the attitude about spam where people are anti registration that
> anonymity of senders and conveniencing senders is more sacred than
> protecting local users?  Who has the right to be anonymous sending
> email to private sites without asking first?

In reality, no one is anonymous. Spamcop was a great way to find where a 
spam came from.

I'm not advocating conveniencing anyone. I'm advocating NOT 
inconveniencing anyone. I'm also advocating NOT letting the spammers get 
their mail through, at least, not intact. So far, a combination of 
DNSRBL and spamassassin do a nice job of this.

Russ

>If by "registration" you mean your scheme where all email addresses become

It's my private site, why I should I have to talk to people who won't 
identify
themselves to me?  If people would would desist in setting up mail sites 
that don't
require sender subscription, the spam problem would subside a great 
deal.  With
any spamlist like dns ignorant, etc., there is an attempt to mark 
certain email sources.
There's no law which states that any private entity has to receive any 
email that
anyone wants to send to it, nor should there be.  With the spamassassin and
dns lists approach solely, you have to work all the time or put up with 
spam.
Part of the wonder of conversation is choice in who the conversation is 
with,
take that away and it becomes a less useful tool.  

Requiring sender subscription closing subscription down sometimes allows 
you
to take a break.  A day may come when the environmental and sociological
impacts of relying on filtering of email through heuristical testing 
becomes a
common concern.  Missed junk can be disturbing, especiallyt if there is a
growing amount?  Do we need coal based power plants solely for our spam
filters alone?  There is a responsible expense for filtering and a point 
at which
one must question if the cost of communication is getting too high and 
another
content control method is needed.

>>Who has the right to be anonymous sending email to private sites without
>>asking first?
>>    
>>
>
>Everyone... just as they have the right to speak or send mail through the
>post office.to 
>
>  
>
I see you have no respect for privacy nor any respect for people who 
don't want
to actively work on severing communication wth people they don't want to 
talk
to.  Registration offers a way to block spam that makes the sender work, 
I see
a lot of good in this.  And concerning the post office, there are anti 
junk mail
laws that people actually use.  I think you're confusing right with the 
ability to
do something.  I see no supporting argument here that there is any right 
to email
me when I'm not interested.  I do have a right to email privacy though 
when it
comes to not wanting certain stuff coming in.  Spammers don't pay me
when my bandwidth gets used for their message, I owe them nothing.  I don't
have to inconvenience people I want to talk to, I can presubscribe them
myself.  If I don't know someone's email address, they merely have to
subscribe.  If someone wants to talk to me, there is a willingness to
initiate conversation that can overcome minor inconveniences for the
sake of focus.  I don't want to be distracted by junk coming through.

From chris at maybe.net  Tue Apr 13 20:49:01 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Apr 13 20:49:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi set up pointers needed
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131945190.30658@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131503170.29876@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <407CA10E.7000607@linuxlink.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131945190.30658@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040414034817.GE24436@maybe.net>

On Tue, Apr 13, 2004 at 07:53:01PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   The tools seem to be there. But, I don't know how to configure wlan.
> What's a MIB, WEP and the other acronyms? How do I answer config file
> questions when I've no idea what it is I should want?

A MIB is a schema for an SNMP tree. I really doubt you'd need it as a
client... WEP is encryption. Failing better advice or making it to a
workshop, I'd point you towards /etc/pcmcia/wireless.opts and "man
iwconfig". The two work together. However, first try to find
distro-specific config stuff so as to make your life easier.

>   A step-by-step, cookbook approach is what I want now. I've too many things
> going on (my book's going to be late to the publisher and I do have to make
> money in between all the fun things) so I don't have the interest in
> spending a day or two futzing with getting the card and notebook talking
> WiFi.

Unfortunately, as you may have gathered from previous threads on this
mailing list, wireless is not a particularly "solved" problem in Linux
yet. However, if you're confident your hardware should be
transparently supported by your Linux-ready laptop (vis-a-vis the
hardware being the same as your vendor would've sold you --- although
this is not always a guarantee, some vendors have been known to change
chipsets in manufacturing runs of the same model), then it may just be
a matter of filling in the right fields in the mentioned config file.

If you're still not past your implementation deadlines, feel free to
keep asking questions. :-)

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

Michael Robinson wrote:

> Not that kind of cost.  Think about network load instead.  If I'm 
> saying no the same sender
> address n times that starts to cost too. 

Thats not the way DNS works. DNS looks the address up once, and then 
it's cached until the ttl runs out. Then it looks it up again. If it's 
still there, it caches it again. Very minimal cost if you ask me.

And from my experience, it works very well. I received 25 spam messages 
marked as such and appropriately filed by procmail. I received one 
(count em, one) false negative, which I moved to my spamscan folder so 
my copy of spamassassin can learn to block that one too.

An aside here. Spamassassin is also caching the virii for me, since I 
threw those in the spamscan folder too.

On Tue, 13 Apr 2004, Michael Robinson wrote:
> It's my private site, why I should I have to talk to people who won't

Nobody has even once suggested that you have to talk to anybody... or even

(probably out of respect for the potential recipient).

> If people would would desist in setting up mail sites that don't require
> sender subscription, the spam problem would subside a great deal.

OK, you understand that mail is an open protocol that just describes a
datastream connecting on a particular port, right?  You don't need a "mail
site" to send mail, you just need a TCP connection and an appropriate data
stream.  Every node on the network is a potential "mail site".

> With any spamlist like dns ignorant, etc., there is an attempt to mark
> certain email sources.

Contrary to Paul Johnson's insistence to the contrary, I don't think
there's any evidence that this is effective at all.  Your own fruitless
labors should at least hint that the approach is flawed.

> There's no law which states that any private entity has to receive any
> email that anyone wants to send to it, nor should there be.

I don't think anybody here is directly advocating coersion or state
tyranny.  I believe many of us are just trying to express to you the value
of remaining as open to what others have to offer as possible.

You've configured Apache, right?

We're saying you should go with:
Order allow, deny

And you're pushing for:
Order deny, allow

That's more restrictive and narrow; least open and social.  Civilization
is built on sharing ideas from one to another... and there've been quite a
few times when those who were brought to enlightenment were dragged
kicking and screaming.  You don't know what's out there if you only let in
what you already recognize and accept.

> With the spamassassin and dns lists approach solely, you have to work
> all the time or put up with spam.

I wouldn't call it "work".  You just move aside the messages you don't
want to read.

With your "Default Deny" approach, you have to work all the time just to
maintain the bare minimum of the healthy stream of new ideas and insights
that open communication brings.

> Part of the wonder of conversation is choice in who the conversation is
> with, take that away and it becomes a less useful tool.

That's not "wonder" on any level at all (except maybe the wonder that you
lived this long without understanding the value of strangers' seemingly
contrary modes of existence and thought).

Yeah, we respect your RIGHT to plug your ears and shout "neener neener" to
drown out the rest of the world, but we also feel somewhat obligated to
show you how to engage that world meaningfully and grow from that
experience.

> Requiring sender subscription closing subscription down sometimes allows
> you to take a break.

Uh huh... do you always check with someone in person before you send them
email?  Or do you just send the message expecting delivery and that the
recipient will make their own intelligent decision about whether or not it
merits response, acknowledgement or even notice?

The system you propose just puts another barrier between people.  All of
human progress to this day has been pushing for the opposite.  In fact,
one perfectly acceptable definition of "regressive" is "increasing the
disparity between people" and that is surely one result of increasing the
effort-requirement in personal communication.

> A day may come when the environmental and sociological impacts of
> relying on filtering of email through heuristical testing becomes a
> common concern.

I hope you just wrote that in desperation without really thinking about
it.  Consider the load average of your desktop machine over 24 hours.
Consider that spam processing doesn't exactly bog down anything you or I
are able to run for mail servers.  And consider further that the
electrical power per instruction in CPUs is dropping through the floor
which, in turn increases the ready availability of ever-faster machines
for our hobbies and home servers.

> Missed junk can be disturbing, especiallyt if there is a growing amount?

Disturbing?  What are you talking about?  Is it more of your fear of sex
and drugs?

> Do we need coal based power plants solely for our spam filters alone?

Wow.  That's quite a reach you've got there.

Trust me, we'll run out of coal before spam processing is consuming even
the power of ONE coal plant each day.

> There is a responsible expense for filtering and a point at which one

> another content control method is needed.

The filters are all in your head.  You're the one who's annoyed, so put
the filter between your ear and the rest of the world.  Don't slap it on
other people's mouths.

> >>Who has the right to be anonymous sending email to private sites
> >>without asking first?
> >
> >Everyone... just as they have the right to speak or send mail through
> >the post office.to
>
> I see you have no respect for privacy

How is receiving an unsolicited email an invasion of privacy?  I suppose
you could be trying to conflate receiving an electronic message with some
kind of trespass of chattels, but the lack of demonstrable damages sort of
makes the whole thing moot.

> nor any respect for people who don't want to actively work on severing
> communication wth people they don't want to talk to.

Uh... if I'm parsing all those negatives correctly, you're writing that I
have don't respect people who don't try to ignore other people.  No idea
where you got that, because I was writing just the opposite.  Openness is
a GOOD thing.

Your idea seems to hinge on the belief that you know who has something
worthwhile to say to you before they say it.  Where would you get such
foreknowledge?

> Registration offers a way to block spam that makes the sender work, I
> see a lot of good in this.

You see a lot of good in making it harder for people to communicate with
you... you see a lot of good in causing pain for those who would offer you
information for your benefit?

Stunning.

You DO realize, don't you, that this would not just impact spammers but
colleagues who read your posts on this mailing list and would like to help
you in some endeavor and wonderful people that get your email address
because they want to get to know you well, but are too timid or
embarrassed to approach you directly?  Both of those situations happen to
me on not-infrequent occassion and I can't even express how much love and
joy has come from those experiences.

This reminds me of the magic mind-reading filter you wanted that would
ditch failed delivery notices for messages to addresses that were guesses
at valid mail accounts for the purpose of spam, but would inform you when
the failed delivery was for a message that whose recipient names were
guesses because the well-meaning sender didn't have better information.
There's no electronic "intent" filter.  Spamassassin's the closest we've
got.

> I think you're confusing right with the ability to do something.

Uh, no.  Attempting to communicate MUST be protected as a right of all
people, else they will have no means to rally others' against oppressive
consolidated power.  Our respect of and desire for freedom demands respect
for the right of people to attempt to communicate with others and share
their ideas.

> I see no supporting argument here that there is any right to email me
> when I'm not interested.

It's the principle of least restriction.

You have the choice of making a small sacrifice (spending some time
handling spam) so that others can continue to enjoy the freedom of and
leisure allowed by the expected behavior of email or forcing all others to
make a small sacrifice for your benefit.

The choice seems obvious to me... and, I guess, to you.  Maybe I
misinterpreted "Christian".

> I do have a right to email privacy though when it comes to not wanting
> certain stuff coming in.

So stop the stuff from coming in.  Your system does nothing to stop the
stuff from coming in.  You have to let it in in order to bounce it back
and tell the sender that they have to jump through your little hoop for
the priviledge of your audience.

Your argument about bandwidth is, at best, a red herring and at worst
purposeful misdirection to support your fascist agenda.  From now on, I'll
just call you Michael Rumsfeldson.

> Spammers don't pay me when my bandwidth gets used for their message, I
> owe them nothing.

And you don't pay me when my bandwidth gets used for your message.  So
what?  The whole structure of the email system depends on assumed reliable
delivery and complicit dedication of resources to the medium.

> I don't have to inconvenience people I want to talk to, I can
> presubscribe them myself.

What if you don't know you want to talk to them?  What if they are a fine
person who is shy as in the example above?  What if they are on the far
side of the world, but have developed a solution to your publicly lamented
problem?

> If I don't know someone's email address, they merely have to subscribe.

And how do they know to subscribe?  And how is this not an inconvenience?
And how does this not break the expected delivery principle?

> If someone wants to talk to me, there is a willingness to initiate
> conversation that can overcome minor inconveniences for the sake of
> focus.

That willingness gets the mail typed in the first place.  You're assuming
that you have nothing to gain from anyone who isn't willing to sacrifice
to get information to you.

> I don't want to be distracted by junk coming through.

Then use good filters and get some Ritalin... because your distraction
threshold is really low.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Apr 14 06:00:03 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Apr 14 06:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi set up pointers needed
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131945190.30658@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131503170.29876@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <407CA10E.7000607@linuxlink.com> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131945190.30658@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404140546520.16338@pecos.madboa.com>

On Tue, 13 Apr 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   The tools seem to be there. But, I don't know how to configure
> wlan. What's a MIB, WEP and the other acronyms? How do I answer
> config file questions when I've no idea what it is I should want?

Try the iwconfig(8) man page.

For quick and dirty, try

1. Insert the pcmcia card.

2. Run iwconfig without any arguments. Does the new device show up?
   Here things get tricky. The name of the device might be eth1, or
   wlan0, or something else entirely. If you don't have iwconfig, try
   "cat /proc/net/wireless" instead.

3. If the device doesn't show up, tail /var/log/messages to see if
   there are any "I'm frustrated" messages from your hotplug setup.

   If that isn't revealing, then you'll need to do some Googling to
   find out what kernel module supports your card. If it's, say, the
   very common orinoco_cs module, then do "modprobe orinoco_cs" and
   then repeat step 2 to see if anything has happened.

4. I don't know how Slackware does network configuration, but you'll
   almost certainly want to set up the wireless interface to use DHCP.
   Very few people hard-wire their wireless addresses.

Does any of that help?

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

On Wed, 14 Apr 2004, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> 1. Insert the pcmcia card.

  Did this prior to booting.

> 2. Run iwconfig without any arguments. Does the new device show up?
>    Here things get tricky. The name of the device might be eth1, or
>    wlan0, or something else entirely. If you don't have iwconfig, try
>    "cat /proc/net/wireless" instead.

  Response to 'iwconfig' is that neither lo nor eth0 have any wireless
extensions. Results of 'cat /proc/net/wirelsss' is a set of headers with
nothing in the rows below.

> 3. If the device doesn't show up, tail /var/log/messages to see if
>    there are any "I'm frustrated" messages from your hotplug setup.

  No, nothing there.

>    If that isn't revealing, then you'll need to do some Googling to
>    find out what kernel module supports your card. If it's, say, the
>    very common orinoco_cs module, then do "modprobe orinoco_cs" and
>    then repeat step 2 to see if anything has happened.

  Here's where it gets interesting. According to one site, the 3CRWE154G72
card uses the Prism GT chipset (found on a Prism54 driver Web page). Details
provided include the type as 'cardbus', the subsystem ID and vendor device
both as 10b7:6001, the default PCI ID as 1260:3890 and the chipset as
'ISL3890'. The only driver I can find there is a patch for the 2.4.25
kernel; I run the 2.4.24 kernel.

  On another Web site, the ISL 3890 chip set is associated with the Prism
Duette chip set rather than the GT flavor. This site (from Rutgers U.) has
not been updated since last September. It has a driver identified only by
version number. The latest is 1.0.4.3.

  When I search the system for a prism2_cs module, one shows up for both the
2.4.20 and 2.4.22 kernels, but none for the 2.4.24 kernel.

> 4. I don't know how Slackware does network configuration, but you'll
>    almost certainly want to set up the wireless interface to use DHCP.
>    Very few people hard-wire their wireless addresses.

  That's fine by me. I assume that -- eventually -- I'll use dhcpcd to get a
dynamic, wireless IP address as I now use dhcpcd to get a dynamic address
when I plug into the ethernet port in the hotel.

> Does any of that help?

  Well, ... I have more data on the card and a more focused sense of
confusion. :-)

Thanks, Paul!

From ali at axian.com  Wed Apr 14 08:03:01 2004
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Wed Apr 14 08:03:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla development?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404131916190.20102-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404131916190.20102-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <20040414150202.GA10214@zaphod.axian.com>

On Tue, Apr 13, 2004 at 07:17:42PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Has anyone here done any application development using Mozilla and XUL?

Yes.  The first bit I did was just as a training exercise.  The results
are now published at 

	http://www.hevanet.com/acorbin/xul/top.xul

I also did a couple of paying projects, writing GUIs for kiosks.
> 
> Pros?  

'Tis cool.  We were replacing GUIs written in html, and XUL is much more
powerful.  It has a bunch of widgets available and it's easy to lay out.
It's faster than html, mostly because you can change and redraw a single
component instead of refreshing the whole screen.  And it's designed to
work nicely with stylesheets and localization.

A big selling point is its cross-platform-ness.  Provided that mozilla
is installed on the machine, any XUL GUI will work anywhere.

> Cons?

It's still fairly new.  It's not as mature as other widget sets, such
as gtk or qt.

It's still fairly new.  Printed documentation is either non-existant
or hopelessly out-of-date.  I bought the O'Reilly book for the overview,
but learned most of the details from the web, from:

http://www.xulplanet.com/
http://www.mozilla.org/projects/xul/
http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&group=netscape.public.dev.xul
http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&group=netscape.public.mozilla.xpfe
http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&group=netscape.public.mozilla.xpcom

(This was a year or more ago.  There might be better docs now.)
	
You pretty much have to learn javascript to provide the functionality.
Theoretically, you could use a different scripting language, but so far
everything (like all of mozilla) has been done in javascript.

Ali

To the PLUG list, and to Personal Telco:

The questions about properly setting up Wifi on Linux keep reappearing
on the PLUG list.  This smells like opportunity!

Some of us have crippled wifi setups, others have trouble even getting
started.  I propose that we set up a one-time all-day event, perhaps in
conjunction with the Saturday linux clinic, or perhaps some other time
or place, where we can bring laptops and Wifi cards and access points and
other gear and get it all properly set up and security tested.  If should
be far enough in the future that (1) we can plan, and (2) attendees can
make purchases, do their reading, and prepare their systems based on that
plan.  Perhaps late June?  I'd like to get this done before vacation
season and OSCON.

We may also want to talk about setting up Linux laptops for general
secure road warrioring (modem/CAT5/Wifi).

Does anyone consider themselves capable enough in Linux WiFi setup to
help specify some prerequisites?  How many people are interested in
participating as teachers/helpers/pupils/blackhats?  

Keith

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Apr 14 09:19:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Apr 14 09:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi set up pointers needed
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404140650520.441@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131503170.29876@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <407CA10E.7000607@linuxlink.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404131945190.30658@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404140546520.16338@pecos.madboa.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404140650520.441@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1081959496.1742.25.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2004-04-14 at 07:03, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Here's where it gets interesting. According to one site, the 3CRWE154G72
> card uses the Prism GT chipset (found on a Prism54 driver Web page). Details
> provided include the type as 'cardbus', the subsystem ID and vendor device
> both as 10b7:6001, the default PCI ID as 1260:3890 and the chipset as
> 'ISL3890'. The only driver I can find there is a patch for the 2.4.25
> kernel; I run the 2.4.24 kernel.
> 
>   On another Web site, the ISL 3890 chip set is associated with the Prism
> Duette chip set rather than the GT flavor. This site (from Rutgers U.) has
> not been updated since last September. It has a driver identified only by
> version number. The latest is 1.0.4.3.
> 
>   When I search the system for a prism2_cs module, one shows up for both the
> 2.4.20 and 2.4.22 kernels, but none for the 2.4.24 kernel.

I think you should try to install the hostap drivers
(http://hostap.epitest.fi/), they will use your kernel headers to make a
module for your specific kernel.  The documentation is pretty good and
compiling the modules is fairly straight forward.  They are also much
more flexible than the orinoco drivers.  Hostap supports almost all of
the wireless extensions and with these drivers, you can also turn your
laptop into an access point.

I also don't know how Slackware configures the network interfaces, but
for the initial testing, I recommend using a static IP address, that way
you don't have to wait around for the DHCP to time out before the
interface comes up.

You should also look into wireless sniffing tools like Wellenrieter or
Kismet, both support the prism chipset, but Wellenrieter seems to run
better with the hostap drivers.  Wavelan is the best tool I've seen for
console monitoring of the wireless signal.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree
