I have a Dell Inspiron 5100.  I looked at LinuxCertified Inc. but 
decided not to
buy because the  price was atrocious for a machine where your supposedly
saving on not getting a Windows license.  The other problem is credentials,
who are these guys anyways?  I called them, but I wasn't impressed enough
to move away from name brands, namely Dell.  I'm not happy with my Dell
though, they could have put in a decent bios.  Expecting it to work 
really well,
I'm dissapointed.  It works if you don't mind: no battery life 
indicator, Linux
thinking there are six cd/dvd drives, shutdown being the only feature that
Linux supports between power management and acpi, and the uncanny
lockups I'm getting with xmms.  It's also heavy, 7 lbs.  An iBook might 
be a
good idea if you don't have to have a PC.

Recommendations are to put Debian on my laptop.  I'm running Redhat 9
because I don't know if Maple will work under Debian.  The few special
keys on it will be really handy if I can get lineakd to work. 
 Apparently it's
no problem under Debian, but it refuses to configure under Redhat.  The
battery life is short too, two and a half hours to three max.

The whole cost of the Inspiron 5100 though is only $1049 with the $50
screen upgrade you probably don't want to go without in general.  
Evidently for the 2.4.6 and 2.6.4 kernels there are bios patches for this
machine, but I haven't been able to get either kernel configured to  know
if the patches work.  For the cost of XP Pro on the Inspiron 5100 and
the extra good LCD screen, you're still cheaper than a Linux Certified
box without Windows.  

Buying used is risky, but you can get Thinkpads from various
places.  I think you'll find that the price is wrong though.
Surprisingly when I called IBM, the woman was extremely
rude about running any non Windows OS or getting one
without an OS preinstalled.  I'd like to see an open design
hardware laptop to run Linux on, but it appears impossible
to establish the necessary economy of scale where a lot of
people struggle with having to run this or that on a Microsoft
supported Windows PC.  Our education systems are not
generally friendly to Windows PC alternatives.

At least Dell doesn't rip your head off when you tell me you
want to run Linux.  The Inspiron is supposed to be as close to
a normal P4 in a laptop form factor as possible, so why in the
heck is the bios messed up?  Well, just type Inspiron 5100
Linux in google.  I'm typing on it now so it works, though
the cursor likes to bounce occasionally.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Apr 15 01:49:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Apr 15 01:49:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Directory Directive
In-Reply-To: <1081993827.407dea636e462@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1081993827.407dea636e462@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404150138330.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

(Assuming Apache 1.3)

On Wed, 14 Apr 2004 dan at fiddlers-green.info wrote:
> I'm trying to limit access to a logs directory on my webserver, and I
> can't seem to get the following to work:
>
> <Directory /var/webconfig/htdocs/reports/data>
>     Options Indexes FollowSymLinks
>     order deny,allow

>From the documentation under "Configuration Files":
  Directives in the configuration files are case-insensitive, but
  arguments to directives are often case sensitive.

So perhaps you would like that to read "order Deny,Allow" or, for
readability, "Order Deny,Allow".

>     deny from all
>     allow from 192.168.2.*

This isn't shell expansion or regex, so your * means nothing.  The syntax
is flexible, but they didn't bother to put in support for every imaginable
scheme of shorthand.

A full or partial domain name
An IP address
A partial IP address
A network/mask pair
A network/bit CIDR spec

So you want one of the following three:
Allow from 192.168.2
Allow from 192.168.2.0/255.255.255.0
Allow from 192.168.2.0/24

(I ignored the obvious and impractical explicit lists of each subset.)

> Unfortunately everyone still gets denied access. I'm under the
> impression if I remove the "deny from all" statement, then anyone will
> get access. I would like to give access to only my local subnet.

Clear as vodka, sir.  Fix that and see.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Apr 15 01:54:01 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Apr 15 01:54:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Directory Directive
In-Reply-To: <407DF8C5.2040501@frenetic.com>
References: <1081993827.407dea636e462@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
 <407DF8C5.2040501@frenetic.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404150149340.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 14 Apr 2004, Daniel Logghe wrote:
> Try:
> allow from 192.168.2.0/255.255.255.0

This is pretty pointless.  If you're going to use a netmask that ends with
zeros, you may as well just truncate the address.

Even if you don't like this admittedly nonstandard way of indicating a
subnet, you could at least use the CIDR notation that's going to be much
shorter and easier to read.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Apr 15 02:00:03 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Apr 15 02:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Directory Directive
In-Reply-To: <20040415030427.GA15688@edge>
References: <1081993827.407dea636e462@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
 <20040415030427.GA15688@edge>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404150156180.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 14 Apr 2004, Bill Barry wrote:
> That should be
> order allow,deny
> if you want deny to be the default. See
> http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_access.html#order

You're misreading that, Bill.

Allow,Deny with his Deny and Allow directives will result in everyone but
that subnet getting access.

Deny is the default if you don't have a Deny directive with that order.
That just means "Deny for all" is implied and doesn't need explicit
statement.

>From the site you cite:
  In the following example, all hosts in the apache.org domain are allowed
  access; all other hosts are denied access.

    Order Deny,Allow
    Deny from all
    Allow from apache.org

This is exactly what he wants and it uses the order he's indicated.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

 http://www.openlaw.org

> > order allow,deny
> > if you want deny to be the default. See
> > http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_access.html#order
> 
> You're misreading that, Bill.
> 
> Allow,Deny with his Deny and Allow directives will result in everyone but
> that subnet getting access.
> 
> Deny is the default if you don't have a Deny directive with that order.
> That just means "Deny for all" is implied and doesn't need explicit
> statement.
> 
> >From the site you cite:
>   In the following example, all hosts in the apache.org domain are allowed
>   access; all other hosts are denied access.
> 
>     Order Deny,Allow
>     Deny from all
>     Allow from apache.org
> 
> This is exactly what he wants and it uses the order he's indicated.
> 

Yes, I agree, that works . But from my reading this

   Order Allow, Deny
   Allow from apache.org

also works. Am I wrong here?

Bill Barry

Last nite about 10 pm I finally got a real live working linux install 
going.It was the Fedora core1 distro and after I tweaked the partitions 
a little it went onto my (new to me) IBM T21 laptop with no hassle other 
than the usual issues with recognizing the sound card.  I carefully read 
several articles about how to fix that but they were written in greek or 
urdu so I'll take them with me to the next newbie clinic and work on it 
there.  But I digress.

Having failed miserably to get Linux installed on my old IBM Aptiva, and 
my Toshiba 2545XCDT, I was wild with excitement.  I set up my email 
accounts in the Ximian Evolution email program and could only get mail 
from our MS Exchange server located on our network.  I launched Mozilla 
to check out the browsing and got the message:

"*SonicWALL Network Anti-Virus Software Required.*"

The antivirus software is McAfee and is automatically installed and updated by the sonicwall appliance.  No A/V, no internet.  I followed the click thru to the install link and discovered messages warning that MS IE 4.01 SP2 or better must be resident on my system.  There was also a plug in for Netscape users but I suspect its for the Windows version.

Have any of you encountered and conquored this issue?  Changing the server and anti-virus software for the entire office is probably not an available option.

I read it the same way Bill. The only difference is by default everyone will be
denied access in the example you cited. That's why they don't need the "Deny
from All" directive in the example on apache's website. In my setup I have "Deny
from All" which would then deny access to everyone, counteracting the default
access which is to allow everyone.

I've tried it both ways:
<Directory /var/webconfig/htdocs/reports/data>
    Options Indexes FollowSymLinks
    Order Allow,Deny
#    deny from all
    Allow From 192.168.2
</Directory>

and,

<Directory /var/webconfig/htdocs/reports/data>
    Options Indexes FollowSymLinks
    Order Deny,Allow
    deny from all
    Allow From 192.168.2
</Directory>

Both return a 403 when attempting to access a page that needs to read from the
reports/data directory. The only time it works is if I use Deny,Allow and
comment out the "Deny from All", which just means access is open to everyone
now. Since its the system stats and intrusion data reports on the gateway
server, that is probably bad security form.

Since its not taking either example above, there is something else that is
interfering with the directive. The directive is simple enough, which makes me
think I'm being stupid and missing something. I'm logged in as root into
webconfig, and it should be using that authentication when looking at the
directories. If it's using the server's process id, the server is allowed to
read or write to the directory as well.

Of course I can't be sure since ClarkConnect doesn't come out and state it, but
the webconfig server itself has got to be apache. The directives in the conf
file follow the apache conf file exactly. Although its possible they modified
the code, but it wouldn't make sense to me to ignore taking a specific ip
address/mask pair.

Dan H.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Apr 15 14:53:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Apr 15 14:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Apache Directory Directive
In-Reply-To: <1082053112.407ed1f866f2f@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1081993827.407dea636e462@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
 <20040415030427.GA15688@edge> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404150156180.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <20040415163759.GA16336@edge> <1082053112.407ed1f866f2f@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404151448360.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 15 Apr 2004 dan at fiddlers-green.info wrote:
> Quoting Bill Barry <barryb at proaxis.com>:
> > Yes, I agree, that works . But from my reading this
> >
> >    Order Allow, Deny
> >    Allow from apache.org
> >
> > also works. Am I wrong here?

No, you're not wrong.  That does also work.  However, my reading makes me
believe that
  Order Allow, Deny
  Allow from apache.org
  Deny from all

results in total denial from all.  That means that if he'd used
  Order Allow,Deny
he'd have ended up denying all as the Allow would have been overridden.

> <Directory /var/webconfig/htdocs/reports/data>
[snip]
> </Directory>
[snip]
> Both return a 403 when attempting to access a page that needs to read
> from the reports/data directory.

Perhaps there's more to this and we're missing the crucial bit.

Also, if you can tell us exactly what version of Apache you're using and
whether this is a global config or part of an .htaccess.

I'm also assuming that /var/webconfig/htdocs/ is set as the servers
DocumentRoot.  If that's not the case, we need to know exactly how the
directory is being referenced in the http document space.

J.

From griffint at pobox.com  Thu Apr 15 16:18:01 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Thu Apr 15 16:18:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Home directory on USB drive
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404151422100.27603-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404151422100.27603-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <200404151617.51409.griffint@pobox.com>

On Thursday 15 April 2004 2:25 pm, Matt Alexander wrote:
> In Knoppix, I can have my USB thumbdrive be my home directory by going
> through a setup wizard in Knoppix and giving this option at the boot
> prompt:
>
> home=scan
>
> Does anyone know how to do the same thing with other distros, like Fedora
> or Debian?
> Thanks,
> ~M
>
>
I wrote a Sys-V style init script to do this. It assumes that the USB drive
is already known by devlabel. If devlabel has created the symlink for the
USB drive then the script mounts it under /home (for a the user specified
in the config file). If devlabel didn't create the symlink then the script
assumes the drive is not plugged in and you get your regular /home.

Attached is the script (usbhome) and a sample config file (usbhome.conf).
It's been tested with fedora. It should work as-is with any redhat-ish distro,
and could be modified to work with pretty much anything else.

Terry
-------------- next part --------------

Type: application/x-shellscript

-------------- next part --------------
DEVICE=/dev/usbhd
MOUNTPOINT=/home/griffint
FSTYPE=ext2

Does being your new best friend come with beer?

The knoppix.img part shouldn't be too hard to handle. There would just need
to be some extra logic in the script (maybe triggered by extra info in the
config file) to mount knoppix.img as a loopback device.

Auto-detection of knoppix.img is not out of the question either. It could
first mount the USB device at the specified /home location. If there's no
knoppix.img file then it's done. If there is a knoppix.img file, remount the
USB device to some temp directory, and then mount knoppix.img under /home.
It would have to be careful to unmount things in the right order when
stopping the service.

As for AES, I just got a catalog in the mail from them today (Amateur
Electronic Supply). And that's how much I know about AES in Linux.

Terry

On Thu, 2004-04-15 at 14:23, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Thu, 15 Apr 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > Does anyone have recommendations for a way to access a file server
> > through a web browser (using https)?  I've looked at the
> > phpGroupWare Filemanager module and it looks like a possibility, but
> > I wanted to see what others have had good experience with.
> 
> If read-only access is good enough, then WebDAV with Apache will do
> the trick.

WebDAV can also make modifications, but it's a little bit difficult to
set up. Once you have a user using WebDAV, you're recommended to not use
anything else to access the files. But if this is OK and you get it set
up right, it is easy to access from Windows: Use the native "Web
Folders" functionality.

Run WebDAV over https to make it secure.

Evan

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Thu Apr 15 21:16:01 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Thu Apr 15 21:16:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Quick Apache Re-write Rule
In-Reply-To: <1082052744.8235.211.camel@localhost>
References: <1082052744.8235.211.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <1082088938.3807.15.camel@timmy>

On Thu, 2004-04-15 at 11:12, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> All,
> 
> Would anyone provide me with a quick "re-write rule" for the
> following:
> 
>                                            
> ___________                                  ____________
> www.virtualdomain.com  ----> | main server |  ----> rewrite rule  
> ---> | inside server |  
>                                           
> ---------------------                                 
> ---------------------
> 
> So if a request comes in for www.serverb.com it is forwarded by
> www.servera.com (via vhosts.conf) to www.serverb.com.

I'll rephrase your problem to make sure I'm understanding it correctly.

You have servera.com on the internet. serverb.com resolves to the same
IP address as servera.com. You want content on therealserverb.com to be
served when going to serverb.com.

That is easy. Load mod_proxy and put this on servera.com:

<VirtualHost *>
   ServerName serverb.com

   ProxyPass / http://therealserverb.com/
</VirtualHost>

You might run into some trouble with self-referencing urls. To fix that,
add a line to /etc/hosts on servera.com that makes serverb.com resolve
to the same address as therealserverb.com.

I hope I'm making sense.

Evan




From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Thu Apr 15 21:26:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Thu Apr 15 21:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Debian lost NIC
In-Reply-To: <49996.209.210.31.11.1082087917.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <49996.209.210.31.11.1082087917.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <1082089495.32517.22.camel@timmy>

On Thu, 2004-04-15 at 20:58, Steven Raymond wrote:
> 1)  Today I rebooted for no important reason and now the system doesn't
> seem to recognize the NIC any longer.  It worked fine for a week or more
> before the reboot.  Doing /sbin/ifconfig shows only the loopback
> interface.  Am stumped.  What can I do to fix it?

Try ifconfig eth0 to see if the hardware is recognized. If you don't see
an error message, try ifup eth0 or /etc/init.d/networking start to get a
dhcp address on the interface.

> 2)  Sound worke the first time I logged on as root several days ago.
> Immediately thereafter I logged in as a regular user and got a message
> about sound being unable to load (I suppose the error message would be
> useful?  where can I find it, after clicking "ok"?).  I figured not being
> root had something to do with it.  Any advice on how to fix sound?

I assume you're using alsa. Log in as root, type alsamixer to adjust the
volumes, type aplay somewavfile.wav to test that you can actually play.
Then check the permissions on /dev/dsp so you can play sounds as a user.

> 4)  I really like apt-get.  Was able to install x-chat and Shockwave flash
> pretty easy.  What's the best way to determine the name of the package if
> you don't know the full name already?  Someone suggested "apt-cache search
> blah"- is that the best way to search?

Yes. It even supports regexes.

> 5)  In my /etc/apt/sources.list, I have a "updates main" and "testing
> main".  Are there any more useful source lists to consider?

All I have in my testing box's sources.list is this:

deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ testing main  contrib
deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ testing main  contrib

> Thanks!

You're welcome!

Evan

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Apr 15 22:15:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Apr 15 22:15:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Debian lost NIC
In-Reply-To: <50116.209.210.31.11.1082091937.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

      <1082089495.32517.22.camel@timmy> <50116.209.210.31.11.1082091937.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

On Thu, 15 Apr 2004, Steven Raymond wrote:
> "eth0: error fetching interface information: Device not found"
>
> :( Need to mess with modules or something now?

Yeah.

But it should be easy.

Run modconf and go down to drivers/net and see if you can't find your NIC
on the list there.  If you don't know which module to use, ask or hit
google.

That should really be that.

You'll want to make sure that the eth0 section in /etc/network/interfaces
is correct.  It has nothing to do with hardware, of course, but it will
tell you if the interface will be configured correctly when it does,
eventually, come up.

J.

From drl at drloree.com  Thu Apr 15 22:17:01 2004

On Thu, 2004-04-15 at 20:58, Steven Raymond wrote:
> So after reading the recent thread about Debian, I installed Sarge netinst
> beta 3 onto my spare hard drive and without too much trouble (compared to
> Gentoo ;) was able to get it installed and working, X even.
> 
> 1)  Today I rebooted for no important reason and now the system doesn't
> seem to recognize the NIC any longer.  It worked fine for a week or more
> before the reboot.  Doing /sbin/ifconfig shows only the loopback
> interface.  Am stumped.  What can I do to fix it?

First look through /var/log/syslog to see if the kernel tried to do
anything with it.  If it did, there should be some clues as to why it
isn't working.  If not, you probably need to load the module for the
card, (lspci should give some clues if you don't know which module to
load) then run ifup eth0 to get it running.  To have the system load it
on the next reboot, just add the module to /etc/modules.
> 
> 2)  Sound worke the first time I logged on as root several days ago.
> Immediately thereafter I logged in as a regular user and got a message
> about sound being unable to load (I suppose the error message would be
> useful?  where can I find it, after clicking "ok"?).  I figured not being
> root had something to do with it.  Any advice on how to fix sound?

Add the regular user to the audio group.
> 
> 3)  KDE is the default (window manager?) environment.  I believe that
> gnome is also installed.  Can I easily switch between the two?  How does
> one do so when launching startx from the CLI?

Edit ~/.xsession to start the window manager, or desktop environment of
your choice.
> 
> 4)  I really like apt-get.  Was able to install x-chat and Shockwave flash
> pretty easy.  What's the best way to determine the name of the package if
> you don't know the full name already?  Someone suggested "apt-cache search
> blah"- is that the best way to search?

I don't use it to install packages, but gnome-apt has a pretty good
search function, it searches the package descriptions too (like most
debian packages, it will run under any window manager, not just inside
Gnome).
> 
> 5)  In my /etc/apt/sources.list, I have a "updates main" and "testing
> main".  Are there any more useful source lists to consider?

"testing main non-free contrib" will open up a whole new world.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Thu Apr 15 22:27:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Thu Apr 15 22:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] accessing a file server securely through a web browser
In-Reply-To: <1082091205.1220.43.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404151426030.27603-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
	 <1082091205.1220.43.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <1082093179.3811.27.camel@timmy>

On Thu, 2004-04-15 at 21:53, Derek Loree wrote:
> On Thu, 2004-04-15 at 14:26, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > On Thu, 15 Apr 2004, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > 
> > > On Thu, 15 Apr 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > > 
> > > > Does anyone have recommendations for a way to access a file server
> > > > through a web browser (using https)?  I've looked at the
> > > > phpGroupWare Filemanager module and it looks like a possibility, but
> > > > I wanted to see what others have had good experience with.
> > > 
> > > If read-only access is good enough, then WebDAV with Apache will do
> > > the trick.
> > 
> > Users need to be able to download files, make changes, and then upload
> > them back later.
> 
> WebDAV (known as Internet Folders in Redmond) can have write access in
> exactly that manner.  Use Apache-ssl to encrypt and Apache Access
> control to allow only the users you specify.

I'm doing just this for myself, so I just figured out a mod_rewrite
setup that will make that easy for an unlimited number of users:

    <Location /webdav>
        DAV on

        AuthType Basic
        AuthName "secure area"
        AuthUserFile /var/www/dav-users
        Require valid-user

        Options -Indexes

        ForceType text/plain
    </Location>
    RewriteEngine on
    RewriteRule /webdav/(.*) /home/%{LA-U:REMOTE_USER}/public_html/$1

You can even use mod_auth_pam to authenticate through the normal UNIX
files or whatever auth mechanism PAM supports (rather than an htpasswd
file, as show above). If you use shadow files, the webserver will need
to read /etc/shadow. 

Hope this is useful to someone.

Evan




From barryb at proaxis.com  Fri Apr 16 05:30:03 2004
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Fri Apr 16 05:30:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba printer "access denied"
In-Reply-To: <86brlt7vrp.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86brlt7vrp.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20040416122944.GA20043@edge>

On Wed, Apr 14, 2004 at 08:41:30PM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> Recently, my boss has reported that he can no longer (for how long,
> who knows) kill print jobs from Windows 2k.  I was previous running
> 2.2.7a, just upgraded to 3.0.2a, same thing.  He can print, but under
> Settings/Printers sees the big "Access denied, mumble-mumble" field
> after each printer.  When I am logged on, I do have access.  The
> printer section of my smb.conf looks like this:
> 
> [printers]
>         path = /tmp
>         printable = Yes
>         print command = /scripts/lpd/printThenDelete %p %s
>         lpq command = /usr/bin/lpq -P %p
>         lprm command = /usr/bin/lprm -P %p %j
>         browseable = No
> 
> Does anyone know what is broken?  
> 

Maybe lprm is trying to remove jobs for the wrong user.
If you are using LPRng, there is a -Uuser option for lprm
that can correct this.
This is discussed in part 6 of
http://www.lprng.com/LPRng-Reference-Multipart/smb.htm
Also you might try adding a -a to the lprm command so
that it removes files for all users for which it has 
permission. That said, I can't get the similar thing
to work for cups either. I can print fine but not
purge the print jobs.

Bill Barry

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Apr 16 09:10:04 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 16 09:10:04 2004
Subject: [PLUG] accessing a file server securely through a web browser
In-Reply-To: <1082091205.1220.43.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404151426030.27603-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
 <1082091205.1220.43.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404160905540.16338@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 15 Apr 2004, Derek Loree wrote:

> WebDAV (known as Internet Folders in Redmond) can have write access
> in exactly that manner.  Use Apache-ssl to encrypt and Apache Access
> control to allow only the users you specify.

I can't speak for IIS's implementation of WebDAV, but on Apache, all
file ops are carried out under httpd's uid and gid. Apache manages all
authentication and authorization; the underlying filesystem doesn't
know a thing.

So afaik a WebDAV filesystem needs to have one and only one entry
point: Apache. You can't mix and match regular filesystem access with
WebDAV.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Apr 16 11:36:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Apr 16 11:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Wifi Clinic?
Message-ID: <20040416183438.GA11779@gate.kl-ic.com>

I suggested a Linux Wifi clinic.  The response has been great. 

Dan Haskell <danh at fork.com> writes:
> You are very welcome to do this at PLUG's Linux Clinic. While Clinics are
> usually only half-day events (1-5pm), we might be able to extend that. I
> would need to talk to the kind folks at Riverdale before committing it.
>
> May or June would work fine for us. Just remember that there is no Clinic
> this Month (April 2004).

Them's beautiful words, Dan!  Let's shoot for Saturday May 15, starting
as early as Riverdale will permit (Or 9am, let's keep this sane ...).
Does Riverdale already have wifi?  We may need to temporarily turn it
off to test the association of other access points;  maybe not, I will
defer to the able folk at Portland Personal Telco for their approach to
that.  Something to find out about.

I will come back from Linuxfest Sunday evening, brimming with ideas,
mostly about how we can make this manageable and on-task.   Normally,
I would allow another month to prepare, but so many folks have stepped
up with offers of help that it looks like we can pull this thing off
in less than a month.

I think the first thing to think about is the range of wifi solutions
we want to try to support for that first saturday, or encourage people
to explore.  B only? or G too?  Just laptops and WAPs, or PCI card
solutions, too?  Antenna fiddles, setting up gaming networks, and
setting up full Personaltelco sites, may be too ambitious for the
first Linux Wifi Clinic.  So is setting up Windoze servers (though
Windoze clients might be OK).

The trick will be keeping this practical and success-oriented, though with
good teachers we can take on a lot of the harder stuff.  The main thing
is to make sure we can put in the effort necessary to debug some nasty
problems on some snakepit machines, rather than focus on taking the
A class setups into the stratosphere.  The Personal Telco folks are really
good at the A class stuff, but that can be accomplished at other times.
I want to focus on helping newbies, cleaning up snakepit machines, and
on road-warrior security and ease-of-use.

Pupils:  
Show up early.  Your machines may be snakepits and take a long time to
set right.  If we do manage to teach you to set up your machines right,
plan on taking time after to help others.  In medical school, the rule
is "learn one, do one, teach one" and that should apply here.

Hardware:
I am fond of separate ethernet-connected WAPs (the Linksys BEFW11S4's
are cheap and damned easy to set up, and can be mounted where the
radio needs to be, not on the back of a metal case) but a Soekris
solution would be fun to learn about, too!  PCMCIA card-wise,
we should steer clear of the cheap Fry's card du jour, and go for
PRISM chipsets (and teach people how to tell the difference).  Before
he left town, Lonnie Wormley of Invictus Networks set me up with an
excellent Senao 2511CD 200mW card with external antenna for $100;
folks that do not already have PCMCIA cards should consider that one. 
I understand there are alpha drivers for Atheros and some other
chipsets, but some wifi cards are very difficult to support under
Linux.  Closed-source drivers are available for the built-in CISCO
laptop wifi solution.  Seattle Wireless has a good list of cards,
IIRC.   Bottom line:  we might be able to help with the marginal stuff,
but if you have cheap driverless oddball gear, plan on replacing it 
before May 15.  

Software:
I would like pupils to show up prepared (some reading done, OS already
installed on backed-up machines, CD drives available, all the hardware
researched and purchased), the helpers and teachers set up with
downloaded software on CDs, and the blackhats ready with penetration
tools.  We will not have time for WEP exploits (that usually takes
hours of packets) but there will still be plenty of other network
and firewall vulnerabilities to test for.  I would like to support the
common distros, so it would help to have folks who understand networking
for Debian/Knoppix, Redhat/Fedora, SUSE, and other distros.

Drivers:
I tried the PRISM wlan drivers for a few months, but switched to the
host-ap drivers.  The setup that comes with Knoppix is very good, too.
If someone else steps up ready to support Atheros or other chipsets,
volunteer, and we can support those, too.

Vendors:  It would be nice if everyone came with the correct hardware,
but some newbie will inevitably show up with a Fry's nine dollar special
5mW PCMCIA card based on some obscure Bulgarian chipset;  a few low-end
and high-end PRISM cards might find willing buyers.  Newbies:  bring
your checkbook.

PLUGgers:  Look over the Portland Personal Telco website 
( http://www.personaltelco.net ) for lots of great ideas.  These are
an amazing group of people, and worth joining and helping.  After we
do a linux WIFI clinic, it would be nice to help them with a LINUX wifi
clinic, so they can escape Windoze and the Blue Screen of Hell.

Again, more exploration after Linuxfest. 

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From m at phxlinux.org  Fri Apr 16 11:41:02 2004
From: m at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri Apr 16 11:41:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Home directory on USB drive (resolved)
In-Reply-To: <200404151802.33041.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404161007510.30051-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

On Thursday 15 April 2004 2:25 pm, Matt Alexander wrote:

> In Knoppix, I can have my USB thumbdrive be my home directory by going
> through a setup wizard in Knoppix and giving this option at the boot
> prompt:
>
> home=scan
>
> Does anyone know how to do the same thing with other distros, like
> Fedora or Debian?
> Thanks,
> ~M

I love Linux!!  I recompiled my kernel after patching with loop-AES:
http://loop-aes.sourceforge.net

Next, I patched linux-utils with loop-AES and rebuilt "losetup" to support
256-bit AES.

Now I can mount my Knoppix home directory:

mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/usb 
losetup -e aes256 /dev/loop0 /mnt/usb/knoppix.img
mount /dev/loop0 /home/myhomedirhere

I then modified /etc/rc.d/rc.sysinit (Fedora) to do this during boot.
~M

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Apr 16 13:00:03 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Apr 16 13:00:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] recovery, fried MB
In-Reply-To: <E1BEYJm-0004hy-00@smtp.perfora.net>
References: <E1BEYJm-0004hy-00@smtp.perfora.net>
Message-ID: <1082145563.6075.34.camel@localhost>

On Fri, 2004-04-16 at 11:42, theo at portlandpictureframe.com wrote:

> I think the data is untouched. Is it possible to just get a new MB/proc
> and plug everything in, cast a spell or two, pray to the dead Linux
> ghurus and have everything boot and be as it was?
> 
> I don't expect so...

One of the nice things about Linux's modularity *is* the general ability
to just drop in replacement hardware, even if it isn't necessarily
horribly similar to the hardware being replaced.  You should be able to
drop in a new motherboard, processor, and whatever else is dead, fire it
up, and be good to go.  You may need to adjust configuration files and
the like for the hardware, depending on how much (and how) hardware
detection the fancy hat OS does.

> 1. What is my best recovery plan? I will have to buy a new MB/proc or
> use something I have lying around.

Plug in the new hardware, hit the power button, watch the fun messages
that go scrolling by your screen.  Fix what is broke.  :-)

> I planned for disk failure and power failure but not this :/
> 2. Is there a good way to manage this swapping of MB? What about if I
> want to switch to a PIII?

Plug 'er in.  Make sure the motherboard, RAM, and CPU are all
compatible.  Most boards today use DDR.  Drives and case should be good
to go.  If it's an old board you're replacing, with an AGP video card,
you may need a new video card, too (if it doesn't fit, do NOT force
it).  PCI cards should be good to go.  Make sure your PSU is capable of
powering the new board/CPU properly (a 200W PSU may have been fine for
an old Athlon 550, but won't power an Athlon XP 2400+ very nicely).

> UGH!! My hardware router also bit it last night. I think one of Bill
> Gates' imps was haunting my house yesterday!

Or a lightning strike?

Rob

> > My home server
> > Fedora 1
> > kernal raid mirror 2 IDE 160 gb
> > Fried MB/proc (MSI K7? / AMD 1700XP)
> 
> The only issue I see is hardware related:
> 
> CPU:  Athlons sometime require "noathlon" in the kernel parameters. 
> This can also effect some drivers, alsa being one of them.
> 
> Video:  Something should work.
> 
> Once you get a login, merely running redhat-config-* should be enough to
> fix the hardware differences.

Actually most of the important ones will be caught by kudzu at boot time.

The only difficulty is if he changes video cards and has the default run 
level set to 5.  (i.e. booting into X.)  To fix that you have to boot in 
single user mode and change the runlevel to something sane, like 3. (DON'T 
set it to 6.  Double-plus ungood.) I don't believe kudzu fixes a change in 
videocards correctly in X.

AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> wrote:

> On Sun, 2004-04-11 at 12:20, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> 
> > Different codecs have different bandwidth requirements.  G.723.1 is 
> > one of the lowest with around 7-8kbps.  G.729 is better quality but a 
> > little higher bandwidth.  About 12kpbs IIRC.  This is just for the 
> > codec audio stream, not other overhead!
> 
> What's a kpbs?
> 
> I'm sure it isn't Kilobits per second, as 12k really isn't very much
> bandwidth, in the grand scheme of things.  Guess I could host a lot of
> those on my 512/256 slow-ass DSL.
> 

It is kilobits per second.  A typical voice channel would be 8 bit u-law
or a-law samples at 8 kHz.  That gives 64 kbps.  With 8 to 1 compression
that puts it in the realm of Kyle's numbers.  If you could tolerate LPC
compression, you could get 2.4 kbps.

galen

> with an SMTP 550 error:
>
>   5.7.1 message was identified as junk mail

  I used to reject 'em all with a 550 error message that was a coded rule.
That way I could fix false positives when folks told me about them. Now, I'm
discarding all multi-word rules because I've not yet seen a false positive
on them.

  When I asked on the postfix mail list about guidelines for electing
'discard' versus 'reject' I was told there no such guidelines. So, after a
few years rejecting 'em I'm now discarding 'em. Don't know if it makes any
difference.

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Apr 16 14:35:02 2004
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri Apr 16 14:35:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] VoIP on DSL?
In-Reply-To: <1082149352.6068.40.camel@localhost>
References: <200404111855.i3BIttD10497@box002.ultravolt.net> <200404111220.53622.kyle@silverbeach.net> <1082149352.6068.40.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <200404161434.21135.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Friday 16 April 2004 14:02, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Sun, 2004-04-11 at 12:20, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> > Different codecs have different bandwidth requirements.  G.723.1
> > is one of the lowest with around 7-8kbps.  G.729 is better
> > quality but a little higher bandwidth.  About 12kpbs IIRC.  This
> > is just for the codec audio stream, not other overhead!
>
> What's a kpbs?
>
> I'm sure it isn't Kilobits per second, as 12k really isn't very
> much bandwidth, in the grand scheme of things.  Guess I could host
> a lot of those on my 512/256 slow-ass DSL.

It is kilobits per second.  With a decent codec, voice doesn't take 
much bandwidth.  That's why all the backbone voice carriers are 
slowly rolling out VoIP onto existing fiber.  They can get a lot more 
conversations on a single fiber with a good codec than they can with 
uncompressed data.

Uncompressed voice uses 64kbps.  Compressed can do about 8-9 times 
better.  Seems funny that you should get such good compression until 
you realize a few things:

1) the human voice is in a very narrow frequency band.

2) the human voice can be modelled relatively well with a fairly small 
number of parameters.

3) around 30% of all the time in a conversation is dead silence.  This 
can be between words, between sentences, little audible pauses etc.

Given those three things, the bit rates look a lot more reasonable.  
Even with overhead for UDP/RTP etc. two conversations on a solid 28.8 
connection is possible.  The latency is ugly though :-P

Best,
Kyle

From john at meissen.org  Fri Apr 16 15:52:01 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Fri Apr 16 15:52:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Training a bayesian filter
In-Reply-To: <1082148647.6076.37.camel@localhost>
References: <1082148647.6076.37.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <48507.209.234.100.72.1082155890.squirrel@meissen.org>

AthlonRob said:
> When you say reject, you actually mean silently drop, right?
>
There's a difference between reject and bounce. You should never
generate new mail by bouncing the message. But rejecting it during
the SMTP handhake will let a legitimate sender know that their email
didn't get through. If you silently drop it then victims of false
positives will never know what happened to their message. It won't
make any difference with real spam... spammers ignore rejects anyway.

Once your system accepts the email, though, rejecting is pointless.
So if you're talking about SpamAssassin during local delivery,
that's different.

john-

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri Apr 16 22:02:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri Apr 16 22:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Real-life hardware comparison.
In-Reply-To: <20040417024102.20667.67940.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200404170501.i3H51SBK012701@m5p.com>

I keep hoping to replace my hardware, so I've been tracking hardware
capabilities.

> From: Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>
> I've got a really decent dual PIII motherboard and a gig of PC133 SDRAM
> but a single rather pathetic processor on the board.
> 
> I could just max out the motherboard with procs that fit.  I think the
> best I could do would be a pair of PIII 1.3GHz things and another gig of
> RAM.

Be careful, just because they use the same socket doesn't mean they'll
work together. I think it was the 1.13GHz P3 they changed one of the pins
and older motherboards wouldn't work; check whether the motherboard
officially supports the P3 1.3GHz processors.

> OR I could go with something on the middley-end of what's current (because
> I'll need new motherboard, power supply likely, as well as processors and
> memory).

Not all the recent motherboards require the P4 connector, though many
(including a number of the AMD ones) do. There are also some recent
boards that will work with vanilla SDRAM too. The ECS K7S boards have a
horrendous DOA rate, but if you avoid the DOA they're a very good board
(these are the ones Fry's offers every week bundled with an Athlon
2600+). This then comes to the next issue...

> Is the new fast bus stuff really that much faster?  Is it really
> worthwhile to have DDR memory and a single 2GHz processor over the
> maxed-out system I could have for much less money?

Well, increasing the memory bandwidth by a factor of two (bottom-end
modern board/133MHz+DDR) to six (high-end board/200MHz+DDR+dual channel)
helps in most cases.

> I guess the best my mobo will take are 1.4GHz.
> 
> And does 512K cache make a huge difference over 256k?

Everything helps. On the P3s and Athlons it helps, but not a horrendous
amount. Very different matter with the P4s though, on the P4 that extra
cache is absolutly *critical*. Also note that the P4s with 1MB cache are
the "Prescott" core whose performance is somewhat dubious...

In your case it sounds like you'd want a low-mid range Athlon. You can
get higher-clocked P4s for the money, but the Athlons are far better
performers (AMD's performance code numbers are /roughly/ accurate).

On Fri, 2004-04-16 at 09:09, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Thu, 15 Apr 2004, Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > WebDAV (known as Internet Folders in Redmond) can have write access
> > in exactly that manner.  Use Apache-ssl to encrypt and Apache Access
> > control to allow only the users you specify.
> 
> I can't speak for IIS's implementation of WebDAV, but on Apache, all
> file ops are carried out under httpd's uid and gid. Apache manages all
> authentication and authorization; the underlying filesystem doesn't
> know a thing.
> 
> So afaik a WebDAV filesystem needs to have one and only one entry
> point: Apache. You can't mix and match regular filesystem access with
> WebDAV.

Samba isn't exactly a regular filesystem, but it is capable of writing
files with a specific uid, independent of the uid of the actual user.  I
have set up systems that use both Samba and WebDAV to read and write the
same files.  Its not regular, but it is a mix.

Derek Loree

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Apr 16 23:42:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Fri Apr 16 23:42:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Real-life hardware comparison.

On Fri, 2004-04-16 at 22:01, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> I keep hoping to replace my hardware, so I've been tracking hardware
> capabilities.
 
I'm not too thrilled with P4 technology myself.  It seems a little
bleeding edge.  A good PIII is something to go ahead and bore out.  
I don't even have 1 Ghz PIII's, but I'm happy.  I have an
Athlon system I put together cheaply through E-Bay, I've been 
happy with it.  That was a super deal though.  I wonder if any of the
P4 enhancements work. I probably use the processor to get 
video performance if there aren't drivers that can take 
proper advantage of my video card.  Biggest disappointment is 
when incompatible parts are integrated.  Probably best to spend 
a little more money and get something that won't give you trouble 
or keep what you have.

A friend of my brother's who marked hard drives as bad found them
at Fry's.  They literally will sell garbage as new stuff there.
Seems Oregon has no law that states that new and refurbished/
repackaged goods have to be distinguished from each other.
Guess I take the same risk on E-Bay though, so it's fairly 
relative.

Another option is to cluster four old but solid Pentium III's
together, might be better than 1 Pentium 4.  Theoretically, if
you cluster AMD and Intel technology you should have all of
the best optimizations, but I don't know if clustering works
this way.  Apparently scheduling is a huge problem for cluster
performance.  One advantage of a cluster is many controllers 
to hook drives up to and places to add memory, assuming you 
b channel with fast enough cards that there isn't a network 
bottleneck.  With 10k cards and very short patch cables, that 
shouldn't be an issue.

Big thing is, you can theoretically using Linuxbios set up some
computing power really cheap.  I guess the kernel gets installed
into the bios itself, very fast boot.  You can set up one
machine with drives and network boot as many other motherboards
as needed for raw power.  I've heard of LTSP being used this way.
Mosix comes to mind too.

There was a Linux cluster at PSU before I left, that's when the
new building with all the glass was finished.  Have no idea how
anyone gets to find out anything about it, but it's there.  It's
a ridiculous number of computers in standard cases on shelves.
I wonder why they didn't go rack mount?  

     --  Michael C. Robinson

AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> writes:

> On Sun, 2004-04-11 at 08:52, plug.9.faster at spamgourmet.com wrote:
>
>> Because your spam is not the same as my spam. I host email for some
>> friends' domains, and I see the spam I reject for them and the spam I
>> reject for me. There is almost zero intersection, if you leave out the
>> fact that most of it is relayed through Asia or sent via
>> broadband-connected zombies.
>
> When you say reject, you actually mean silently drop, right?

No, because that breaks SMTP.  He means reject, as in, after DATA has
arrived, reject it at SMTP-time.  You can do this for more than just
spam, you should be doing this for virus-infected mail already (and
not sending bounce messages after accepting it like too many sites
do).

http://ursine.ca/article.pl?sid=04/04/11/1127234

-- 
Paul Johnson

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Sat Apr 17 08:15:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Sat Apr 17 08:15:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] umask
In-Reply-To: <40809900.2040606@brianquade.net>

Message-ID: <1082214873.3778.2.camel@timmy>

On Fri, 2004-04-16 at 19:40, Brian Quade wrote:
> I had a problem where my j2re would only run applications if I am logged 
> in as root.  I tried to find out how to fix it by searching the 
> Internet, but I discovered that a lot of people have this problem and 
> can not fix it.  I reported it to Sun as a bug and they told me it is a 
> usage error, probably my umask.  I can't find much info on umask other 
> than that it is a bash command.  Is it the same as file permissions (set 
> with chmod) or is it something else?  My umask for root is 0002 and my 
> umask for my other user is 0022.  What does this stuff mean?  And how do 
> I change it?

This is from my umask manpage. (for the C function)

The  umask  is  used  by  open(2)  to set initial file permissions on a
newly-created file.  Specifically, permissions in the umask are  turned
off  from  the  mode  argument  to open(2) (so, for example, the common
umask default value of 022 results in new files being created with per-
missions  0666  &  ~022  = 0644 = rw-r--r-- in the usual case where the
mode is specified as 0666).

I'm not telling you to RTFM: I don't think I fully understand that
paragraph myself. But it might make sense to you!

Evan

> > can not fix it.  I reported it to Sun as a bug and they told me it is a
> > usage error, probably my umask.  I can't find much info on umask other
> > than that it is a bash command.  Is it the same as file permissions (set
> > with chmod) or is it something else?  My umask for root is 0002 and my
> > umask for my other user is 0022.  What does this stuff mean?  And how do
> > I change it?
>
> This is from my umask manpage. (for the C function)
>
> The  umask  is  used  by  open(2)  to set initial file permissions on a
> newly-created file.  Specifically, permissions in the umask are  turned
> off  from  the  mode  argument  to open(2) (so, for example, the common
> umask default value of 022 results in new files being created with per-
> missions  0666  &  ~022  = 0644 = rw-r--r-- in the usual case where the
> mode is specified as 0666).
>
> I'm not telling you to RTFM: I don't think I fully understand that
> paragraph myself. But it might make sense to you!
>
> Evan
>

The umask command in bash has a "-S" switch which will display your current
umask setting in symbolic form instead of octal. This may help in
understanding what's going on. When setting a new umask value in bash, you
may specify it in octal or symbolic form.

It's a fairly recent thing for umask to be shown as four octal digits. For
a long time it was just three. The new digit on the front has a default
of zero, so 0022 is the same as 022. The extra digit is used for special
bits like the SUID and SGID.

Note that the symbolic representation is inverted from the octal
representation. So an octal umask of 022 is represented symbolically as
"u=rwx,g=rx,o=rx". The octal value says: These permission bits will *not*
be set for newly created files. The symbolic representation says: These
are the most permissive settings that will be given to newly created files.

Here's a general discussion of permissions:

http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/answers.php?action=viewarticle&artid=20

It doesn't talk about umask but it does explain the octal-represented
permission bits.

Be aware that if you change your umask, it only applies to the current
process (bash) and the processes it creates. If you want to change it for
your whole environment you should put a umask command in your login script,
then log out and back in.

Terry




From drl at drloree.com  Sat Apr 17 10:58:01 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Apr 17 10:58:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Real-life hardware comparison.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404162329050.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <200404170501.i3H51SBK012701@m5p.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404162329050.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1082224697.1220.170.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2004-04-16 at 23:31, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Fri, 16 Apr 2004, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > In your case it sounds like you'd want a low-mid range Athlon. You can
> > get higher-clocked P4s for the money, but the Athlons are far better
> > performers (AMD's performance code numbers are /roughly/ accurate).
> 
> But will a single "low-mid range Athlon" outpace my dual PIIIs?

This depends on what you are doing, what chipset you get to run it, and
the speed of the memory.  It will certainly compile a kernel faster (if
that is the only task running), but may not hold up under many heavy
tasks.  Remember, you can't split a task across two processors, and
faster memory is always a good thing.  

Disk I/O speed is something else to consider, SATA, when coupled to the
right drive (high rpm, large cache), is going to be much faster than the
UDMA33 your old motherboard is capable of doing and less expensive than
SCSI.

Beware that AMD has still not implemented any kind of thermal
protection, the motherboard is still responsible for shutting down an
overheated processor.  However, the nVidia chipset looks like an
impressive performer. 

Sorry, there is no easy answer to your questions.

Derek Loree




From griffint at pobox.com  Sat Apr 17 11:07:02 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Sat Apr 17 11:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Of Modules and Men
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404171037330.24561@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404171037330.24561@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200404171106.02289.griffint@pobox.com>

On Saturday 17 April 2004 10:41 am, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I'm curious about this: in /etc/modules.conf there is an alias:
> 	alias wlan0 prism2_cs.o
> but lsmod shows the driver as Prism54 and ifconfig -a (or iwconfig) shows
> the interface as eth1. Why the discrepancies?
>
>   On a similar note, now that I resolved the problem(s) making and
> installing hostap_cs.o, is there a relatively simple way to swap between
> the two interfaces? Might there be advantages in doing so?
>

By default the module name (shown by lsmod) is the same as the the module's
file name (without the .o) but the device driver may override the default
during its initialization and specify some other name.

Likewise, network device drivers get to decide during their initialization
what the base interface name should be. I have this vague recollection of a
feature for forcing a particular interface name on a device driver, but
I can't recall how or even if the feature really exists. Obviously the setting
in /etc/modules.conf isn't it.

What the driver absolutely can't do is choose the interface number. The
kernel does that. So if eth0 already exists and the new driver wants to
be eth-something, then it will get eth1.

Terry

videocards correctly in X.

>>>>> "Derek" == Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com> writes:

Jeme> But will a single "low-mid range Athlon" outpace my dual PIIIs?

Derek> This depends on what you are doing, what chipset you get to run
Derek> it, and the speed of the memory.  It will certainly compile a
Derek> kernel faster (if that is the only task running), but may not
Derek> hold up under many heavy tasks.  Remember, you can't split a

I sent this to Jeme last night, but thought I'd post it here for
general information.  I have a dual P3-1GHz with a gig of PC133 RAM
and a P4-2.53GHz with a gig of 533MHz DDR RAM.  For an allnoconfig
2.6.5 kernel compile (for pippin-to-gravenstein comparison), here's
what I found:

 P4: $ time make 
     69.84s user 10.48s system 95% cpu 1:24.01 total
 
 P3: $ time make -j4
     159.04s user 20.73s system 181% cpu 1:39.19 total

The source files almost certainly had been loaded into cache by the
time I ran these, so disk speed isn't so relevant (the P3 probably has
marginally faster disks).  The P4 box had no swap and maybe a 100 meg
of RAM in use for X, mozilla, etc.  The P3 box has swap but not much
in use and approximately the same load.  Adding -j's to the P4 didn't
significantly change things.  With only a -j2 on the P3 about doubled
total time.

Note the P4 was not a lot faster.  From CPU clock speed alone (never
mind memory speed), you'd expect a 26.5% improvement with the P4, but
only observed about 18%.

FWIW.


--

The alias was probably inserted when your system was installed.  It
doesn't look like a discrepancy to me, if you want the Prism54 interface
to show up as wlan0, change that line to match the driver that is
actually loading.

The only thing I can think of is to write a couple of scripts that will
bring down the interface, unload its module, load the other module and
then bring up the interface.

>  Might there be advantages in doing so?

>From my experience, the hostap drivers are more stable, more versatile
and better supported than the kernel drivers.  Unless you want to use
Kismet for access point discovery, that is the only program that I have
run across that uses the prism2 drivers and not the hostap drivers,
though the developers are working on hostap support.  BTW, Wellenrieter
does a great job with the hostap drivers.

Have fun WAR driving!

From drl at drloree.com  Sat Apr 17 17:49:01 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sat Apr 17 17:49:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Real-life hardware comparison.
In-Reply-To: <86isfy8jbb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <200404170501.i3H51SBK012701@m5p.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404162329050.27682@shaft.bitmine.net>

	 <8665bya0pn.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	 <1082230140.1212.222.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <86isfy8jbb.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1082249345.1177.216.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2004-04-17 at 13:02, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Derek" == Derek Loree <drl at drloree.com> writes:
> 
> >>  I sent this to Jeme last night, but thought I'd post it here for
> >> general information.  I have a dual P3-1GHz with a gig of PC133 RAM
> >> and a P4-2.53GHz with a gig of 533MHz DDR RAM.
> 
> Derek> What chipsets are on the boards, is this single channel or dual
> Derek> channel DDR?
> 
> The dual P3 is a VIA chipset (Apollo Pro266, a SuperMicro
> P3mumble-mumble-mumble).  The P4 is an Intel 845GEBV2.  
> 
> RE single-vs-dual channel DDR... dunno, how do I tell?.

By the chipset, that one is a single channel, and will only run memory
at either 266MHz or 333MHz, the memory bus itself is either 133MHz or
166MHz.  The processor bus is run at either 400MHz or 533MHz.  The 865
and 875 chipsets will run dual channel,  The 875 has a memory bus of up
to 200MHz, so the DDR comes out looking like 400MHz, dual channel means
the processor can access two sticks of RAM at the same time (but the
processor must be designed for it).  The processor bus on the 875 can
run at 800MHz.

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Apr 18 13:34:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun Apr 18 13:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Real-life hardware comparison.
In-Reply-To: <20040417134221.32500.83543.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200404182032.i3IKWuUh037096@m5p.com>

> From: Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>
> On Fri, 16 Apr 2004, Elliott Mitchell wrote:
> > In your case it sounds like you'd want a low-mid range Athlon. You can
> > get higher-clocked P4s for the money, but the Athlons are far better
> > performers (AMD's performance code numbers are /roughly/ accurate).
> 
> But will a single "low-mid range Athlon" outpace my dual PIIIs?
> 
> That's really the question.  Is there really significant increases in
> real performance or is it just upgrading for upgrading's sake?
> 
> (We see this ALL THE TIME in the cycling world... splined bottom brackets,
> threadless headsets, etc... not BETTER than what came before, but
> different and "more advanced".  Looks good on paper, lots of benchmarks,
> but real-world performance doesn't change a bit.)

The two crucial points have been brought up. What speed P3s will that
board support? Unless you've got something designed to work in a
multi-processor environment the single faster processor is likely better.

I feel the first question is the big issue. Intel changed the pin
assignments near when the P3 hit 1GHz creating an electrical
incompatibility, but not a physical one (socket was the same, but the
newer processors would no longer work with older boards). Before you make
the decision check the exact model number and revision of your board,
what is the fastest processor it will support? If it can only handle
processors up to 800MHz...

The other issue is the worth depends on what exactly you're doing.
Threaded programs will do better on the dual P3s. Programs not written
for multi-processor systems will be faster on a single Athlon. This is
the majority of programs so unless your board supports processors faster
than 900MHz I have to point towards the single faster processor.

Analogy carries over in other ways: The reason real-world performance
might not change for these spiffy new bike parts is because you're not
the level of athlete that can take advantage of them.

If your home workload doesn't need huge performance, maybe you're
better off scrounging up the remaining parts for your dual P3 and
saving cash. I'll bet that more than likely you need better/more hard
drives before you need screaming CPU performance.

 In Mozilla when you hit the print button select the properties
button at the command screen and the string that is actually used
will be displayed. You can change this if you need to. Another 
method you can use with Mozilla is to simply print to postscript 
file and use ghostview type program (I use gv) to print the files. This
also allows you to easily correlate printed pages like 1,3,5 then 2,4,6
on the front and back of printed pages.
 I don't know how OO uses the printer or where the commands are kept in
the config files.


>   2) E-mail:
> 
>   This also used to work but stopped. I configured the latest-and-greatest
> mozilla-1.7b to send/retrieve mail from mail.appl-ecosys.com. Incoming is on
> the server's port 110 and downloaded from /var/spool/mail/<username> to the
> laptop's /home/<username>/mail; well, it's supposed to be but the connection
> keeps timing out. The hostname, mail.appl-ecosys.com, is in /etc/hosts on
> both the laptop and the server.
> 

telnet mail.appl-ecosys.com 110

If you can't access it then for some reason the server is not running
or it is configured not to allow connections outside of
localhost.localdomain (127.0.0.1) or a firewall is blocking the port.

as root 
service qpopper 
or
service --status-all
may tell you if the service is running.

Dan Young said:
> Russell Senior said:
>> I am curious how the hyperthreading on the faster P4's affect things.
>> Can someone who has one please do the:
>>
>>   $ make distclean
>>   $ make allnoconfig
>>   $ time make -j4

I also tried this on a dual P4 Xeon 2.4GHz box. Those are also HT
processors, so /proc/cpuinfo shows four logical processors. Not being
satisfied w/ only -j4, I continued to double the parallelization
(rerunning the distclean and allnoconfig each time). As you can see, the
improvement lessens dramatically after -j8. I was impressed that they
didn't start to increase until 512 parallel makes! I can't account for
the -j2 build being slower than the single make, but that was consistent
over several builds.

# time make
real    1m29.736s
user    1m17.550s
sys     0m12.420s

# time make -j2
real    1m32.468s
user    1m23.820s
sys     0m9.190s

# time make -j4
real    0m48.566s
user    2m5.960s
sys     0m12.760s

# time make -j8
real    0m42.608s
user    2m15.400s
sys     0m13.130s

# time make -j16
real    0m41.969s
user    2m18.690s
sys     0m13.240s

# time make -j32
real    0m41.771s
user    2m20.050s
sys     0m14.120s

# time make -j64
real    0m41.624s
user    2m20.770s
sys     0m13.990s# time make

AMD, definitely.  I don't much care for my K7S5A motherboard, but the
CPU has been a dear, and the combo cost like $50.  The Athlon64s are the
fastest thing out there and getting affordable I hear.  And I'm of the
opinion that DDR is appropriate on anything with 512MB or more of RAM.

a video card ($5 or so at FreeGeek) away from a whole 'nother 'pooter.

Yes and yes.  How much less money, really?  And do you need the
horsepower?  If you find you need a GB+ of RAM, you likely do.  
But watawino, I'm running an AMD 1.3GHz and a half-gig of RAM, and 
think it's more than I need.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Apr 18 22:05:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Apr 18 22:05:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] LinuxFest Trip Report
Message-ID: <20040419050330.GA6133@gate.kl-ic.com>

(cc. Bill Wright of Linuxfest)

On the PLUG mailing list, Russell Senior writes:
> Anybody go, want to do a trip report?

I went with my wife, and gave my Dirvish/Rsync talk .  I saw Brian
Martin (who gave a VMWare talk), and a couple of fellows from Corvallis,
but it appeared to be mostly Washington and B.C. folk.  There appeared
to be about 600-800 people there;  fortunately, it was a sunny day and
folks could schmooze outside, because inside it was CROWDED.

There were big posters and street banners for the Fest all over
Bellingham.  The locals really put a lot into this.

The Bellingham Technical College was well equipped (if small) for
this event; LCD projectors, free wifi in all the rooms, ample
parking, etc.  Sort of a PCC-Rock-Creek kind of setup.   Next year,
it will probably have to move to a larger venue, though. 

The cafeteria was taken over by vendors and user groups.  I bought
some books at 60% off.  I considered buying a stuffed Tux for $10 and
didn't (give the infants distros, not plush toys, I say!), and picked
up an install disk and a 5% off flier for VMware Workstation 4.5
( referral code VMRC-BILWRI265 ).  My wife got a Seattle Linuxchix T-shirt.

Outside, there were stands set up to sell grilled salmon, hotdogs,
and misc. junk food (excuse me, programmer fuel). 

The talks were mostly good to very good, though there were only 
6 time slots and things got crowded in the 11 parallel sessions.
I missed Rasmus Lerdorf's talk on PHP, which I'm told was the best
talk.  I did see two extremely good talks, one by Chris Negus and
Tom Weeks on Fedora / Redhat Troubleshooting (these guys needed
another hour) and one by Brian Hatch on Linux Security.   I saw a
talk that was merely "very good" by Tim Witteveen about the PNNL High
performance Linux Cluster, and another by Charles Ditzel of Sun, mostly
about Java Desktop,  a Sun Linux distro with Staroffice and Java and
Netbeans built in (SunJD users in the audience thought highly of it). 

My talk was in a smaller room, but still SRO with people in the
doorway, and well received.  It was in a room designed for cooking
classes (with a noisy fridge).  If the Detroit MI area Penguicon
( http://www.penguicon.org ) isn't scheduled on top of Linuxfest
next year, perhaps Marcel Gagne could give an intimate Linux Chef
talk in that room.

My wife went mostly to the newbies sessions, and learned a lot. 
Now I can look forward to her correcting my bad habits :-)  Newbie
sessions were moved from a room for 40 to a room for 100.  In general,
small planning mistakes like that were corrected rapidly and expertly.

There were a couple of "well, here's the screen of my laptop, 
here's an xterm, what do you want me to show you" talks that I
walked out of.  Obviously, a few people had never been in front
of a crowd of non-electronic brains before.  But with 5 to 11 tracks
to choose from, there were plenty of non-bozos right next door.

Brian and I made it a point to attend different talks, so he can tell us
about the different talks that he saw.  There will be lots of pointers
to the various talks, with many of the presenter's websites reachable,
at:     http://lfnw.blug.org/fest2004/schedule.dxp .

Some audience members were VERY knowledgable, it was like 6 hours of
Advanced Topics without the beer.  The beer came later, at the Afters
party sponsored by Fibercloud.  My wife and I went to that for about
half an hour;  I argued with a system manager from Boeing for a while
(he felt that Fedora Core 2 Test 1 Rawhide wasn't easy enough to use.
Well, duh!).   My wife and I decided that shouting over an amplified
band was less fun than watching the sunset over Puget Sound, and the
mountains and valleys back to Everett and south.

We stayed with friends in Gig Harbor on friday and saturday night, so
we did not learn much about Bellingham motels, beyond the fact that
there are a bunch of them.  We also learned that the free upgrade
from rental econo-car to mini-van can be financially punishing at
$2/gallon (the trip was 580 miles RT).  Vegetarians looking for food
on Saturday should consider the Potato Burrito at Casa Que Pasa on
Railroad Ave.

Overall, one of the best Linux events I've ever seen.  If they do one
of these next year, go!  My wife the non-geek had fun, so bring your
S.O. with you.  Perhaps with some additional help they might even
have a childcare track (script kiddie for kiddies?) next year, so
this could easily become a family weekend event.  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Apr 19 09:51:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Apr 19 09:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi (still): diagnosing lack of card recognition
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404190835340.11828@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404190835340.11828@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1082393456.1211.57.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2004-04-19 at 08:39, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   My enthusiasm was premature. On Saturday I tried to get a connection at a
> local coffee house (well, sorta' local: Urban Grind on NE Oregon). No luck.
> 
>   According to lsmod, prism54 is loaded, but I cannot get a MAC address from
> the card when I try 'iwconfig eth1'. If I try to not load prism54 (or it's
> synonym, prism2_cs) and use hostap_cs, there's still no luck. If I bring
> down the eth1 interface and try to bring it up again with the hostap_cs, it
> just will not come back up.

hostap_cs should activate the card as interface wlan0, you may also need
to set some of the wireless extensions like "essid any" and "mode
managed".  There are two steps to activating a wireless card after the
drivers are loaded (though most distros combine them into a single
step).  First the wireless extensions need to be set with iwconfig, then
the IP settings net to be set with ifconfig.  Debian combines these by
being able to define both the wireless extensions and the IP settings in
/etc/network/interfaces, so the command "ifup wlan0" loads both the
wireless settings and the IP settings.
> 
>   Where do I start to diagnose this problem? The card _does_ light up when
> placed in another laptop known to work.

Run "tail -f /var/log/syslog" as root, then pop the card out, wait, pop
the card back in.  My guess is that you have hotplug running and it will
try to load the card's drivers, hopefully this will give you a clue.  If
nothing happens, then either hotplug isn't running, or some piece of
hardware is broken.  If hotplug isn't running, "modprobe hostap_cs"
should spew to syslog.  To get a second opinion, try booting Knoppix
with the card in, then look through the syslog file.

HTH,

Derek Loree

From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Mon Apr 19 09:56:02 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Mon Apr 19 09:56:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] upgrading disk without reinstalling anything
Message-ID: <200404191655.i3JGtCFa009943@barrierb241.nike.com>

> Rob.Anderson-at-nike.com |PDX Linux| wrote:
> 
> > 1. Install the new 120G disk as a IDE slave
> > 2. Boot up. Partition and format the new disk.
> > 3. Sync the files from the old disk to the new disk, one 
> partition at a time.
> > 4. Install the bootloader on the new disk. (How do I do this part??)
> >
> > Does this sound like the path of least resistance? If so, 
> how do I do step 4?
> 
> This sounds like a good way to do it.  In step 3 be sure to 
> use a program
> that preserves permissions and isn't stupid about things like block
> devices.  Most Linux utilities do this well.  The only tricky 
> part really
> will be limiting your copies to one partition at a time or 
> else you'll end
> up copying your new drive back to itself ad infinitum.  I find the
> "--one-file-system" option to cp, rsync, or tar to be 
> especially useful.

I mounted one partition of the new disk at a time and used "cp -ax" as root. I mostly followed the Disk Upgrade mini Howto, except for the bootloader stuff, since I am using GRUB instead of lilo.

> 
> To reinstall GRUB, refer to the manual:
> 
> http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/manual/grub.html#Installation
> 
> I'd suggest making a GRUB boot floppy and testing it before installing
> GRUB in the MBR of your new drive.  This lets you back out easily if
> "something" goes wrong with no risk to your current setup.  The
> alternative of "grub-install" will probably work, but if it 
> doesn't, your
> system might be rendered unbootable.
> 
> Use the "native installation" method documented at:
> 
> http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/manual/html_node/Installing-GRUB-natively.html
>
>You may want to either print this out or have it in a browser on another
>PC since you'll be referring to it while your MythTV PC is down.
>
>The process would be:
>  1) Make a GRUB floppy per the instructions
> 2) shut down your PC
>  3) disconnect the IDE master and make your new drive the master
>  4) boot from the GRUB floppy
>  5) install according to the above instructions
>  6) reboot your PC, GRUB should boot Fedora
>
>If it doesn't work, you can always hook your original drive back up and
>your PC will be back where it was until you have time to figure out what
>went wrong.
>
>  -- Steve

Steve, The process you describe above worked great. There were a few hicups, like I did not label the new partitions and the kernal panic'd the first time I tried to boot with the new disk. But like you said, I was able to plug in the old disk and resolve the issue rather painlessly. Now with my 120G disk installed in the MythTV box I can store many more Scooby-Doo episodes and still have space to record Survivor!

Thanks,

-Rob Anderson

Or your home may have marginal power-- many do.  Invest in in a decent
UPS and you won't have to worry about lags/brownouts causing problems like
this.  It doesn't have to be a huge UPS.  I have a 650VA unit with a
massively overconfigured PC, three switches, firewall, and cable modem
plugged into it.  The runtime is only 5 minutes, but that's more than
enough to cover brownouts (30s is generally enough here) and times when I
pop the breaker by running too many tools in my garage.  (If I ever find
the guy who wired half my house on one circuit, he's gonna have some
'splaining to do...)

  -- Steve

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Mon Apr 19 12:11:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Mon Apr 19 12:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Go with Battery Backed up SDRAM or not...
Message-ID: <408423FE.5000307@robinson-west.com>

I'm curious what is available thinking to use it on servers
instead of hard drives for a mail spool.  I'm considering
setting up back up caches that never deliver locally and
only delivering mail that isn't sender subscribed depending
on which account it is bound for.  I don't want to write to
hard disk at this stage so that untrusted mail isn't hard to
erase.
 
I figure using RAM will lengthen drive life and lower
internal case temperature since a mail spool can get hit
a lot.  My scsi box especially is a bit on the warm side.  
I have a 32 meg SDRAM chip and a 64 meg one also
that's probably just PC66.  Is there an SDRAM to IDE
hard drive simulation kit?  It would need to take nicad
batteries, have a charger built in, one sdram slot, and it
would need to simulate the AT command set.  I
suppose it could also simulate an atapi device.  I probably
want to run a power connector for these out to the ups so
that the charger is powered even when the server is off.  
How much power does it take to run an SDRAMM stick
for five minutes anyways?

As far as just using Sandisks, I don't know that they
would take getting written to and erased so many
times a day very well.  I also don't know that any
NVRAM device is any easier to erase completely
than a hard disk partition is.

Another option using a Sandisk is to set up the mail
spool in system ram with a boot time write to it from
a Sandisk and dump the contents of the ram spool
back to the Sandisk at shutdown.  The latter approach
in the case of lockups or improper shutdown isn't
going to be as robust though as a device that always
holds the spool nonvolatilely written to in a cautious
manner.  This approach is a matter of getting two usb
2 cards with usb conectors integrated right onto
the pci board so that I can install Sandisks inside my
server cases protecting them.

The other spool protection option would involve an
assumption that at least one server will always be
running.  Using nfs or samba, I could have two ram
drives on each server implementing a mirroring idea.  
Server B will check for a mirror of what it had on
Server A when it boots back up and vice versa.  As
long as both servers aren't turned off simultaneously,
nothing ever gets lost.  This means that writes have
to be synchronized though between a ram disk and
it's mirror ram disk.  With this scheme, I could still
 write to Sandisk at shutdown, but I avoid writing
data out when a mirror is still up.  

An improvement would be mirroring the two
backups again on the mailhub itself.  I don't
know if I would want a permanent spool
storage option or not on every server, but I
guess that would be the best.  Sandisks aren't
cheap at $50 a pop.  A dedicated hard drive
for nonvolatile spool storage starts to makes
more sense if it doesn't have to be written to
very often and I have a way to confidentially
erase it.  A hard drive really starts to make
sense if Linux puts it to sleep saving me
power and reducing heat without any
manual intervention.  

I have an old Conner 250 floppy tape drive,
but I can't seem to get it to work very well
under Linux.  Don't know if the tapes are
 junk or what.  If enough tapes are good, it
wouldn't be that hard to pick up two more
drives.  Tapes, like floppies, can be
shredded if there's a cheap enough supply
to replace them.  If I mount the tape drives
inside the server cases they are protected,
though that really makes replacing tapes
a pain.  At some point I guess I should
build a glass enclosed case for my three
servers.

     --  Michael C. Robinson

have several cases where I use XP on FAT32 with just as much stability as on
NTFS.

especially without a complete backup of your data.

Why use NTFS if you can't perform backup and restoration using
3rd party utilities?  Is any netbooted system that allows the creation
of NTFS partitions to whatever size is desired and restoration
of any partition to them of any other size that isn't larger available
without a costly license?
  
It would make more sense if Microsoft shucked NTFS and went
with ext3 or Reiserfs, at least then you'd be able to back
up your Windows system using Linux.  Microsoft dos client 3 is
so out of date and it won't help with NTFS anyways.  The current
Intel products don't offer NDIS drivers for some of the intrgrated
nics anyways it seems.  The other concern I have with Dell is
that their Windows installation may not be stock, I may not be
able to go out and buy a copy of XP PRO if I want it and
have it install successfully.  Microsoft doesn't seem to want
people backing up OEM systems and buying Windows upgrades.
 
Hopefully I just won't need XP and won't have to worry about it.  
Windows 2000 is another story though.  My brother set up a
computer for our dad thinking it would be better than 98, but it
uses NTFS too.  Seems like I can't get everyone completely
out of Windows fast enough considering data integrity
problems working with NTFS.

I would argue that NTFS makes Windows less stable because it's
proprietary.  Any system that doesn't back up is hardly worth
having.

     --  Michael C. Robinson
