From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Mon Apr 19 13:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WiFi (still): diagnosing lack of card recognition
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404190835340.11828@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404190835340.11828@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1082407338.9338.26.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2004-04-19 at 10:39, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   My enthusiasm was premature. On Saturday I tried to get a connection at a
> local coffee house (well, sorta' local: Urban Grind on NE Oregon). No luck.
> 
>   According to lsmod, prism54 is loaded, but I cannot get a MAC address from
> the card when I try 'iwconfig eth1'. If I try to not load prism54 (or it's
> synonym, prism2_cs)

the wlan drivers use 'wlan0'  just try 'iwconfig' and see what the
interface name is.

>  and use hostap_cs, there's still no luck. If I bring
> down the eth1 interface and try to bring it up again with the hostap_cs, it
> just will not come back up.
> 

I have not had any luck with host_ap yet.

>   Where do I start to diagnose this problem? The card _does_ light up when
> placed in another laptop known to work.

dmesg | less

Look and see what the kernel *thinks* it found.

You can pop the card and reseat just before doing that, its quite
effective.

Then look at /var/log/messages.

BTW under redhat /etc/rc.d/init.d/pcmcia restart is almost always as
effective as popping the card, with the added benefit it tells you when
a pcmcia driver is stuck "on".  I often have an ethernet driver left
hanging around since the network still has it up.  Usually this means I
suspended with it in, or I told kudzu to autoconfigure it when it was in
while booting.


> 
> TIA,
> 
> Rich

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Apr 19 17:51:01 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Apr 19 17:51:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MythTV on the small and cheap.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404191742270.32551@shaft.bitmine.net>

OK, so I'm looking at TV stuff (half dreaming, half seriously).

I don't watch TV.  I don't have cable and I don't expect to ever need
multiple simultaneous television inputs.

I've been using my PC and its TVOut stuff to feed my television DVD and
DiVX ;-) videos for quite some time.  But now the TV is kind of dying and
I'm seriously considering just using a big old monitor instead of a
television.  The only trick is the VCR.  I still want access to the tapes.
So I will need TV-in so I can watch VHS on the computer (as well as
digitize analog input, which is cool).

I'm looking at the hardware options (including the MythTV hardware
database) and I'm coming to see that perhaps the most expensive choice is
the cheapest!  That is to say, it seems like the best price/performance
point is buying a high-end TV card that will do hardware encoding AND
decoding so that the PC itself can be relatively low powered.

Does anyone here know much about the hardware decoder cards?  Do they only
do output to TV or can the decoded video go to your regular graphics
adapter?

Does it make sense?  Cheap PC with good encoder/decoder card?  I figure
you can do the whole thing for well under $400 from scratch.  I happen to
have a PIII-450 sitting idle in my living room that would seem perfect
with the right card (the playback right now is choppy).

Is there a hardware decoder that will do DiVX and DVD as well?  Or is that
all of a piece and I'm drawing artificial distinctions?

Lots of questions... still reading.

More of an aside than a proposed solution, but if you A) don't mind
doing any necessary encoding in software, and B) have an interest in
creating your own videos, it's possible to use a MiniDV camera as a poor
man's A/D converter. Most cameras have analog inputs, and will stream
the incoming signal to your computer via a FireWire port in real-time.
DV cams can be had for under $300, too.

From sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com  Mon Apr 19 18:41:01 2004
From: sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com (Sasha Romanosky)
Date: Mon Apr 19 18:41:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MythTV on the small and cheap.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404191742270.32551@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <00c301c42678$81b48940$6401a8c0@LAPTOP>

I'm not an expert on all the codecs and what they can and cannot do. 

However, a P3/450 with a card that does mpeg encoding should be fine.
The key there, of course, is the card that does the encoding for you.
The hauppauge 250 cards seem to be the most popular. They're $150 at
fry's last time I checked. 

Join and read the mythtv lists, you'll find lots of (and probably too
much) information.

Mythtv has many modules, including one that can play DVDs. Actually, all
it really does is launch a real player (like mplayer) with command line
options. Nevertheless, having those modules integrated to mythtv results
in a single application that does it all. 

Good luck, 

sasha

Debian, added those (and removed the wrong modules with modconf, and now
I've got sound too! :) :)

From dzl at frenetic.com  Mon Apr 19 22:04:02 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Mon Apr 19 22:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] MythTV on the small and cheap.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404191742270.32551@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404191742270.32551@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <4084AF30.3070400@frenetic.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:


> Does anyone here know much about the hardware decoder cards?  Do they only
> do output to TV or can the decoded video go to your regular graphics
> adapter?

Typically they can do output to a monitor using a pass-through. 
Different cards may very though.

> Does it make sense?  Cheap PC with good encoder/decoder card?  I figure
> you can do the whole thing for well under $400 from scratch.  I happen to
> have a PIII-450 sitting idle in my living room that would seem perfect
> with the right card (the playback right now is choppy).
> 
> Is there a hardware decoder that will do DiVX and DVD as well?  Or is that
> all of a piece and I'm drawing artificial distinctions?

No, there are not hardware decoders that will do divx yet, divx is quite 
a bit different encoding and there is currently no standard so there are 
half a dozen slightly different codecs out there, divx, xvid, the ogg 
one, etc.. They may eventually be standardized under mpeg4, but until 
then it's unlikely there will be much hardware support for them.

Pretty much all the decoder/encoder cards will handle mpeg 1 and 2. DVDs 
are mpeg2, so any of them should be able to handle dvd decoding properly.

You can still use a slow pc with a decoder card and play divx stuff if 
you have a fast pc on your network. You can play it off the fast one and 
translate into mpeg1 or 2 streaming over the network. VLC works quite 
well for that. Or just reencode them before playing them.



From chris at maybe.net  Tue Apr 20 03:46:02 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Apr 20 03:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Reasonably-priced SCSI Drives?
In-Reply-To: <20040420000955.GA12807@nellump.net>
References: <20040420000955.GA12807@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <20040420104555.GD6662@maybe.net>

On Mon, Apr 19, 2004 at 05:09:55PM -0700, Paul Mullen wrote:
> Is there such a thing as a SCSI HDD that approaches $1/GB, or am I
> better off buying an ATA controller and a cheap IDE drive?

If you're worried about price, odds are you're better off buying an
ATA controller and a cheap IDE drive.

In the "budget range", there isn't so much a performance advantage --
these days you're paying for the warranty more than anything.

I have a small array of 10K RPM 9GB SCSI's for my homedirs and system
volumes and a huge array of 7200 RPM 120GB ATA's for "nearline" media
storage. Less noisy, too.

chris kb7rnl =->

This is a common strategy. I follow the MythTV list and users report great success with PVR-250 and PVR-350 cards. However, you are planning to use an AGP (I assume) video card to display to a computer monitor. This is not exactly the setup that most people use with these high end PVR cards so I'm not sure how successfull you will be on a low powered machine. I have chosen the other approach: Cheap capture card (bt878) and a powerful computer. The reason I chose to do it this way was because I could build a prototype on my existing linux box very inexpensively ($40 for the tuner card) and then upgrade the box for about $350. And if the thing fell flat on it's face after buying the new box, I would still have a powerful box that I could use or unload on eBay.

You could be looking at about the same price to take the approach that I have. Maybe an additional $100 to boost the RAM of a newer machine.

I first setup my MythTV box on a dual P2/300 with a bt878 tuner card, just to see if I could make it work. Once I got it running I bought a Dell 400sc P4/2.4Ghz 640MB RAM and it smokes.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Tue Apr 20 09:12:02 2004
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Tue Apr 20 09:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] how to find out where my new SATA drive is
In-Reply-To: <1082470208.2713.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1082470208.2713.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <20040420161123.GA9544@edge>

On Tue, Apr 20, 2004 at 07:10:08AM -0700, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I've just added a new SATA drive to my existing FC1 system.
> (2.4.22-1.2166.nptl kernel)
> 
> I'd like to initialize the drive, but I have no idea where it is in the
> device system. 
> 
> Where did my OS stash this information?
> 

As other have said dmesg is a good place to start.
Also /proc/partitions should have this information.

In /usr/src/linux/Documentation/filesystems/proc.txt
there is a useful list of info contained in /proc
The list is short, so I will reproduce it here.

Table 1-3: Kernel info in /proc
..............................................................................
 File        Content
 apm         Advanced power management info
 buddyinfo   Kernel memory allocator information (see text)     (2.5)
 bus         Directory containing bus specific information
 cmdline     Kernel command line
 cpuinfo     Info about the CPU
 devices     Available devices (block and character)
 dma         Used DMS channels
 filesystems Supported filesystems
 driver      Various drivers grouped here, currently rtc        (2.4)
 execdomains Execdomains, related to security                   (2.4)
 fb          Frame Buffer devices                               (2.4)
 fs          File system parameters, currently nfs/exports      (2.4)
 ide         Directory containing info about the IDE subsystem
 interrupts  Interrupt usage
 iomem       Memory map                                         (2.4)
 ioports     I/O port usage
 irq         Masks for irq to cpu affinity                      (2.4)(smp?)
 isapnp      ISA PnP (Plug&Play) Info                           (2.4)
 kcore       Kernel core image (can be ELF or A.OUT(deprecated in 2.4))
 kmsg        Kernel messages
 ksyms       Kernel symbol table
 loadavg     Load average of last 1, 5 & 15 minutes
 locks       Kernel locks
 meminfo     Memory info
 misc        Miscellaneous
 modules     List of loaded modules
 mounts      Mounted filesystems
 net         Networking info (see text)
 partitions  Table of partitions known to the system
 pci         Depreciated info of PCI bus (new way -> /proc/bus/pci/,
             decoupled by lspci                                 (2.4)
 rtc         Real time clock
 scsi        SCSI info (see text)
 slabinfo    Slab pool info
 stat        Overall statistics
 swaps       Swap space utilization
 sys         See chapter 2
 sysvipc     Info of SysVIPC Resources (msg, sem, shm)          (2.4)
 tty         Info of tty drivers
 uptime      System uptime
 version     Kernel version
 video       bttv info of video resources                       (2.4)

Bill Barry

> there a way to view the actual value being currently used in the kernel?
> For example, if I've set tcp_conntrack_max to be 10000 and there's
> currently 9500 tracked connections then I'd like to know that so I can

/proc/net/ip_conntrack lists all tracked connections; wc -l should show
you a total.  I also seem to recall a top-like tool that will monitor
this, but I forget the name.

From miken at hotsushi.com  Tue Apr 20 10:09:02 2004
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Tue Apr 20 10:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] how to find out where my new SATA drive is
In-Reply-To: <1082470208.2713.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <E1BFyj3-0001e5-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Hi,

On a 2.4 kernel, the default BIOS didn't find mine either.  I think 2.6 may
be different. There wasn't much to find six months ago but In a message on
the kernel developersd mail list, someone mentioned setting the drive to
"legacy".  On an Intel D865GBF BIOS, this meant changing the ATA/IDE
Configuration from Enhanced to Legacy and then setting the Legacy IDE
Channel to "SATA P0/P1, PATA Sec" but depending on your BIOS and kernel,
Your Mileage May Vary.  Once it's running correctly, it is very cool..

Cheers,Mike

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Apr 20 10:37:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Apr 20 10:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Two tools: unison and lndir
Message-ID: <1082482569.6096.72.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>


I've discovered two new tools that I thought I'd share.  The first is
called 'unison' and it's located at 
http://www.cis.upenn.edu/~bcpierce/unison/.

It's a two-way file synchronizer; if you've ever used rsync to try to
maintain a copy of your home directory between multiple machines, you
know it's not quite cut-out for two-way syncing.  Unison uses some
aspects of the rsync protocol, but has not only two-way support (i.e.,
it shows you if you've got changes in one file direct and not the other,
regardless of which way it is) but also conflict detection, like CVS. 
If you need to maintain multiple copies of files on different systems
(like between a laptop and a fileserver), it's a pretty nice tool.

The second is a very simple tool called 'lndir'.  It ships as part of
the XFree86 source as a way of maintaining multiple source trees with
one set of actual source files (for example, building for multiple archs
when the Makefiles don't support RPATH).  It recreates directory trees
in the destination and populates them with symlinks to files in the
source tree.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                          mailto:wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

> (2.4.22-1.2166.nptl kernel)
> 
> I'd like to initialize the drive, but I have no idea where it is in the
> device system. 
> 
> Where did my OS stash this information?
> 
> 

Just to be complete, is the driver for your SATA drive loaded?

On my system (an A7N8X motherboard), the "siimage" module has to be
to use SATA drives.  I'm currently using a 2.6 kernel, but if I
remember correctly the driver for the 2.4 kernel was also siimage.
(The module is derived from the name of the manufacturer of the
SATA chipset used by the a7n8x.)

With the driver loaded, it shows up as /dev/hd*.

dgc

From chris at maybe.net  Tue Apr 20 14:18:01 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Tue Apr 20 14:18:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] how to find out where my new SATA drive is
In-Reply-To: <1082490718.2713.18.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1082470208.2713.8.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> <20040420161123.GA9544@edge> <1082490718.2713.18.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <20040420211752.GE6662@maybe.net>

On Tue, Apr 20, 2004 at 12:51:58PM -0700, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> > As other have said dmesg is a good place to start.
> > Also /proc/partitions should have this information.
> 
> zero bytes, as with almost all entries in that dir, except kcore and
> mtrr.

They aren't on-disk files. Their file size may have no relevance to
their contents whatsoever. Try "cat /proc/devices", &co. instead. If
you are actually booting to a prompt and "cat /proc/devices" returns
absolutely nothing then there is something far more serious wrong with
your setup.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Tue Apr 20 17:09:02 2004
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Tue Apr 20 17:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Reasonably-priced SCSI Drives?
In-Reply-To: <20040420000955.GA12807@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404201635190.14960-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Mon, 19 Apr 2004, Paul Mullen wrote:

> A question for the list's SCSI aficionados:
>
> Where do you shop for reasonably-priced SCSI hard disk drives? By
> reasonably-priced, I mean something that's at least close to competitive
> with run-of-the-mill IDE drives. I realize that there's a price to pay
> for SCSI's performance advantages, but I have had a difficult time
> finding any SCSI drives that are less than 10k RPM. The prices (again,
> relative to IDE) are exorbitant, and the capacities are usually less,
> too.

About a year ago, when I was buying some new SCSI drives, I bought them
off of eBay: Fujitsu MAE3182LPs for about $40.--, IIRC. Not the cutting
edge of technology, but a safe step or back from said sharp point. It also
helped that the mother board in my current computer has 2 built-in SCSI
controllers.
>
> Is there such a thing as a SCSI HDD that approaches $1/GB, or am I
> better off buying an ATA controller and a cheap IDE drive?
>
I bet you can find some old 1 to 5 Gig SCSI HDD for $1/GB. Otherwise,
I doubt it. But then, one of the strengths of SCSI is that adding storage
is the same as adding another hard drive: you don't run into the limitations
of 4 devices (at most) per adapter, & you take advantange of the
multi-tasking ability of the SCSI interface.

Which leads to this rule about the practicality of SCSI: that if you are
going to have 5 or more storage devices (CDROM, hard drives, Zip drives,
etc.), then it makes sense to set use SCSI; if you will only have a single
hard drive, DVD/CDROM drive, & maybe one other peripheral, it frankly makes
better sense to stick with IDE.

Geoff

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Tue Apr 20 17:55:03 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Tue Apr 20 17:55:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Reasonably-priced SCSI Drives?
In-Reply-To: <20040420000955.GA12807@nellump.net>
References: <20040420000955.GA12807@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <28869-02155@sneakemail.com>

On Mon, 19 Apr 2004, Paul Mullen pem-at-nellump.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Where do you shop for reasonably-priced SCSI hard disk drives? By
> reasonably-priced, I mean something that's at least close to competitive
> with run-of-the-mill IDE drives. I realize that there's a price to pay
> for SCSI's performance advantages, but I have had a difficult time
> finding any SCSI drives that are less than 10k RPM. The prices (again,
> relative to IDE) are exorbitant, and the capacities are usually less,
> too.

Unless you go used, there's no touching the price/capacity of ATA drives
right now.  SCSI is less about performance and more about reliability, in
my opinion.

With software RAID (mirroring) it's cheaper to get 2 ATA drives and throw
one out every year than to get SCSI drives.  (Plus you get more capacity.)
Since the drives are redundant, you can be less concerned about how
fragile they are.  ;-)

> Is there such a thing as a SCSI HDD that approaches $1/GB, or am I
> better off buying an ATA controller and a cheap IDE drive?

Used SCSI drives using server-style SCA connectors can be had for $1/GB.

http://www.softwareandstuff.com/h_hd_ST446442W.html

However, the SCA-to-normal adapters add about $10/ea to the drives.

  -- Steve



From bderr at myrealbox.com  Tue Apr 20 17:57:01 2004

Date: Tue Apr 20 17:57:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] umask
In-Reply-To: <1082214873.3778.2.camel@timmy>
References: <40809900.2040606@brianquade.net> <1082214873.3778.2.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040421005652.GA18716@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>

On Sat, Apr 17, 2004 at 08:14:33AM -0700, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> This is from my umask manpage. (for the C function)
> 
> The  umask  is  used  by  open(2)  to set initial file permissions on a
> newly-created file.  Specifically, permissions in the umask are  turned
> off  from  the  mode  argument  to open(2) (so, for example, the common
> umask default value of 022 results in new files being created with per-
> missions  0666  &  ~022  = 0644 = rw-r--r-- in the usual case where the
> mode is specified as 0666).

The umask just subtracts permissions for newly created files.  For a
normal file the default permissions are 0666 or rw-rw-rw-.  When you add
in a umask of 0022 you get the following:  666 - 022 = 644 or rw-r--r--.
Umasks are really a simple concept, you just have to remember they are
*subtracting* from the default permissions.  666 for a normal file, 777
for a directory.

Here is a little lesson:

brian at brian:~$ umask
0022
brian at brian:~$ umask 000
brian at brian:~$ umask
0000
brian at brian:~$ mkdir f00
brian at brian:~$ ls -ld f00
drwxrwxrwx  2 brian users 48 Apr 20 20:54 f00/
brian at brian:~$ umask 022
brian at brian:~$ mkdir f00b4r
brian at brian:~$ ls -ld f00b4r
drwxr-xr-x  2 brian users 48 Apr 20 20:54 f00b4r/

Brian

-- 
The just man walketh in his integrity:
his children are blessed after him.  -- Proverbs 20:7

From dgc at easystreet.com  Tue Apr 20 20:38:02 2004
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Tue Apr 20 20:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] how to find out where my new SATA drive is
In-Reply-To: <200404202007.50017.kyle@silverbeach.net>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20040420164928.00abe7d0@www.hotsushi.com> <1082510697.2048.1.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> <200404202007.50017.kyle@silverbeach.net>
Message-ID: <4085EC5D.30508@easystreet.com>

Kyle Hayes wrote:
> 
> Um, I thought I read that SATA drives show up as SCSI drives under 
> 2.4.  I'm not sure about 2.6, but I'm pretty sure I read this 
> recently.
 >

Technically I suppose it probably depends on the specific SATA driver.
(SATA drives typically need their own driver; they don't use the
"normal" ide driver).  If your SATA port uses the SII chipset (like
the a7n8x motherboard), you need the siimage driver loaded, and the
drives show up as /dev/hd* "ide" drives.  This is the same for 2.4
and 2.6.

There might be SATA drivers around for other chipsets that work
differently; I don't know.

dgc

A bit off topic - I just purchased a repairable InFocus LP70
computer projector from Ebay.  1100 Lumen, 1024x768 XGA.  Tiny little
critter, about as big as a medium-sized computer book and weighing
2.4 pounds.   I expect to have it repaired in a week or two, and will
make it available for the May Advanced Topics, I hope.
                                                                                
Even more off topic - the repair would go faster and possibly cheaper
If I could test-swap lamps with another LP70 projector.  Does anybody
have access to one?
                                                                                
More off topic still - Lamps in most computer projectors cost around
$400 these days (they range from $250 to $600 and up).  Most of them
contain a special Philips UHP "burner", a very high tech arc lamp
that runs at 200 atmospheres and 6000C.  There is a place that
refurbs the lamp assemblies with new burners for $200.  Even
more interesting, TI, which makes the DLP moving-mirror display
modulators for the projectors, has a consortium going to standardize
and cost-reduce the lamps, which means cheaper projectors in a year
or two.  So if you can wait a while, you can get a projector that
will make mine look stupid at a fraction of the price.
                                                                                
Keith

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Apr 21 01:35:02 2004

So, I'm looking at these fancy motherboards with SATA and reading about
the benefits of the change.

Nearly everybody thinks that the cabling change is the #1 greatest thing
in the whole wide world.  That seems weird to me, but isn't really all
that important.

But the great loss as I see it is the decrease in the number of drives.
Nearly all of the layouts I've seen have just 2 SATA connectors.  What the
heck is that?  You can't exactly have a single boot drive AND a RAID array
for storage in the same system without some extra card shoved in there.

Is this temporary?  Why aren't they just lining these things up across
where the IDE interfaces used to be?  You could get like ten of those
things in that space.

I'd imagine it's temporary. Remember that currently, most SATA drives
(and basically all of the models that we mortals can afford) are just
PATA drives with integrated SATA bridges.

Certainly 3ware's latest RAID controllers take great advantage of the
connector density offering a 12-port model in about the same space as
your video card. They cost an arm and a leg, though.

Remember, when you're mass-producing a mainboard, saving 35 cents is
EVERYTHING. (That's not sarcasm.)

From guy1656 at ados.com  Wed Apr 21 06:24:02 2004
From: guy1656 at ados.com (GLL)
Date: Wed Apr 21 06:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SATA newbie question.
In-Reply-To: <20040421102847.GF6662@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404210131000.32551@shaft.bitmine.net> <20040421102847.GF6662@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <200404210627.03062.guy1656@ados.com>

: Remember, when you're mass-producing a mainboard, saving 35 cents is
: EVERYTHING. (That's not sarcasm.)

The big boys have 'Walmart'-ed the price of the 7-pin SATA to about 6 cents a 
pop, for ga-jillion quantity orders.

However, just as SATA took the wind out of the sails of an emerging cable 
technology called Infiniband 1X, (the jury is still out on Infiniband 4x and 
12x) the new 29-pin SAS (Serial Attached SCSI) might chew through SATA before 
SATA really gets super-popular in the consumer market (say, like USB or 1394 
Firewire.)

SAS receptacles are backward compatible with SATA, because the only difference 
is that the long power and the short signal 'eyebrows' are connected into one 
long bar that has two tabs below. The space between the 'eyebrows' holds two 
more differential pairs (and grounding contacts.) So technically that should 
provide twice the data readout as SATA. Eventually.
And SATA 3.0 is supposed to go to what, 6Gb/s?

More info on SAS at the developers' comittee website:
http://www.scsita.org/aboutscsi/sas/tutorials.html

-GLL, (aka 'the cable Guy')

"A shot-gun is parallel data. A machine gun is serial data."

> I did download jpilot, and it has a lot of conduits, but none for Avantgo.
> I'm wondering if there is some other package I need to download as well.

Barbara,

  I'll confess that I have no idea what is Avantgo. What I do know is that
jpilot is the interface between pilot-link and us. pilot-link comes with
every distribution; I think it's up to ... well, I forget now but I have
0.11.7 installed here on the RH 7.3 box.

  Try 'locate pilot-link'. If it's not there, grab either a Slackware
package at the pilot-link Web site (indirectly via jpilot, too) or the
source tarball.

HTH,

Rich

With the low end tuner card (no hardware compression), I got about 1 frame per 3-4 seconds. Piss poor performance, but it did work, and that's all I needed to know. Of course, that was watching live TV (compressing and decompressing simultaniously). And the video card in that box has about 4MB RAM, which would contribute to the poor perfomance greatly. It would have probably done much better with a PVR-250. Even a descent video card would have made a big difference.

I would say, skip the MythTV unless you want Tivo functionality. If you don't need simultanious capture and playback you can get by with a lot less in terms of hardware. I have no idea about divx. If you are just capturing video from VHS tapes and don't need the tuner for TV, you might consider getting a hardware motion JPEG capture card, like the old Miro DC10 or Iomega Buz card. I just saw a Buz card on eBay for $5.

On Wed, 2004-04-21 at 08:22, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   I'll confess that I have no idea what is Avantgo.

Avantgo is a conduit used to sync things like news and wepages, AFAIK. 
It's one of those Windows conduits.

As far as I know, there isn't currently a way to use such things... I
don't think you can use such conduits as the AOL ones, either, for
instance.  jpilot doesn't, as far as I know, support them.

You may have luck running the Windows sync software under Wine... I
really don't know.

It's been a few years since I've pulled out and sync'd my palm pilot. 
It is really really old.  I haven't purchased a new one for the simple
matter of so many conduits I would wish to use require Windows.

Rob




From m at phxlinux.org  Wed Apr 21 10:16:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] web failover server at remote location
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404210959320.10977-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

Let's say you have a web server at location A.  You also have a
mirror copy of the server at location B.  If server A goes down or the
connection to A is lost, what methods have people used to redirect all
traffic to server B?  What products have people used to accomplish this?
I suppose I could use a box running IPTables to do DNAT/SNAT to redirect
the traffic to the remote location, but that's assuming that the
connection to location A is available.  I guess the only option left would
be DNS and perhaps configuring the primary DNS server so that other
servers only cache the IP address for a short period of time?

A virtual penny for your thoughts...
Thanks,
~M

I /dev/null'd Avantgo when I got my Tapwave Zodiac (runs Palm OS 5.2).
Check out Plucker...

http://plkr.org/

    "Plucker is an offline Web and e-book viewer for Palm OS(r) based
    handheld devices and PDAs and comes with Unix, Linux Windows and Mac
    OSX tools, scripts, and conduits that let you decide exactly what
    part of the World Wide Web you'd like to download onto your PDA (as
    long as they're in standard HTML or text format). These web pages
    are then processed, compressed, and transferred to the PDA for
    viewing by the Plucker viewer.

    Plucker supports many features, including clickable images (pan and
    zoom), italic, narrow, and HiRes fonts, multiple concurrent
    databases, configurable display parameters and stylus options
    (gestures and hardware button navigation) ZLib and DOC compression,
    Perl and Python conduits and parsers, a Windows fully-integrated
    installer, and a whole lot more!"

The latest CVS snapshot of the Palm client has DIA (silk) support. There
is a very active community of open source advocates supporting this fine
project.

hth,
Sandy

[Aaron Ten Clay] 
Yeah, the best way to do this is pretty simple, just create multiple ADDRESS
records for the fqdn and all clients should be able to get to the site if
one of the servers goes down. The tricky part could be making sure your DNS
is still up. Assuming you have offsite DNS that you are confident is
reliable, you shouldn't have any problems.

Senior Distributed File Systems Engineer

?*Senior* SW Engineer and member of the Solutions Engineering team

*emphasis* on Linux-based NFS solutions.

POSITION REQUIREMENTS 
?Previous experience in the development of Windows or Linux distributed
filesystem technologies such as NFS, Samba, or CIFS.

at the protocol and kernel layers.  The ideal candidate is experienced
in the development of NFS v4.
?Ideal candidate is operating system agnostic; experienced with both
Windows and Linux file system development (or willing to rapidly acquire
proficiency in both).
?Ability to work for consensus in a team environment.
?Minimum bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Engineering, Physics,
Mathematics, or a related discipline is required.
?A *minimum* of 5 years of related development experience required. 
?Work location is PolyServe's headquarters in Beaverton, OR.

The nerdy way is to change upir ~/.Xclients-default to say

exec startkde


(Even nerdier is to put this in your ~/.Xclients, instead of the 
stuff that RH put there.)

From m at phxlinux.org  Thu Apr 22 05:16:02 2004
From: m at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Apr 22 05:16:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] web failover server at remote location
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404211309370.32551@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404220500001.11918-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

On Wed, 21 Apr 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> 
> On Wed, 21 Apr 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > Let's say you have a web server at location A.  You also have a mirror
> > copy of the server at location B.  If server A goes down or the
> > connection to A is lost, what methods have people used to redirect all
> > traffic to server B?
> 
> Round-robin DNS with really low TTL?

A couple complications with that...  First off, DNS is handled by the
domain registrar and there's not a way to modify the TTL through their
web-management interface.  I'll have to contact them and see if they'll
let me modify the TTL value, or else host DNS myself.
Secondly, the data on A gets pushed to B using rsync each night.  So
Round-robin would cause inconsistencies for users, particularly if they're
using webmail on server A and they see the mail for today and the next
time they login and get server B then the mail is not there yet.
It would be nice if you could set a priority for A records like you can
for MX records (maybe there's a way that I'm not yet aware of).
Also, I'm not sure that setting a really low TTL would always fix this
because of caching, unless the TTL was 0, which would significantly
increase the load on the DNS servers.

Matt,

All these points that you make are correct.  Some DNS will ignore the
value if it is really low.  As for a way to resolve your problem..

Currently the only way is at the ISP level.  To have your hosting
service have redunted connections for ISP and power.  You can then run
a load balancer with multiple servers behind the one IP.  DNS doesn't
have a similar information for other protocols like it has for MX.  It
has been proposed and may happen one day but not currently available. 
Something that would be nice for all people without lots of money. 
:-)

Josh

Subject: [PLUG] how to find out where my new SATA drive is
In-Reply-To: <1082611278.2277.1.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20040420164928.00abe7d0@www.hotsushi.com>
	 <1082510697.2048.1.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	 <1082527647.3348.1.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
	 <1082565474.1150.0.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <1082611278.2277.1.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1082655166.1150.843.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2004-04-21 at 22:21, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> On Wed, 2004-04-21 at 09:37, Derek Loree wrote:
> > On Tue, 2004-04-20 at 23:07, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> > > On Tue, 2004-04-20 at 18:24, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> > > > On Tue, 2004-04-20 at 16:52, Mike Neal wrote:
> > > > > When you boot the box is there any recognition of the SATA drive in the 
> > > > > BIOS messages or in the CMOS setup screens?  If the BIOS doesn't see it, 
> > > > > the OS may not either.
> > > 
> > > The BIOS sees it, and lets me take an option to turn it into a RADI
> > > device.
> > > 
> > > I'm not finding much when I google the board (ga-7vt600 1394) and look
> > > for a SATA driver.
> > > 
> > > Any pointers here?
> > 
> > Does "lspci" show the name of the controller?
> 
> I do not think so, but I'm no pro:
> 
> 00:00.0 Host bridge: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT8377 [KT400 AGP] Host
> Bridge (rev 80)
> 00:01.0 PCI bridge: VIA Technologies, Inc. VT8237 PCI Bridge
> 00:0f.0 RAID bus controller: VIA Technologies, Inc.: Unknown device 3149
> (rev 80)

This looks like the device.  The 2.6.4 kernel does support it, but the
kernel help doesn't say what the name of the module is.  The SATA
support is a sub-menu of SCSI devices.  You may need to do a custom
compile to make it functional.  Since you have IDE controllers for four
devices, look for the SATA drive(s) to be hde or hdf.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Apr 23 10:07:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Apr 23 10:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Training corpus for bayesian spamassassin
Message-ID: <20040423170534.GA18539@gate.kl-ic.com>

I'm looking for opinions about "selected training" for bayesian
spamassassin.

I am transitioning from bogofilter to spamassassin;  poor old bogo 
is having trouble with the spammers addition of random filler words,
and about 50% of spam was making it through (with admittedly high
thresholds to minimize false positives).  

I have a corpus of about 22K saved spams (since 2003 Aug), and about
110K saved hams (good GAWD I've read a lot of email since 1975).  
Estimated accuracy after some careful cleaning is 0.02% misclassification.
Training with all those through a spam filter creates an enormous
database, which makes mail processing and retraining rather slow.
A recent subset, or a selected subset, makes a lot more sense.

It is superficially plausible to train the bayesian filter on
spamassassin with just the misclassified false positives and
false negatives.  For the last week or so, I have been running 
spamassassin with the bayesian filter and training turned off,
to see what kinds of mistakes it makes with the heuristic rules.
It seems to pass about 30% of the spam (false negative) and trap
about 5% (false positive!!) of the ham, with the threshold set
to 3.0 and a whole bunch of addresses whitelisted.   I will have
quite a few false-negative spams before long (sigh), and I can
build a modest ham training list by including some of the recent
"squeakers".  The result should be a tolerably sized bayes_toks file.

Does this "selected subset" training approach make sense, or have I
got my head so thoroughly wedged up my behind that oxygen is not
getting through?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Apr 23 10:42:19 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Apr 23 10:42:19 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Training corpus for bayesian spamassassin
In-Reply-To: <20040423170534.GA18539@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040423170534.GA18539@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404231027200.16338@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 23 Apr 2004, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> I'm looking for opinions about "selected training" for bayesian
> spamassassin.

I think it's sufficient start with a base of 200 or so of spam
messages and a similar number of ham. The spam messages ought to be
recent, because their content has changed considerably even since last
summer.

It's always good to feed the false negatives and, especially, the
false positives to the bayesian db -- but I'd also make sure it got a
reasonable diet of standard spam and ham as well.

A threshold setting of 3.0 seems a bit low to me, but I haven't done
much testing with a setting that low.

After that, I'd feed any spam that didn't get BAYES_99 tag back to the
bayesian database. It doesn't really matter whether or not
SpamAssassin caught it correctly the first time.

Why?

My goal is that all spam should get BAYES_99 so that only content --
not mail headers, sender address, or whatever -- is used to identify
spam. That's not to say the other indicators aren't helpful, but to my
mind the goal is to classify messages based on content as much as
possible.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Apr 23 11:00:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

In-Reply-To: <1082741068.22562.2.camel@apollo.spears.org>

 use it only for test, as we say quite a lot.

 SELinux will be the result
SELinux is a form of MAC

> have a timeout reset on them, so flicking it on and off will not

> 
> Any ideas?  I would prefer not spend $600 on a remote power strip.  I am

I had a similar problem, a DSL modem that goes on the blink every week
or so and can only be fixed by power cycling (which, says Qwest, does
not make it faulty.)  It always happens when I've just started a long
trip.  For $9 I got a cheap mechanical timer from Radio Shack that
I've set up to turn the thing off and on again in the wee hours of
every morning.

A more sophisticated, and expensive, solution would be to get X-10
gear and power-cycle only when there's no connection to the modem.  That
may be the direction you want to look.

--Eric

attachment on the ups that is able to generate that power on signal at 
some interval.

exist.

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Fri Apr 23 16:04:02 2004

Date: Fri Apr 23 16:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] web failover server at remote location

> On Wed, 21 Apr 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
>
>> Let's say you have a web server at location A.  You also have a
>> mirror copy of the server at location B.  If server A goes down or
>> the
>> connection to A is lost, what methods have people used to redirect
>> all
>> traffic to server B?  What products have people used to accomplish
>> this?
>> I suppose I could use a box running IPTables to do DNAT/SNAT to
>> redirect
>> the traffic to the remote location, but that's assuming that the
>> connection to location A is available.  I guess the only option left
>> would
>> be DNS and perhaps configuring the primary DNS server so that other
>> servers only cache the IP address for a short period of time?
>
> This might work...
>
> http://www.linux-vs.org/
>
> with...
>
> http://keepalived.sourceforge.net/

The real problem is that you still are relying on getting to one IP. 
No matter how you set up load balancers or other information.

Ultimately it would be nice to be able to configure in DNS (which gets
cached on all clients) two or more locations to find the HTTP server.

This would allow you to have multiple servers located at different
sites and perhaps even have smart IP routing to the fastest server. 
The advantage of DNS having multiple MX records is the kind of
redundantcy for the other IP protocols that would benefit the user.

Since there is no such service today, the best you can do is to host
at a site that is doing reduntant ISP and power.

Josh

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Apr 23 17:56:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Apr 23 17:56:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Zot's power cycling for Linux
Message-ID: <20040424005447.GB21519@gate.kl-ic.com>

Zot writes:
> I have a remote machine that is locking up.  I want to be able to shut
> power down for 5 minutes, and then power back up.  The power supplies
> have a timeout reset on them, so flicking it on and off will not
> work....

Have you considered a watchdog timer board?  These run around $100, IIRC,
and will do a hard reset of the machine if they are not tickled by code
every so often.  I was having problems with a machine back in my BSDI
days, I got a such a card, wrote a BSDI driver based on the supplied Linux
driver,  and it worked!  When the machine went zombie and stopped tickling
the watchdog board, it would wait 30 seconds and then do a hard reset.

Turned out to be better to replace the flakey machine, though.  I think
I still have the old ISA card around someplace.

In any case, these cards come simple or complex, PCI or ISA, sometimes
with additional connections for switching an external relay on and off,
or activating when the phone rings and the modem doesn't answer.  Lots
of nifty options.  

Another alternative would be to temporarily attach a second linux box
with a signal from the parallel port controlling a 5V relay.  You could
have two machines control each other this way.  Finally, a task slow
enough to run on a 386-12 machine!  That's 0.012 GHz for all you young
people.  :-)

Keith

P.S.  Dollars to donuts this thread gets hijacked without changing
subject lines.

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Sat Apr 24 10:28:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Sat Apr 24 10:28:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] UPS for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <1082753813.9850.19.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <34019.209.210.31.3.1082652017.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com> <1082753813.9850.19.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20040424172721.GA17093@bavariati.org>

On Fri, Apr 23, 2004 at 03:56:54PM -0500, Zot O'Connor wrote:
> I am looking for the opposite.  A UPS that linux can tell to shut down,
> and restart.
> 
> I have a remote machine that is locking up.  I want to be able to shut
> power down for 5 minutes, and then power back up.  The power supplies
> have a timeout reset on them, so flicking it on and off will not
> work....
> 
> Any ideas?  I would prefer not spend $600 on a remote power strip.  I am
> thinking more like 30-60 for a UPS.

Two not-so-hackish fixes would be (a) new hardware (power supply most likely,
motherboard second) or (b) watchdog card.

For the hackish UPS fix, you'll want an APC SmartUPS, since it has
a signalling protocol that can do what you want.  UPSes with "dumb"
signalling (e.g. APC BackUPS) can just monitor the UPS state, not change
it.

And then you'll need something to give you access to the serial port on
the UPS.  A modem could be made to work, if you can spare a phone line.
A second computer or terminal server would work, if it could be given
its own IP address, and secured.  

There are also overpriced appliances from Black Box, Pulizzi and others
that can do this stuff.

My experience has been that it *always* pays to just swap-out the whole
box.  The customer appreciates a quick and certain solution, diagnosis
is easier and the bad system generally gets worse as time goes on.
Whole systems are *cheap*.

JOB DESCRIPTION

TITLE: Linux System Administrator

General Summary
Primary role is to provide support for all Linux production resources
with a secondary role providing support for other IT production
resources.

Principal Duties and Responsibilities may Include:
1. Troubleshoot and resolve day-to-day issues with Red Hat 9 Linux
workstations

proficient with Kickstart, Anaconda and rsync; able to write
sophisticated make(1) rules)
3. Maintain host configurations for network services (ISC DNS and DHCP,
NFS export lists, printer daemon configurations, Kerberos keytabs, SSH keys,
etc.)
4. Maintain asset and host configuration databases (good knowledge of
SQL required)
5. Resolve any hardware problems (should be able to build systems from
scratch)
6. Work with vendors to procure new systems, exchange failed parts, etc.
7. Compile and install new Linux kernels
8. Work with various package management tools (rpm, apt, yum, slink,
etc.)
9. Compile and install drivers for third-party hardware
10. Install and maintain production software (Maya, RenderMan, Shake)
11. Setup and maintain Windows applications under Wine
12. Setup and maintain configurations for X displays (including dual
monitors, multiple input devices, tablets, etc.)
13. Setup and maintain KDE desktop environment
14. Setup and maintain basic applications and utilities (Netscape,
OpenOffice, various media players, J2RE, etc.)

Supervisory Responsibility
None.

Minimum Qualifications
1. Three to five years experience in system administration (at least
three with Linux)
2. Three years experience in Perl programming
3. Demonstrated experience with network design, protocols and equipment
4. Demonstrated experience with Windows operating systems (2000, XP)
5. Demonstrated ability to prioritize
6. Ability to work under pressure
7. Detail oriented

Preferred Qualifications

filers
2. Experience with computer animation

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sun Apr 25 20:59:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sun Apr 25 20:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Using a dangerous mail network...
Message-ID: <408C88E1.2020402@robinson-west.com>

The suggestion to install a one way router serving a secondary private
network with a mailserver in it for untrusted mail sources has been
suggested.  The thought is, have an outside mail server route mail
either to the normal mailhub or the dirty mail mailhub based on what
senders the intended recipient trusts.  

I wonder if I should run spamassassin on both mail servers?  It's
preferable to be able to read a message that gets routed to the dirty
mail site, if it's important.  The dirty mail mail server faces a higher
probability of infection than the normal mail server which will only
get touched by trusted sources.

Do I need to worry about the smtp software itself getting infected?  
Is it fairly safe to use pine on the untrusted mail site from the
standpoint of infection?

If I'm not signed up for mailing list xyz, I wonder whether or not
mail can be routed from it to me and how much I should worry
about potentially sending a sender subscription request out to
xyz?  This clearly isn't what I want to do since informing a
mailing list that noone is subscribed to about getting messages
off of it doesn't help matters.
 
Sender subscription would cut out computer generated and anonymous
stuff.  Where many mailing sources don't care whether or not you want
their stuff and you're talking hundreds of attempted sends a day from
such sources, how much concern about missing out is really merited?  

The talk tonight was about AOL's black hole behavior for certain
sites they don't trust.  AOL doesn't ever bounce from certain
sources, AOL apparently just accepts and then trashes.  The smtp
protocol would be better if  notification via a return email had
always been part of the design so that the sender can know
what the recipient decided to do.

The bad news I've thought of so far...

    1)  Valid email can have unresolvable source or destination
         addresses.

    2) With this is mind, a spammer can use many unresolvable names
         since they figure you won't block mail from unresolvable sites
         because of 1.

    3) The received from ip could be from an open relay or a server that
         won't accept a notification message on what your server does with
         it's message...

         3a)  If it's an infected computer, sending a message to it is 
strange.

         3b)  If the source is a mailing list, sending a notification 
message is
                rude.

     4) There are some untrusted sites that should be black holed, but what
          if a site is bad for a while and then isn't anymore later?

     5)  The dirty mail site may periodically get important email which
           might not be seen if it gets infected.
     
     6)  It's logical to use a cheap computer for the dirty mail site which
          won't in all likelihood please the local users...

           6a) It's another computer, this means more power.

           6b) Remote access is too dangerous, this is a dirty mail mail
                 site after all.

     7) How much mail should be held from an untrusted source?  If
          it's an important sender, I guess the  first message will have to
          be good enough.

          7a)  Less junk on hard disk is good, but filling the routing 
server's
                 ram based spool in the event of a dirty mail site 
outage isn't
                 good.  I'd much rather hold on to trusted mail.

          7b)  No bounce may mean that a new valid sender doesn't know
                  they didn't get through where local users may not know
                  either if there's no dirty site or the routing server 
has filled
                  up and can't hold any more untrusted mail.

     8) This approach doesn't help with infected trusted sources.

     9)  Once email goes to the dirty site, moving it to the clean site
           isn't safe.  A lot of valid mail could go there where the dirty
           mail site is protocol sealed from the outside world.

The biggest thing is when to bounce mail and where to bounce to
so that senders can know they didn't get in even if the routing mail
server fills up.

/etc/modules.conf shouldn't start samba,
rc.samba might
/etc/inetd.conf might (but shouldn't)
/etc/xinetd.conf might (but shouldn't)
/etc/rc.d/init.d/smb might (on RatHed-ish systems .. i know you're using
a real linux, i just put that there in case)

On Mon, 2004-04-26 at 12:48, Barbara Pfieffer wrote:

happens?  Does it power down until I tell it to power up?  Does it power
down until line power is back on?  In this case line power is already
on...

I was hoping for a solution in the $30 range.  I could grab a relay,
attached to a parallel port, then to a sock, and put it all in a
junction box and ship it, but that sounds a bit iffy to rely remotely.

> For the hackish UPS fix, you'll want an APC SmartUPS, since it has

> signalling (e.g. APC BackUPS) can just monitor the UPS state, not change
> it.
> 
> And then you'll need something to give you access to the serial port on
> the UPS.  A modem could be made to work, if you can spare a phone line.
> A second computer or terminal server would work, if it could be given
> its own IP address, and secured.  
> 

I have other computers nearby.  My problem is that I do not understand

or for line power to return to the unit.  What if line power is already
on?

> There are also overpriced appliances from Black Box, Pulizzi and others
> that can do this stuff.
> 

Overpriced is right.  Remember when Black was cool *and* cheap?

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Apr 26 15:34:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Apr 26 15:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Making a DVD as bootable
In-Reply-To: <002f01c42bcf$94d26ea0$4b00a8c0@alphaqq4o0tdl8>

Message-ID: <1083018838.1639.7.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2004-04-26 at 13:46, Chris Penwell wrote:
>     I have the CD ISOs for Mandrake 10.0 community. I am able to mount
> the ISOs to a directory. Here is what I want to do. I want to be able
> to burn them to a DVD and then boot from the DVD into the install.
>  
>     I know how to burn on to a DVD using KDE however I'm not so naive
> as to think I can just burn the files to a DVD and expect it to work.
> Is there anything I have to do to make it (the DVD itself,) bootable?

If I understand what you want to do, you will need to mount all of the
ISO images, then copy the contents to a new directory and make a new ISO
image for the DVD size.  When you make the new ISO image, you will need
to specify the location of the boot image file from the bootable CD ISO
image.  I don't have any experience with the KDE burning tool, but I
know that gcombust will do everything but mount the ISO images.  The man
page for mkisofs has all of the details, including how to specify the
boot scheme.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

to capture packets remotely, say from within an ssh session or a cron
job, and save the results to a file. Then you can bring the file into
a local workstation and use Ethereal to analyze the traffic visually
postmortem.

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Apr 27 07:40:03 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Apr 27 07:40:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] (M$) CommView-like setup for console
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404261702400.18820-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0404261702400.18820-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <1083076614.9391.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2004-04-26 at 19:10, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> I would like to monitor some _strange_ traffic I'm (not) seeing and 
> accounding to the Tech Manager the only thing (he's a Windows guy) that 
> he's found that will see this is CommView.  And rather than install this 
> Windows software on a machine and take it to the NOC I'd like to get the 
> same functionality out of an OS solution but it has to run console.
> 
> The CommView software (GUI) looks a lot like some of the output I
> associate with Ethereal and friends.  I don't have nearly enough
> experience with networks so I'm open to suggestions.


Just run ethereal for 20 mintues on any network.

It should be real easy to understand.

The trick is filters.  The capture filters use the tcpdump language
(host www.cnn.com and not port 22), whereas the filters use the display
language (roughly ip.addr == 212.212.212.212 and tcp.port != 22).  Use
the GUI to build the display filters.

Make great use of sorting by clicking columns, display filters on IP,
port and protocol.

Always set it to update and scroll on update when you capture.  You can
turn these off live, but sometime you cannot turn them on.

Also if your capture file is huge, you can pre-filter with the tcpdump
lingo on load "ethereal -r file host www.cnn.com"  This can save lots of
memory.

--

From srau at rauhaus.org  Tue Apr 27 08:56:02 2004

Message-ID: <20040427155506.GA22196@rauhaus.org>

* Zot O'Connor <zot at whiteknighthackers.com> [040427 07:40]:
> On Mon, 2004-04-26 at 19:10, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> > I would like to monitor some _strange_ traffic I'm (not) seeing and 
> > accounding to the Tech Manager the only thing (he's a Windows guy) that 
> > he's found that will see this is CommView.  And rather than install this 
> > Windows software on a machine and take it to the NOC I'd like to get the 
> > same functionality out of an OS solution but it has to run console.
> 
> Just run ethereal for 20 mintues on any network.
> 
> It should be real easy to understand.
 
Also note that if you're on a switched ethernet network (and most
ethernets are these days), you will only be able to sniff broadcast
traffic, and multicast and unicast traffic that is destined for the
specific MAC that the switch sees on the port your sniffer is plugged
in to.

If you want to see _all_ the traffic on a given network, you'll need
(someone) to configure a monitoring port. In the Cisco world this would
be done with "port monitor" or "monitor session" commands, depending on
the specific platform.

--Stafford

From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Tue Apr 27 10:08:01 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Tue Apr 27 10:08:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sorted find command
Message-ID: <200404271707.i3RH6tU1004076@barrierb241.nike.com>

Michael Montagne wrote:

"I need to find all the files from last november 1 and return a sorted
list by date.
My attempt "find . -mtime -179 -ls -exec ls -ltr {} \;" does not sort.

Seems to me like this should work.  Can some offer a helpful hint?"

Michael,

ls -ltr will sort by date/time. However, in this case you are calling ls -ltr on each file that you are finding, individually, and therefore loosing the context by which the sorting would occur.

-Rob Anderson

> I need to find all the files from last november 1 and return a sorted
> list by date.
> My attempt "find . -mtime -179 -ls -exec ls -ltr {} \;" does not sort.
> 
> Seems to me like this should work.  Can some offer a helpful hint?
> 
find . -mtime -179 | xargs ls -l --sort=time 

...will work better.

Admittedly, it's not a perfect solution.  If the list of files is too
long, xargs will deliver it in chunks to ls.

Ali

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Tue Apr 27 10:46:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Tue Apr 27 10:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Sorted find command
In-Reply-To: <20040427165500.GA25287@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040427165500.GA25287@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <1083087929.4181.7.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Tue, 2004-04-27 at 09:55, Michael Montagne wrote:
> I need to find all the files from last november 1 and return a sorted
> list by date.
> My attempt "find . -mtime -179 -ls -exec ls -ltr {} \;" does not sort.
> 
> Seems to me like this should work.  Can some offer a helpful hint?

Use the '-printf' option to 'find' generate a listing of 'YYYYMMDD
filename\n' and pipe through 'sort -n'.

e.g.:

$ find . -mtime 179 -printf '%AY%Am%Ad %p\n' |sort -n

If you want more fields than the date and filename, you can include
them.

Wil

Yes we are a new group.  We started down the path back in October with
significant investment by the OSU community, the administration, and a
number of other groups of campus.  We have also seen significant
interest from just about every group on campus (colleges, research
centers, etc) for the Open Source Lab.

The research program will really have two main "arms."  The first arm
will be infrastructure and hosting.  This includes data-center
management, support, hosting, and development for open source projects. 
We are already a huge mirror for various open source projects (we are
pumping out about 1.3 TB every day).  On top of that, we have
specialized infrastructure for a number of projects including Gentoo,
Debian, Ark Linux, Mozilla, Freenode, etc.  Our purpose here is to
create a strong community and backbone for Open Source projects seeking
a home.  We've got good infrastructure and big pipes, and helping these
projects is good for the community, and good for OSU.  We also host a
wiki and bugs space for open source projects, mail lists, all that sort
of thing.

The second "arm" of the Open Source Lab will be development.  We will
engage in research and development of open source projects, tools, and
processes that are useful in education, research and outreach.  These
are the goals of OSU, and since we are an OSU institution, they are our
goals as well. :)  We are seeking to help OSU processes, engineering and
research using open source.  You can find out some more on the web site
and here http://osuosl.org/about/mission/

If you have any questions please let me (operations manager) or Scott
Kveton (Program Director) know; we are happy to answer them.  We are
very excited for this opportunity.  OSU is the first university in the
US and maybe the world to approve of and build an Open Source research
institution.  Any insight, advice, comments, or questions from the Open
Source community are very valuable to us, so let us know!

From gepr at tempusdictum.com  Tue Apr 27 16:17:02 2004
From: gepr at tempusdictum.com (gepr at tempusdictum.com)
Date: Tue Apr 27 16:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] The well-scheduled man.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404271548170.32551@shaft.bitmine.net>

Jeme A Brelin writes:
 > 
 > I've come to believe my life could use some organization.
 > 
 > I once had a Palm device.  Still got it, somewhere.  Never remembered to
 > sync it and it didn't have an alarm mechanism that actually made itself an
 > unavoidable part of my life.  (There is just one catch, Catch 22:  You
 > have to remember to check your reminders.)
 > 
 > So, what do y'all use for calendar management?

I don't intend to be a smart-ass; but, there's really only 1 trick
to calendar management, regardless of the technology.  Every morning
(or any other time of day... as long as it's the same time each day)
go over the things you have to do that day and the next few days.

So, for example, I use Gnome Calendar.  It does things like throws
up dialog boxes and emails me etc.  But, all that is totally useless
if I don't spend about 15 minutes each day gathering my thoughts about
what should be done that day and over the next few days.

If you spend that 15 minutes, any technology will suffice, including
a little spiral notebook, a wad of sticky notes in your pocket, or 
notes written on your arm.

Oh, and if you, for some reason, simply cannot discipline yourself to
take that 15 minutes each day, then your life doesn't need organizing.
[grin]  You'd be better off winging it.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Apr 27 17:50:03 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Apr 27 17:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: The well-scheduled man
Message-ID: <20040428004853.GA31787@gate.kl-ic.com>

Jeme writes:
> I've come to believe my life could use some organization.
...
> Anything stand out as the tried-and-true old stand-by?

My scheduler is vi.  Emacs will do in a pinch.

For the last 20 years or so, I have carried a one-page "to-do" list
on a standard sheet of paper, printed out from an ASCII file.  I keep
the paper in a pocket.  On this list are:

lines 1-2:  My own critical contact information.  Who to call if I croak.
lines 3-4: Must do now only stuff.
lines 5~20: Next month of scheduled events, flights, motels, car rental, etc.
lines 20~25: Noncritical things to do.
lines 26~62:  Some phone numbers, addresses, other info
lines 63-65:  Books to buy or from library.
margins and back:  Handwritten notes for new stuff.

I rewrite the page and print it about every two days.  On trips it gets
very marked up.  Some noncritical things disappear.

When I print a new one, the old one goes into a file.  I have a foot thick
stack of old papers live in a filing cabinet.  Good place to look for old
phone numbers, etc.  This is the real value of the paper system, as most
PIM software doesn't keep old snapshots, and just accumulates data forever.
Too much data makes important data less valuable.

Low tech, maybe.  A couple of years ago, I was at a conference with
Carl Helmers, the guy that started Byte magazine.  We were shooting
the breeze, and I pull out my paper to check something.  He pulls out
his.  Eyebrows raise.  He has done the same thing for 20 years.

Note:  I also carry an old REX-3 sometimes.  I erased it three weeks ago
while fuddling a battery swap.  I haven't missed it, though I really
should reload it before my next out-of-town trip.

Keith

Some stuff should be on paper though digital paper might not be a bad idea.

If you compress your paper down and recycle the savings, how many trees
are you really killing?  Before accusing anyone of being a tree killer 
because they
use paper, consider the resources involved in using any sort of digital 
substitute.  

How much environmental impact is there from producing the double A, 
triple A, etc. batteries that a palm pilot needs?  How much mercury and
other toxins will your palm pilot put into the environment over it's
lifetime?  Paper may actually be better for the environment than your
palm, course this can be weighed based on how much paper you're
going to use.  Arguably, different methods produce different results and
differing amounts of pollution.  Who knows, someone may invent a
nontoxic portable power source for the palm.

Michael Robinson <plug_0 at robinson-west.com>:
> What I don't get is why ical if it's so popular isn't being brought up
> to date?

I can't think of anything in particular that needs to be done to
bring ical "up to date".  it does everything I want, and I
haven't seen any bugs.  it's also easy to customize with tcl,
though I haven't felt a need to do that.

I think most of the things that other people would want to change
involve using a different gui toolkit, and it probably seems
simpler to write a new calendar program for a new toolkit.  after
all, ical itself is not a lot of code, and most of it is gui.

it's kind of nice to have a program that isn't stuck in a
constant feature/bugfix change cycle.  I wish more programs were
like that.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Apr 28 10:43:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Apr 28 10:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Wifi Clinic:  BEFW11S4 at Bestbuy, $40
Message-ID: <20040428174125.GB5450@gate.kl-ic.com>

Bestbuy has Linksys BEFW11S4 Wireless Access Points on sale for
$39.99 after rebates.  These are IMHO about the easiest and most
functional 802.11b units around.  They configure via HTML, so they
are O.S. independent (though some of the Linksys units run Linux
internally).  These are 100mW units with two antennas and good range,
and Linksys also sells external booster amplifiers that take you up
to the FCC limit.

I bought one to make sure they are as easy to configure as I
remembered - they are, you can get to the WAP's web page and make
necessary naming, channel, and security changes in less than five
minutes.  I will experiment a little more and see if I can do a
"DHCP passthrough" to my wired internal network.

Those participating in the Linux Wifi Clinic on May 15 who do not
already have a WAP should consider buying one.  Note, these are NOT
suitable for running a managed-access  www.personaltelco.net  site,
you will probably want to buy a Soekris box for that.  That is about
10dB too complicated and expensive for an introductory clinic.

The sale ends Saturday. 

Keith

Mississippi for roughly $100.

The range is excellent.  My version, the version 3, has a few issues,
however.  After between one week and a month of running, it starts
dropping about 50% of the wireless packets to go across the interface. 
Pull the power plug, count to three, plug it back in and we're back in
business without any real interruption.

The different versions of this WAP are considerably different, though,
when it comes to innards and firmware.

> I bought one to make sure they are as easy to configure as I

> necessary naming, channel, and security changes in less than five

FWIW, I'm using it entirely as a wired-wireless bridge.  DHCP passes
right through it, no problems at all.

This last weekend I took it down to the coast and set it up with the
PPPoE DSL down there, to act as a wireless/wired bridge, access point,
and router.  It worked like a charm.  The little DHCP server in there
doled out IP addresses properly... just plug and play.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Apr 28 11:11:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed Apr 28 11:11:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Wifi Clinic:  Senao PCMCIA cards
Message-ID: <20040428180957.GC5450@gate.kl-ic.com>

Another note for the clinic.  Also IMHO, the best PCMCIA wireless
card is the Senao 2511CD Plus with external antenna.  These are
often rebranded, for example mine is rebranded with Teletronics
International.  The ones with internal antennas are cheaper and
a bit more rugged, but somewhat less capable.

I purchased mine for $100 (*with* "rubber ducky" antenna) from a
friend at local company Invictus Networks (www.invictus.com), but
you can also mail order them from Netgate (www.netgate.com) in
Spokane, about the same price.  There are probably cheaper places,
but both these organizations support Portland wireless efforts and
open source.

These cards are based on the PRISM chipset, and work well with the
HOSTAP drivers (preferable to the WLAN-NG drivers).  Note that many
chipsets do not have Linux drivers, like the cheap card-du-jour at
Frys.  In particular, the broadcom chipset is unsupported, and the
TI chipset linux driver is barely alpha.  Learn about the chipset
before you buy the card, and remember that the chipsets sometimes
change given the "same" model number of card.  Check the version, too!


You can learn all sorts of technical details about WIFI cards from
the FCC website:

https://gullfoss2.fcc.gov/prod/oet/cf/eas/reports/GenericSearch.cfm?calledFromFrame=N

My Senao card has an FCC ID of NI3-2511CD-PLUS3, so I enter the
following into the webpage:

Grantee Code:  NI3
Product Code:  -2511CD-PLUS3

then click "Start Search" .   All sorts of weird and partly relevant
technical details emerge, including the user's manual.  You can often
figure out the chipset from this data.  If there is a dash in the ID 
after the three letter grantee code, be sure to include it in the
product code, the FCC site is too stupid to wildcard the search.

Show up with the right stuff at the clinic, and things will go a lot
smoother.  

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

On Wed, 28 Apr 2004, Steven Raymond wrote:

> Why do I get this message about certain packages not being
> installed, when doing an "apt-get upgrade":

To get the "kept back" packages, run

  apt-get dist-upgrade

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Apr 28 14:20:03 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Apr 28 14:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] apt-get: why "kept back"?
In-Reply-To: <32857.209.210.31.8.1083182998.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <32857.209.210.31.8.1083182998.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0404281412170.13676@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 28 Apr 2004, Steven Raymond wrote:
> Why do I get this message about certain packages not being installed, when
> doing an "apt-get upgrade":
>
> The following packages have been kept back:
> discover gnomemeeting gnumeric kamera kcmlinuz kcoloredit kcron
> kdat kdead.....
>
> It seems that the work-around is to go "apt-get install <paste>" where
> paste is the list of packages from above.  While it seems to work, why the
> hassle?
>
> What is the reason for the packages being held back in the first place?

"apt-get upgrade" will update existing packages, but will NOT install new
packages.

If the dependencies have changed for the existing packages and the upgrade
would require the installation of new packages, then "upgrade" will leave
the packages with unmet dependencies untouched.

There are other reasons why a package might be "kept back".  It is best to
see what happens with the package when you try to "install" it.  It's a
tiny bit dangerous to just go ahead and "install" it, though... so do
this:
apt-get -s install <package kept back>

This will do a dry run, but not actually change anything.  You can figure
out from that output why "upgrade" didn't touch it.

> Someone in #orlug said it was because of a dependency problem.  I
> thought the purpose or goal of apt was to fix all dependency problems
> for you?

Yeah, apt handles dependencies just fine.  But "upgrade" isn't for making
major changes to a system (like adding new packages), but for safely
upgrading all of your existing packages.

> How do I make it not hold back any packages with apt-get upgrade?

If it's a production system, I promise you that the behavior is exactly
what you want.  If it's a desktop system, you can either do the dangerous
"dist-upgrade" (dangerous only because it'll install any new available
packages with whatever dependencies it deems fit, so you might end up with
a substantially less secure and sleek system than before).

J.
--
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Apr 28 17:24:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Apr 28 17:24:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] attention geometry geeks
Message-ID: <863c6n4onz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

I am looking for an elegant way of computing the nearest distance from
an arbitrary point P to a surface.  I have solved the simple cases
(for primitive shapes box, cylinder, sphere, toroid), but this one is
slightly more complex.  The case I am concerned about involves the
removal of a sphere of radius r and center point Q from those
surfaces.  Obviously, if point Q is not less than distance r from the
surface, it doesn't remove any material.  And in general, I only care
about cases where point Q is on or above the surface of the primitive.

Any pointers, ideas, solutions?

Thanks.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Apr 28 17:58:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Apr 28 17:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] attention geometry geeks
In-Reply-To: <863c6n4onz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <863c6n4onz.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404281751130.15325@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 28 Apr 2004, Russell Senior wrote:

> I am looking for an elegant way of computing the nearest distance from an
> arbitrary point P to a surface.  I have solved the simple cases (for
> primitive shapes box, cylinder, sphere, toroid), but this one is slightly
> more complex.  The case I am concerned about involves the removal of a
> sphere of radius r and center point Q from those surfaces.  Obviously, if
> point Q is not less than distance r from the surface, it doesn't remove
> any material.  And in general, I only care about cases where point Q is on
> or above the surface of the primitive.
>
> Any pointers, ideas, solutions?

Russell,

  You may want to read the chapter on convex hulls in de Berg, M., M. van
Kreveld, M. Overmars and O. Schwarzkopf. 2000. "Computational Geometry:
Algorithms and Applications, Second Edition". Springer-Verlag. Or, Joseph
O'Rourke's 1998 "Computational Geometry in C, Second Edition" published by
Cambridge University Press.

  The latter book's chapter on convex hulls in three dimensions and the one
on search and intersection may give you the tools you need.

Rich

I've added, though it could be a bug in the ROMs.  It's also possible
that the '##TETHERED' feature -- type that string into the phone app

for some folks if you believe their websites. :-)

Russell> radius r and center point Q from those surfaces.  Obviously,
Russell> if point Q is not less than distance r from the surface, it
Russell> doesn't remove any material.  And in general, I only care
Russell> about cases where point Q is on or above the surface of the
Russell> primitive.

Russell> Any pointers, ideas, solutions?

Rich>   You may want to read the chapter on convex hulls in [...]

Not to put too fine a point on it, but (having found and flipped
through them at Powells) those two references were useless.  They deal
with polyhedral surfaces.  Flipping through other likely looking
titles at Powells was mostly equally useless.  One book came close,
over in the Computer Graphics section, but didn't address my
particular problem.

I am dealing with primitive shapes and need exact solutions.  And at
least for planar and spherical surfaces, I know I can get them.

For a cross-section of the planar case, see:

   <http://www.aracnet.com/~seniorr/indented-plane.png>

In region III, the computation is easy, just the distance to the
inside of the sphere, which is the distance PQ (remember, P is the
arbitrary point, not shown in the figure) minus the radius of the
sphere, r.  In regions I and II, the nearest distance is to points R
or S, respectively.  Above and to either side of those regions, the
nearest distance is the same as to the unindented surface.

The spherical surface case is equally tractable because of the
symmetry.

The intersection between the spherical divot and a cylinder or toroid
is probably going to be hairier since the radius of curvature isn't
isotropic.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

Keith wrote:
> The Senao card I have *looks* like a standard 16 bit PCMCIA card;  it
> doesn't have the funny ground strip that I see on 32 bit cardbus cards. 
> Check other sources, but I believe this ought to work with older machines.  

Earlier I suggested looking at the FCC website for info;  I was too
lazy to take my own advice.  For the Senao card, the PDF manual is at

https://gullfoss2.fcc.gov/prod/oet/forms/blobs/retrieve.cgi?attachment_id=262871&native_or_pdf=pdf

... which states on page 1: "The PC card is a standard PC card that fits
into any PCMCIA Type II slot."

Thus, it ought to work with older laptops.  These cards are 11MBPS maximum
rate, typically a lot slower for data in actual practice.   The 54MBPS
802.11g cards are typically 32 bit cardbus.

Again, before buying a card get the FCC ID if you can, and look it up
on the FCC website.
